questions.text: A 23-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the office because of chronic episodic pelvic pain. The pain begins 2-3 days before menses and continues throughout the menses after which it subsides. Menarche was at age 14. She has a regular menstrual cycle of 25 days with 5-6 days of moderate bleeding. Medical history is significant for recurrent migraine headaches with aura. She is not sexually active. Physical examination shows a fixed anteverted uterus and nodularity in the posterior cul-de-sac. The physician offers surgical therapy, which the patient declines at this time. Which of the following is the most appropriate option to treat this condition medically?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings of chronic episodic pelvic pain, immobile (fixed) uterus and posterior cul-de-sac nodularity highly suggests the diagnosis of endometriosis.

Endometriosis is defined as implantation of endometrial glands and stroma outside the endometrium that grows and triggers an inflammatory response. It is a chronic condition that requires optimal approach for the management of related symptoms based on their severity. Patients with mild pain are usually managed with combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) and as-needed non-steroids anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). For those with contraindications to combined OCPs (see table), progestin-only pills (POP) are an acceptable alternative, which act by inhibiting the growth of endometrial tissue.  

 

Laparoscopic resection of ectopic endometrial tissue is considered the gold standard and is both diagnostic and therapeutic. However, those with mild symptoms or those who decline surgery (as this patient) should be treated with medical therapy. Other medical treatment options which are reserved for patients with severe or recurrent symptoms include danazol, GnRH analogues, and aromatase inhibitors.  

Option Analysis

❌ Combined estrogen-progesterone oral contraceptive pills:
Incorrect: Combined OCPs act indirectly by suppressing ovarian hormones secretion, thereby reducing endometriosis disease activity. Although combined OCPs are the first-line agents in managing endometriosis-related pain, they are contraindicated in this patient due to the history of migraine headache with aura.
✅ Progestin-only pills:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Clomiphene:
Incorrect: Clomiphene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator that is used for ovulation induction. It works by inhibiting the negative feedback on the hypothalamus and pituitary gland, thereby increasing follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH). While endometriosis does predispose to infertility, this patient is not sexually active and is not planning for pregnancy at this time.
❌ Danazol:
Incorrect: Danazol inhibits mid-cycle surges of follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) and prevents steroidogenesis in the corpus luteum. Although it is effective in treating endometriosis-related pain, it is not the preferred option due to its androgenic side effects (acne, edema, weight gain, hirsutism and gynecomastia).
❌ Anastrozole:
Incorrect: Anastrozole acts by inhibiting aromatase, the enzyme that converts androgens to estrogens, thereby regulating estrogen formation in the endometriotic lesions. Its off-label use for treating endometriosis-related pain is reserved for women with severe refractory pain because of limited data and the risk of osteoporosis.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman comes to the office because of a missed period. History reveals her last menstrual period was six weeks ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and takes no medications. A urine pregnancy test is obtained in the office and is positive. Laboratory studies reveal a quantitative hCG of 500 mIU/mL. Pelvic examination reveals a closed non-tender cervix and no adnexal masses. A transvaginal ultrasound is obtained and does not definitively show an intrauterine pregnancy or ectopic pregnancy. Two days later, the patient goes to the emergency department with left lower quadrant abdominal pain. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows guarding and rebound tenderness in the left lower quadrant. Ultrasound shows free fluid in the abdomen. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Recheck hCG and complete blood count

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with acute lower abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, positive rebound tenderness, and hemodynamic instability (i.e., tachycardia and hypotension), raising concerns for a ruptured ectopic pregnancy.  

Ectopic pregnancy should be suspected in any woman of reproductive age who presents with abdominal pain and/or vaginal bleeding. The first step is to decide if the patient is hemodynamically stable or unstable. In an unstable patient, the first step is to stabilize the patient (e.g., IV fluids), obtain hCG levels, and perform FAST ultrasound. Next, a surgery consult and emergent surgery should commence. In extreme acute cases, hCG may not be obtained before surgery.  

 




Option Analysis

❌ Recheck hCG and complete blood count    :
Incorrect: Conservative measures are not appropriate for any unstable patient with an acute abdomen. IV fluids are necessary to address her hemodynamic instability, and she ultimately requires surgical intervention.
❌ Give intramuscular methotrexate    :
Incorrect: Methotrexate for the treatment of ectopic pregnancy is appropriate after the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy has been confirmed, the patient is hemodynamically stable, hCG concentration is ≤5000 mIU/mL, the mass size is less than 3 cm, and there are no contraindications for the treatment. This patient is currently unstable, which is a contraindication for methotrexate treatment.   
❌ Intravenous fluids and observation    :
Incorrect: Conservative measures are not appropriate for any unstable patient with an acute abdomen. While IV fluids are necessary to address her hemodynamic instability, she also requires surgical intervention.
✅ Refer for emergency surgery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.    
❌ Obtain transvaginal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Transvaginal ultrasound should be obtained in hemodynamically stable patients who are suspected for ectopic pregnancy. Since this patient is unstable and the abdominal ultrasound is positive for free fluid in the abdomen, the next best step is surgery consultation and emergency surgery.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 2, is admitted to the labor and delivery unit in active labor. This pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes mellitus, which was managed with metformin. An hour after admission, the patient delivers a healthy baby weighing 4100 g (9 lb 1 oz). Thirty minutes after the placenta is delivered, blood starts flowing profusely from the vaginal vault. Placental examination reveals it is fully intact. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. On physical examination, the uterus is soft and boggy. A large-bore IV catheter is inserted, followed by fluid and blood resuscitation. Which of the following is the most appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with postpartum hemorrhage following the delivery of the placenta. The physical examination reveals a boggy, soft uterus, which is consistent with the diagnosis of postpartum hemorrhage due to uterine atony.  

Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) is an obstetric emergency and is one of the most common causes of maternal mortality. Postpartum hemorrhage is defined as 500 ml of blood loss following a vaginal delivery, or more than 1000 ml of blood loss after a C-section. The definitive management of PPH depends on the underlying cause. The most common causes of postpartum hemorrhage can be remembered as 4 T’s - tone (i.e. uterine atony), trauma (i.e. lacerations), tissue (i.e. retained products of conception), and thrombin (i.e. coagulopathy). The most common cause of PPH is uterine atony. Normally, after delivery, the uterus continues to contract, which clamps the spiral arteries and reduces uterine bleeding. Risk factors for uterine atony are factors that cause overdistention of the uterus such as multiparity, greater than 4 previous deliveries, previous C-section or uterine surgery, polyhydramnios, large fetus (as seen in this patient), anesthetic drugs, and prolonged labor. The diagnosis of uterine atony is made clinically by demonstrating a boggy, soft and enlarged uterus while excluding other sites of bleeding. Initial management includes maternal stabilization, uterine massage and oxytocin (1st line); 2nd line agents include methylergonovine and surgical interventions.



Option Analysis

❌ Administer methylergonovine:
Incorrect: Methylergonovine is a uterotonic and analgesic used in postpartum hemorrhage secondary to uterine atony to control the bleeding. However, it is not first-line treatment and should be used if other measurements have failed. 
❌ Perform suction curettage :
Incorrect: Suction curettage is used if there are retained products of conception, such as retained placenta. The diagnosis is made when the placenta is not expelled 30 minutes following delivery. This patient’s presentation (e.g. soft, boggy uterus) is more consistent with uterine atony. 
❌ Placing a tamponade balloon:
Incorrect: Balloon tamponade is a method that involves the insertion and inflation of a balloon to mechanically control postpartum hemorrhage. It is indicated in patients who have failed uterine massage and uterotonic agents. It can also be used if there is a delay in the administration of uterotonic agents or to decrease bleeding while waiting for interventional radiology or surgical options.
❌ Administer tranexamic acid:
Incorrect: Tranexamic acid is an anti-fibrinolytic agent commonly used in postpartum hemorrhage and traumatic bleeding. However, other measures should be performed prior to this. 
✅ Perform uterine massage :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine health examination. The patient feels generally well and has no complaints. Medical history is notable for gastroesophageal reflux disease managed with pantoprazole. Family history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is normal. The patient is interested in being tested for CA-125 because a friend who was recently diagnosed with ovarian cancer was found positive for this marker. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?

choices.text: Screening with CA-125 for ovarian cancer is recommended
Screening with CA-125 and transvaginal ultrasound for ovarian cancer is recommended
CA-125 is useful only for screening premenopausal women
CA-125 is used in case of equivocal results on fine-needle biopsy for confirmation
CA-125 should be used for follow-up of post-treatment surveillance

questions.solution:
Ovarian cancer is the 2nd most common gynecologic malignancy in developed countries and 3rd in developing countries (cervical cancer is most common). In the United States, ovarian cancer is the most common cause of gynecologic cancer death. Currently, no screening methods have been found to reduce mortality. Serum cancer antigen 125 (CA-125) is the most extensively used laboratory test for the early detection of ovarian cancer. Unfortunately, this test has many shortcomings, as it may be elevated in healthy individuals and in many benign conditions, it fluctuates during menstruation, it increases with age, and it can vary with ethnicity and smoking status. CA-125 serial measurements are instead an important component of the follow-up of post-treatment surveillance.

The current recommendation of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists are as follows:    

Asymptomatic woman at any age - Screening with CA-125 alone or in combination with transvaginal ultrasound is not recommended and increases the risk of invasive tests.    

Premenopausal women with very high levels of CA-125 OR ascites OR signs of distal metastases should be referred to a gynecologic oncologist.    

Postmenopausal women with elevated levels of CA-125 OR nodular/fixed pelvic mass OR ascites OR signs of distal metastases should be referred to a gynecologic oncologist.  

Women who are considered high risk for developing ovarian cancer such as those with a BRCA mutation or Lynch syndrome should be referred to genetic counseling.   

Option Analysis

❌ Screening with CA-125 for ovarian cancer is recommended:
Incorrect: Screening with CA-125 in asymptomatic women is not recommended due to high rates of false-positive results and increasing the risk for invasive testing.
❌ Screening with CA-125 and transvaginal ultrasound for ovarian cancer is recommended:
Incorrect: Screening with CA-125 and transvaginal ultrasound alone or in combination in asymptomatic women is not recommended due to high rates of false-positive results and increasing the risk for invasive testing.
❌ CA-125 is useful only for screening premenopausal women:
Incorrect: Screening with CA-125 in asymptomatic women is not recommended due to high rates of false-positive results and increasing the risk for invasive testing. In general, the specificity of CA-125 in asymptomatic premenopausal women is particularly low compared to postmenopausal women because it is often elevated in many benign conditions which are common in reproductive-age patients.
❌ CA-125 is used in case of equivocal results on fine-needle biopsy for confirmation:
Incorrect: Fine-needle biopsy is not used for the diagnosis of ovarian cancer due to increased risk for seeding. Diagnosis is made with surgery.
✅ CA-125 should be used for follow-up of post-treatment surveillance:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to OB-triage for evaluation of uterine contractions. The patient is 37 weeks gestation and is admitted for labor induction. Once roomed, the anesthesia team begins preparation for administration of analgesia via placement of a catheter in the spine. Following the procedure, the patient has full mobility of the lower extremities and can still feel her contractions. She has no sensation in her pelvic floor and perineum. This procedure involved the administration of an anesthetic agent into which of the following anatomic sites?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for labor induction with a procedure performed that results in anesthesia of the pelvic floor and perineum with retention of musculoskeletal strength and sensation of the lower extremities. These findings are consistent with epidural anesthesia, which reflects the placement of a catheter into the sacral canal.   

The two standard methods of anesthesia during labor include spinal and epidural anesthesia. The anesthetic agent is introduced with a needle into the subarachnoid space at the L3-L4 vertebral level during spinal anesthesia, which produces anesthesia below the waist. This results in loss of pain in the perineum, pelvic floor, and birth canal and the loss of sensation of uterine contractions. In addition, this procedure results in loss of the motor and sensory functions of the bilateral lower extremities. Since this procedure pierces the dura mater and arachnoid mater, it can result in a cerebrospinal fluid leak and postural headache post-procedure.    

In contrast, epidural anesthesia involves anesthesia administered in the sacral canal using an indwelling catheter covering the S2-S4 spinal nerve roots, providing anesthesia to the birth canal, pelvic floor, and perineum while preserving uterine contractions and lower extremity strength and sensation. It also has the advantage of leaving the catheter in the epidural space and administering the anesthesia repeatedly if needed.



Option Analysis

✅ Sacral canal:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Subarachnoid space :
Incorrect: The subarachnoid space is the space anesthetized with spinal anesthesia. Unlike epidural anesthesia, spinal anesthesia results in motor and sensory function loss below the waist.   
❌ Subcutaneous tissue :
Incorrect: Local anesthetics are injected into the subcutaneous tissue for regional anesthesia, such as in the setting of laceration repairs, IV placement, or other invasive procedures.  
❌ Pudendal nerve  :
Incorrect: Pudendal nerve blocks are often utilized for diagnosis and management of chronic pelvic pain caused by pudendal neuralgia and for regional anesthesia in other gynecologic, obstetrical, and anorectal procedures.  
❌ Lumbar nerve roots:
Incorrect: Anesthesia of the lumbar nerve roots would result in loss of motor and sensory function in the lower extremities.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, comes to the clinic at 28 weeks of gestation for a follow-up appointment. Two weeks ago, her blood pressure readings were 145/95 and 146/93 respectively on 2 separate occasions. At the time, a urinalysis showed protein excretion of 300 mg/24 hr and liver function tests and full blood count were within normal limits. Vitals at the clinic today show a temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse of 95/min, and blood pressure of 161/110 mmHg. She currently feels well and discloses only mild occasional headaches.  She denies any visual changes, urinary symptoms or abdominal pain. Physical examination is within normal limits. Non-stress tests are reactive without decelerations. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s elevated blood pressure?
questions.solution:
This patient has preeclampsia, defined as new-onset hypertension with either proteinuria or end-organ dysfunction after 20 weeks gestation. Preeclampsia can be further classified as preeclampsia without severe features or preeclampsia with severe features. Severe features include systolic blood pressure (SBP) ≥160 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure (DBP) ≥110 mmHg, symptoms of central nervous system dysfunction (e.g. severe headache), hepatic abnormality (e.g., severe persistent right upper quadrant pain, elevated liver enzymes), thrombocytopenia (<100,000 platelets/microL), renal insufficiency, and pulmonary edema. In general, preeclampsia with severe features is an indication for delivery at ≥ 34 weeks of gestation, while patients without severe features are delivered at ≥37 weeks of gestation.  

Regardless of the type of preeclampsia, antihypertensive therapy is currently indicated in pregnancy for blood pressure SBP ≥160 mmHg or DBP ≥110 mmHg. Patients with comorbidities may initiate treatment earlier. Drugs that are safe to use during pregnancy include hydralazine, methyldopa, clonidine, labetalol, and nifedipine (helpful mnemonic: “Hypertensive Moms Can Love Nifedipine!”). Intravenous labetalol and hydralazine are first-line agents for acute therapy of severe hypertension.



Option Analysis

❌ Magnesium sulfate :
Incorrect: Magnesium sulfate is the drug of choice for the prevention of seizures, also known as eclampsia. Currently, there is no consensus regarding the optimal magnesium regimen. Magnesium may be administered at the onset of labor, induction, or prior to C-section delivery. It is not routinely given to stable antepartum patients, though it is occasionally given to patients with preeclampsia with severe features who are being considered for expectant management. While administering magnesium is not incorrect in this case, it will not actually treat this patient’s blood pressure, as it has minimal effects on blood pressure.
❌ Lisinopril:
Incorrect: Lisinopril (an angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor [ACEi]), angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs), and direct renin inhibitors are routinely used in non-pregnant patients with elevated blood pressures; however, they are contraindicated during pregnancy due to significant risk for fetal renal abnormalities. 
❌ Losartan:
Incorrect: Losartan (angiotensin II receptor blockers [ARBs]), angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, and direct renin inhibitors are routinely used in non-pregnant patients with elevated blood pressures; however, they are contraindicated during pregnancy due to significant risk for fetal renal abnormalities. 
✅ Labetalol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nitroprusside :
Incorrect: Nitroprusside is used in hypertensive emergencies. Due to the risk of fetal cyanide poisoning, it is not routinely used in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, gives birth to a healthy 3400 g boy. Four hours later, she suddenly develops a generalized seizure. The pregnancy was complicated by preeclampsia, which was managed with lifestyle modifications. Medical history is unremarkable, but her partner states that during the past day, the patient has been experiencing headache and blurry vision. Current temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 150/95 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears drowsy. Cranial nerves are intact. Reflexes are +3 bilaterally, and clonus is present. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with postpartum eclampsia, as indicated by her hypertension and onset of seizures.    

Eclampsia refers to the new-onset of generalized, tonic-clonic seizure or coma in a woman with prior preeclampsia. The exact cause of eclamptic seizures is not entirely understood, but it is hypothesized to be related to a dysfunctional autoregulatory system of the cerebral circulation which results in vasogenic and/or cytotoxic edema. The majority of patients experience a prodrome of signs and symptoms in the hours before the initial seizure which includes hypertension, headache, visual disturbances, right upper quadrant or epigastric pain, ankle clonus, and altered mentation. Some patients may be asymptomatic. Eclampsia can occur preterm, intrapartum or postpartum. Management is aimed to prevent maternal hypoxia and trauma, treat the hypertension, prevent recurrent seizures, and evaluate the necessity of prompt delivery. Magnesium sulfate is a first-line medication that works by stabilizing excitable membranes and preventing seizure recurrence. In cases refractory to magnesium sulfate, 2nd-line drugs are indicated (e.g., amobarbital, thiopental, or phenytoin).    

Pregnancy-related hypertensive disorders such as preeclampsia are associated with obstetric complications such as growth restriction, preterm delivery, abruptio placentae, and stillbirth. Women with pregnancy-related hypertensive disorders are also at increased risk for hypertension, cardiovascular disease, cerebrovascular disease, renal failure, and diabetes.   

Option Analysis

❌ Hydralazine:
Incorrect: Hydralazine is a hypertensive medication commonly used in pregnancy. Current guidelines include hypertensive therapy to prevent stroke when SBP ≥160 mmHg or DBP ≥110 mmHg. However, hydralazine does not prevent the recurrence of seizures, and therefore, another medication is urgently needed at this time.
✅ Magnesium sulfate :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Amobarbital :
Incorrect: Barbiturates work by facilitating GABA action by increasing the duration of chloride channel opening, ultimately decreasing neuron firing. In eclampsia, drugs such as amobarbital are considered 2nd line treatment for refractory cases not responding to magnesium sulfate administration. 
❌ Phenytoin :
Incorrect: Phenytoin is an anti-seizure medication that works by altering sodium movement across the cell membranes in the motor cortex, therefore decreasing seizure activity. In eclampsia, it is considered 2nd line treatment for refractory cases not responding to magnesium sulfate administration. 
❌ Calcium gluconate :
Incorrect: Calcium gluconate is an antidote used for magnesium toxicity by regulating action potential threshold in nerve and muscle cells. Signs and symptoms suggestive of magnesium toxicity include absent patellar reflex, respiratory rate ≤12 breaths/min, flushing, and hypotension.

questions.text: A 32-year-old gravida 1 para 0 woman at 37-weeks gestation is undergoing a scheduled cesarean section. The patient is prepped and draped, and a horizontal incision with slight convexity is made at the pubic hairline. The remainder of the procedure proceeds without complication. Several hours after the procedure, the patient begins experiencing severe right flank pain and lightheadedness. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F), blood pressure is 92/66 mmHg, and pulse is 109/min. Physical examination demonstrates a large area of ecchymosis over the right flank. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis demonstrates a large rectus sheath hematoma with extravasation into the retroperitoneal space. Which of the following intraoperative actions could have prevented this patient’s complication?

choices.text: Ligation of the inferior epigastric artery
Incision made above the arcuate line
Ligation of the common iliac artery
Ligation of the right superior epigastric artery

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a large rectus sheath hematoma following a cesarean section. This complication was most likely caused by failure to ligate the inferior epigastric arteries, a key step of this common obstetric procedure.

Injury to the inferior epigastric artery may occur with incisions or surgical procedures performed below the arcuate line, as the artery crosses the lateral border of the rectus muscle to enter the posterior rectus sheath. This artery is a branch of the external iliac artery and is a major vascular supply to the anterior abdominal wall.

Procedures performed below the arcuate line include cesarean sections, hysterectomies, laparoscopies, and bowel resections. Horizontal incisions performed during these procedures are at risk of injuring the inferior epigastric vessels and thus must be identified and ligated intraoperatively. Failure to do so may result in the formation of rectus sheath hematomas and ongoing hemorrhage as blood dissects into the retroperitoneum.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ligation of the inferior epigastric artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Incision made above the arcuate line:
Incorrect: An incision made above the arcuate line reflects improper surgical technique for a Pfannenstiel incision. Transverse incisions above the arcuate line are indicated only in select upper abdominal surgeries.  
❌ Cross clamping the aorta:
Incorrect: Cross clamping the aorta is not indicated during an elective cesarean section. This surgical technique is only indicated during resuscitative thoracotomy or major aortic surgeries.  
❌ Ligation of the common iliac artery  :
Incorrect: Ligation of the common iliac artery would result in arterial insufficiency of the lower extremity. It is not a component of performing a cesarean section.  
❌ Ligation of the right superior epigastric artery:
Incorrect: The right superior epigastric artery branches from the internal thoracic artery, traverses the rectus sheath at the seventh costal cartilage, and descends on the posterior surface of the rectus muscle. This artery is not at risk of injury during a cesarean section.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old, gravida 2 para 1 at 34 weeks gestation, comes to the emergency department due to colicky abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting for the past day. She also feels generalized malaise and describes it as “more than usual.” The patient’s current pregnancy has been uncomplicated, other than an upper respiratory infection a week ago. Her first pregnancy was complicated by preeclampsia, which was managed with antihypertensive medications. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 155/100 mmHg. On physical examination, right upper quadrant and epigastric tenderness are noted. The conjunctiva is pale and non-icteric. Laboratory results are shown below:



Which of the following tests is most likely to assist in establishing the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, thrombocytopenia, low hemoglobin, and elevated direct bilirubin levels and liver enzymes, favoring the diagnosis of HELLP syndrome.    

Hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, low platelet count (HELLP) syndrome is a medical condition seen in pregnant and postpartum women; it is thought to represent a severe form of preeclampsia. The exact pathogenesis of HELLP syndrome is unclear. Microangiopathy and activation of intravascular coagulation are responsible for the laboratory findings in HELLP syndrome. The activation of the coagulation cascade results in the consumption of platelets, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is seen as schistocytes on peripheral smear. Risk factors for developing HELLP syndrome include a previous history of preeclampsia or HELLP syndrome. Patients often present with midepigastrium/right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and generalized malaise. Less commonly, headaches, visual changes, jaundice, and ascites may occur. Complications of HELLP syndrome are abruptio placentae, acute kidney injury, subcapsular liver hematoma/hepatic rupture, and pulmonary edema.  



Option Analysis

❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Abdominal ultrasound can be used in the diagnosis of acute cholecystitis. While patients with cholecystitis can present with colicky abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, the presence of high blood pressure, low hemoglobin, low platelets, and elevated liver enzymes raises concern for HELLP syndrome. 
❌ Lipase and amylase levels :
Incorrect: Lipase and amylase levels can be helpful in establishing the diagnosis of pancreatitis. However, this patient is presenting with high blood pressure, low hemoglobin, low platelets and elevated liver enzymes, which raises concern for HELLP syndrome. 
❌ Liver biopsy  :
Incorrect: Liver biopsy can be used to confirm the diagnosis of acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP), which can occasionally be difficult to distinguish from HELLP syndrome. However, liver biopsy is an invasive test and rarely used. Also, AFLP will likely present with fever, liver failure, encephalopathy, and severe hypoglycemia.
✅ Peripheral smear:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ ADAMTS13 activity and inhibitor testing:
Incorrect: ADAMTS13 activity and inhibitor testing can assist in the diagnosis of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). TTP is caused due to deficiency of the ADAMTS13 protease, which is responsible for cleaving von Willebrand factor multimers. TTP typically presents with a triad of thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and acute kidney injury, as well as fever and neurologic symptoms. While some of this patient’s symptoms overlap with TTP, the absence of fever and neurologic signs makes this diagnosis unlikely. Additionally, liver enzymes are minimally elevated in TTP.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the office due to difficulty conceiving. Menarche was at age 11 years, and her menstrual cycle has been irregular since then. She has been sexually active with her male partner for the past 3 years and has never used any form of contraception. The patient has gained 10kg (22 lbs) weight over the last year and has been unable to lose weight despite changes in her diet. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Her BMI is 32 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Physical examination shows scant thick hair along the jawline and hyperpigmented, velvety plaques under her axilla. Pelvic examination reveals normal external genitalia and a mobile and nontender uterus with no adnexal masses. TSH, LH and prolactin levels are within normal limits. Considering the most likely diagnosis, which of the following is the best approach to manage this patient’s infertility?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with infertility, obesity and irregular menses, together with examination findings of hirsutism (hair growth on the chin) and acanthosis nigricans (hyperpigmented, velvety plaque under her axilla) is typical of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Ultrasound should be performed to confirm the diagnosis as per Rotterdam criteria. Clomiphene citrate is the most appropriate option for ovulation induction in this patient.


Management options for PCOS in general include:

  •  Weight loss through diet and/or exercise 
  •  Metformin to increases insulin sensitivity 
  •  Spironolactone to treat hirsutism, but since it is teratogenic, some form of contraception is required. 
  •  Oral contraceptives to regulate the menstrual cycle 
  •  Clomiphene citrate or letrozole to induce ovulation 


Option Analysis

❌ Spironolactone:
Incorrect: Sprinolcatone is an antiandrogen that can be used to treat hirsutism in patients with polycystic ovarian syndrome. It is a teratogenic drug and should be avoided in women who desire pregnancy. It does not help in ovulation induction.
❌ Ovarian drilling:
Incorrect: Laparoscopic ovarian drilling involves puncturing a cystic ovary, thereby reducing ovarian secretion of androgens and proteins. The end-result is an increase in LH and FSH secretion, which leads to ovulation. It is the second-line option for ovulation induction in patients who fail to respond to clomiphene citrate or letrozole.
✅ Clomiphene citrate:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Bariatric surgery:
Incorrect: Although bariatric surgery can help with the restoration of ovulatory cycles, and improvements in insulin resistance, hyperandrogenemia, and hirsutism, it is not recommended in this patient with BMI <40 kg/m2.
❌ Progestin-releasing intrauterine device:
Incorrect: Progestin-releasing intrauterine device is an alternative treatment for endometrial protection in patients who choose not to or cannot take combined oral contraceptives. However, it does not help with ovulation induction.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 1, comes to the physician’s office due to fever and left breast pain for the past two days. The patient is 2 weeks postpartum after an uncomplicated pregnancy and vaginal delivery. She had been breastfeeding every 2-3 hours until 2 days ago, when she noticed sharp pain and redness on the left breast. Since then, she has stopped breastfeeding because of worsening pain, and she recently developed a fever and chills. She has no allergies, and her only medication is multivitamins. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. On physical examination, there is a swollen, firm, red, and tender area on the left breast without fluctuation. Tender, swollen lymph nodes are noted in the left axilla. The right breast appears normal, and the rest of the physical examination is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the doctor?

choices.text: Your condition is due to an underlying malignancy; chemotherapy is indicated; stop breastfeeding
Your condition is due to an infectious cause; antibiotics are required; continue breastfeeding
Your condition is due to a milk cyst; needle aspiration is indicated; stop breastfeeding
Your condition is due to an infectious cause and pus accumulation; incision and drainage plus antibiotics are indicated; stop breastfeeding
Your condition is due to a plugged duct; warm compresses are indicated; continue breastfeeding

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise) as well as breast erythema and pain without fluctuance, a presentation consistent with lactational mastitis. The tender axillary lymph nodes are most likely due to reactive lymphadenopathy from the infection.  

Lactational mastitis is a common condition, affecting up to 10% of breastfeeding women. The risk is especially high during the first 3 months. The pathogenesis of lactational mastitis is complex and may occur in the settings of poor drainage, infrequent feeding, engorgement, nipple excoriation or cracking, rapid weaning or illness. The pathogenesis involves nipple trauma, which results in poor milk drainage and breast engorgement, which leads to compression of additional milk ducts, further engorgement, and milk stasis. Bacteria are subsequently able to penetrate the skin and proliferate within the stagnant milk. Staphylococcus aureus is the most common causative organism, which can colonize the neonate’s nasopharynx, leading to infection within the breast during feeding. The diagnosis of mastitis is based upon the clinical manifestations, and laboratory tests are generally not required; however, culture can assist in guiding the antibiotics regimen.  

Initial management of non-severe cases is aimed to reduce pain and swelling (e.g., NSAIDs, cold compresses) and continuation of breastfeeding -- since lactostasis always precedes mastitis, active expression of breast milk to get rid of milk stagnation is of utmost importance. Management of infective lactational mastitis (persistent symptoms beyond 12 hours plus fever) involves antibiotic therapy with activity against S. aureus (nafcillin, oxacillin) and continuation of breastfeeding.  

Option Analysis

❌ Your condition is due to an underlying malignancy; chemotherapy is indicated; stop breastfeeding:
Incorrect: Inflammatory breast cancer is an aggressive type of breast cancer that can occur in women at any age. The typical presentation is a painful, warm, swollen breast with erythematous skin resembling orange peel (peau d’orange). This patient has systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, chills) and only an area of erythema, rather than peau d’orange, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.   
✅ Your condition is due to an infectious cause; antibiotics are required; continue breastfeeding:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Your condition is due to a milk cyst; needle aspiration is indicated; stop breastfeeding:
Incorrect: Galactoceles are cysts that result from a blocked milk duct. They typically present as cystic masses (can be very large) during pregnancy, lactation, or after weaning. Unless there is a superimposed infection, they are usually painless (unlike this patient). If the symptoms are bothersome, needle aspiration or surgical excision can be done. Breastfeeding should be continued. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Your condition is due to an infectious cause and pus accumulation; incision and drainage plus antibiotics are indicated; stop breastfeeding  :
Incorrect: Mastitis can progress to form an abscess if not treated promptly. Breast abscess presents as a tender fluctuant area, along with systemic symptoms. Ultrasound is useful in confirming the diagnosis and guiding drainage. Treatment includes needle aspiration or surgical drainage and antibiotic therapy. Breastfeeding should be continued. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Your condition is due to a plugged duct; warm compresses are indicated; continue breastfeeding:
Incorrect: A plugged duct is an area of localized milk stasis within the milk ducts that leads to distention of the mammary tissue. Patients typically present with a tender and painful palpable lump without systemic findings, such as fever and chills. Continuation of breastfeeding with optimization of feeding technique as well as warm compresses are indicated. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to involuntary loss of urine and chronic constipation. The leakage of urine occurs in coughing, sneezing, or lifting heavy weights. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. The patient has had two forceps-assisted vaginal deliveries. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 105/75 mmHg. Pelvic examination reveals dribbling of urine when asked to cough and a mass at the vaginal opening. Post void residual urine is 40ml. Urinalysis is negative for leukocyte esterase or nitrites. She undergoes a paravaginal defect repair. During the procedure, a nerve passing through the obturator foramen is injured. The patient is most likely to develop sensory loss over which of the following areas?
questions.solution:
This postmenopausal patient has stress urinary incontinence, constipation, and a mass per vaginum. She most likely has pelvic organ prolapse (POP) complicated by stress urinary incontinence. POP management involves pelvic floor exercises, mid-urethral sling placements, or surgery to repair the pervaginal defect.    

The obturator nerve is formed from the second, third, and fourth lumbar roots. It courses through the pelvis, posterior to the psoas major muscle, and the sacrum until it enters the obturator canal within the obturator foramen. In the thigh, it divides into anterior and posterior divisions. Both divisions supply motor innervation to the adductor muscles of the thigh. The anterior division carries sensory input from the hip joint and the medial thigh, while the posterior division carries input from the knee joint.    

The obturator nerve can be injured during surgeries that involve dissection in the obturator fossa. These include pelvic resection surgeries for endometriosis, pelvic lymph node dissection in gynecological malignancies, pervaginal defect repairs, and retropubic sling placements for pelvic organ prolapse. It can also be compressed by pelvic tumors or injured by pelvic trauma. A diagnosis of obturator neuropathy is primarily clinical. Symptoms include sensory loss over the medial aspect of the thigh and weakness in leg adduction.   

Option Analysis

✅ Medial thigh :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anterior thigh :
Incorrect: The cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve supplies the anterior thigh. It exits the pelvis and passes along the femoral canal. It does not traverse through the obturator canal.   
❌ Medial leg :
Incorrect: The medial leg is innervated by the cutaneous branches of the saphenous nerve, a branch of the femoral nerve. It does not originate in the pelvis and is not likely to be damaged in this patient.   
❌ Medial foot :
Incorrect: The superficial peroneal nerve innervates the medial aspect of the foot. It is the branch of the common peroneal nerve and is unlikely to be injured in pelvic surgeries.   
❌ Posterior perineum :
Incorrect: The pudendal nerve provides sensory innervation to the perineum and the lower one-third of the vagina. It passes along the ischial spine and through the pudendal canal. It does not course through the obturator foramen.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency room with nausea, vomiting, and severe abdominal pain. The pain began 6 hours ago and has become more severe over the last 2 hours. Past medical history includes seasonal depression and placement of a progestin-releasing IUD a month ago. Her last menstrual period was two weeks ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 90/75 mmHg. Abdominal examination reveals tenderness in the left lower quadrant. Bimanual examination reveals a tender, palpable left adnexal mass and visible IUD strings at the vaginal orifice. The urine pregnancy test is negative. The total leukocyte count is 8000/mm3. A transabdominal ultrasound reveals a hyperechoic adnexal mass with the decreased arterial flow. An explorative laparotomy is performed. The infundibulopelvic ligament is ligated during the procedure, and the pathological specimen is removed.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presented with acute onset of abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and a tender adnexal mass with the decreased arterial flow. These findings are suggestive of ovarian torsion, which necessitates urgent intervention.    

Ovarian torsion is a common gynecological emergency among women of reproductive age, although it can occur in any age group. Clinical symptoms include sudden onset abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting with or without an adnexal mass. The most important risk factor for adnexal torsion is the presence of ovarian cysts or tumors, particularly those greater than 5 cm in size. Ovarian tumors are more common amongst women of reproductive age as most benign tumors (functional cyst, corpus luteum cysts) are associated with hormonal changes and ovulation induction therapy. Pathogenesis of ovarian torsion involves rotation of the ovary around the axis of its ligamentous attachment, the infundibulopelvic ligament. The presence of a large ovarian mass increases the likelihood of torsion.    

The infundibulopelvic ligament/suspensory ligament of the ovary attaches the superior pole of the ovary to the pelvic sidewall and contains the ovarian vessels. Rotation around its axis can impair the blood supply to the ovaries, which are detected as decreased blood flow on a doppler USG. Compression of the blood vessels impairs lymphatic and venous drainage and impedes arterial supply. Ovarian edema can progressively worsen and result in ischemia, local hemorrhage, and infarction complications.   

Option Analysis

✅ Ovarian torsion :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ectopic pregnancy :
Incorrect: An extrauterine pregnancy is unlikely to cause abdominal pain as her last menstrual period was two weeks ago, and she has a negative pregnancy test.   
❌ Tubo-Ovarian abscess :
Incorrect: A tubo-ovarian abscess would cause fever and leukocytosis, neither of which are present in this patient. In addition, an abscess usually appears as an anechoic or hypoechoic fluid collection on ultrasound.   
❌ Uterine perforation :
Incorrect: Placement of IUDs can result in complications such as uterine perforation. It may present with severe, acute onset abdominal pain as seen in this patient. However, it is more likely to occur at the time of placement or immediately after and is unlikely in this case.   
❌ Endometriosis :
Incorrect: Endometriosis classically presents with chronic pelvic pain, infertility, and dysmenorrhea. This patient's acute onset of symptoms makes this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the obstetrician for evaluation of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. Over the past two weeks, the patient has noticed a fishy vaginal odor. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 110/79 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. Upon pelvic examination, gray-white discharge is apparent. She has never had a sexually transmitted infection but has recently been sexually active with a new partner. An amine whiff test is performed, which enhances the odor. The patient is started on a medication for the treatment of her symptoms. Three days later, while at a restaurant, she develops flushing, hypotension, nausea, and vomiting after consuming a glass of wine. Which of the following best characterizes the mechanism causing this reaction?
questions.solution:
This patient has a fishy-smelling vaginal odor and gray discharge. These findings are suggestive of bacterial vaginosis caused by Gardnerella vaginalis. She was most likely prescribed metronidazole, which causes a disulfiram-like reaction after consuming alcohol since the drug leads to acetaldehyde accumulation within the body.

Metronidazole is an antibiotic and antiprotozoal medication. It functions by generating toxic metabolites that damage pathogenic DNA. However, some of these metabolites inhibit the hepatic enzyme aldehyde dehydrogenase. Aldehyde dehydrogenase plays a vital role in ethanol metabolism by breaking down acetaldehyde into acetate. As a result, when patients consume alcohol while taking metronidazole, acetaldehyde builds up and produces symptoms of a disulfiram-like reaction (e.g., abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, flushing, headache).
   

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of alcohol dehydrogenase:
Incorrect: This patient most likely has bacterial vaginosis caused by Gardnerella vaginalis, often treated using metronidazole. Although metronidazole can cause a disulfiram-like reaction if the patient consumes alcohol while taking the drug, it does not inhibit the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase.  
❌ Rapid accumulation of ethanol:
Incorrect: This patient was most likely started on metronidazole to treat bacterial vaginosis caused by Gardnerella vaginalis. Metronidazole does not directly cause excessive ethanol accumulation.  
❌ Accumulation of acetate:
Incorrect: Acetate is formed via the catalysis of acetaldehyde by the enzyme acetaldehyde dehydrogenase. Metronidazole inhibits this enzyme and causes the accumulation of acetaldehyde, not acetate.  
✅ Accumulation of acetaldehyde:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Deficiency of adequate reducing agents:
Incorrect: This patient was most likely started on metronidazole to treat bacterial vaginosis caused by Gardenrelalla vaginalis. Metronidazole does not deplete reducing agents required for the metabolism of alcohol.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist for a follow-up appointment. She was diagnosed with uterine fibroids eight months ago and prescribed several medications to treat associated menorrhagia. However, these medications have been largely ineffective. The patient continues to experience several days of painful and heavy bleeding every menstrual cycle. Past medical history is notable for irritable bowel syndrome, asthma, and migraine attacks with aura. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 112/67 mmHg, and pulse is 62/min. Pelvic examination reveals an enlarged, asymmetric uterus. No cervical motion tenderness is elicited. After learning about the different treatment options, the patient decides to pursue surgical resection of the uterine fibroids. Which of the following treatments would be most effective in preoperatively reducing the size of her fibroids?
questions.solution:
This patient is scheduled for a myomectomy and was started on a medication preoperatively to help to reduce the size of her uterine fibroids. Among the answer choices, continuous leuprolide therapy would be most effective in achieving this effect.

Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist that can be administered in either a continuous or pulsatile pattern. When given in a constant pattern, the medication can cause down regulation of GnRH receptors in the pituitary. These changes lead to decreased secretion of FSH, LH, and sex hormones (e.g., testosterone and estrogen). As a result, continuous administration can help treat endometriosis, uterine fibroids, prostate cancer, and precocious puberty. Leuprolide is typically given preoperatively for 3-months to reduce the size of uterine fibroids before surgical resection. Furthermore, continuous leuprolide can be used in vitro fertilization techniques to prevent premature ovulation.

On the other hand, pulsatile therapy of leuprolide mimics the physiological secretion of GnRH from the hypothalamus. In other words, the drug binds and activates GnRH receptors, thereby increasing the downstream synthesis of LH, FSH, and sex hormones. This administration method was historically used to induce ovulation and treat infertility but is rarely used today due to the availability of better alternatives (e.g. clomiphene).  

Option Analysis

❌ Estrogen-progesterone combined oral contraceptive therapy:
Incorrect: Combined oral contraceptives can be used to treat menorrhagia secondary to uterine fibroids. This patient's combined oral contraceptives are contraindicated given her history of migraine with auras. Furthermore, combined oral contraceptives are mainly ineffective in reducing the size of fibroids.  
✅ Continuous leuprolide therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tranexamic acid therapy:
Incorrect: Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic that can be used to treat heavy menstrual bleeding secondary to uterine fibroids. TXA does not alter uterine fibroid size and therefore would have unlikely been prescribed to this patient.  
❌ Tamoxifen therapy:
Incorrect: Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator. This medication is an estrogen receptor antagonist in the breast but serves as an agonist in the bones, uterus, and endometrium. As a result, this medication is not typically used to reduce the size of uterine fibroids preoperatively.  
❌ Pulsatile nafarelin therapy:
Incorrect: Nafarelin is a GnRH agonist, a class of medications that can treat conditions including endometriosis, uterine fibroids, and prostate cancer. If a GnRH agonist is given in a continuous pattern, it downregulates GnRH receptors in the pituitary gland, reducing FSH, LH, and sex hormone secretion. These changes can cause fibroids to shrink. In contrast, a GnRH agonist given in a pulsatile pattern increases FSH and LH secretion, leading to fibroid enlargement.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0010, comes to her obstetrician for follow-up following spontaneous abortion. The patient developed vaginal bleeding with passage of products of conception at 16 weeks gestation two months ago. She underwent treatment with misoprostol, and her vaginal bleeding stopped after a few days. The patient feels well except for an occasional cough. She states she is currently in her menstrual cycle. Past medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Temperature is 37.1 °C (98.8°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mmHg. Dry rales are heard diffusely throughout the bilateral lungs. Beta human chorionic gonadotropin levels are 45,000 mIU/ml. The chest x-ray is shown below. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action for the most appropriate medication to manage this patient’s condition?
 

Reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Creation of free radicals that unwind DNA
Incorporation of false pyrimidine analogs into DNA
Formation of cross-links between strands of DNA

questions.solution:
The patient has an elevated chorionic gonadotropin level, vaginal bleeding, cough, and evidence of pulmonary metastases (cannonballs on chest x-ray). Together, these findings are suggestive of systemic choriocarcinoma following spontaneous abortion. The first-line treatment for gestationally derived choriocarcinoma is methotrexate.

Dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) normally converts dihydrofolate (DHF) to tetrahydrofolate (THF), which provides methyl groups necessary for the synthesis of dTMP from dUMP and for subsequent purine synthesis. Methotrexate, a folic acid analog, has a higher affinity for DHFR than DHF  and binds to irreversibly inhibits this enzyme. THF is also involved in the synthesis of purines and amino acids. The result is a net decrease in the synthesis of DNA, RNA, and proteins resulting in inhibition of cell division.

Methotrexate can treat leukemia, especially acute lymphoblastic leukemia, primary CNS lymphoma and non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, solid tumors like breast cancer, and head, neck, and bladder cancer. It is the medication of choice for early unruptured ectopic pregnancy and choriocarcinoma, a germ cell tumor. Other indications for its use include rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis, inflammatory bowel disease, systemic lupus erythematosus, and dermatomyositis.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of beta-tubulin polymerization  :
Incorrect: Vincristine inhibits beta-tubulin polymerization, which inhibits the formation of the essential microtubules for cell division. It is indicated in the management of solid tumors, leukemias, Hodgkin, and non-Hodgkin lymphomas.  
❌ Creation of free radicals that unwind DNA  :
Incorrect: The creation of free radicals that cause breaks in DNA is the mechanism by which anthracyclines (e.g., doxorubicin, daunorubicin) treat solid tumors, leukemias, and lymphomas, but not choriocarcinomas.  
✅ Inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Incorporation of false pyrimidine analogs into DNA  :
Incorrect: Incorporation of false pyrimidine analogs into DNA is the mechanism of several widely used antineoplastic agents, such as 5-fluorouracil. It is not the first-line treatment option for choriocarcinoma.  
❌ Formation of cross-links between strands of DNA  :
Incorrect: Formation of cross-links between strands of DNA and subsequent inhibition of DNA replication is the mechanism of action of several alkylating agents (e.g., busulfan, cyclophosphamide) and platinum-based chemotherapeutic agents (e.g., cisplatin, carboplatin). These agents are indicated in the treatment of solid tumors, leukemias, and lymphomas but are not the first-line treatment option for choriocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, comes to the clinic at five weeks gestation for her initial prenatal visit. The patient is feeling well and has no acute complaints. Past medical history is notable for hypothyroidism secondary to Hashimoto thyroiditis, well-managed with levothyroxine. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 115/73 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. Physical examination yields no concerning findings. The most recent TSH is 2.5 µU/mL. Which of the following is the most appropriate approach to managing the patient’s hypothyroidism as her pregnancy progresses?
questions.solution:
This patient has hypothyroidism that is being treated with levothyroxine, which is a synthetic form of T4. Although the patient is asymptomatic and her TSH is within normal limits, thyroid hormone requirements increase throughout pregnancy. To meet these increased demands, patients will need to increase their levothyroxine dose by 30-50%.

These changes occur since during pregnancy. Increased estrogen levels lead to increased synthesis of thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG). Increased TBG means more bound (biologically inactive) T4 and less free (biologically active) T4.

Thyroid function tests should be repeated regularly throughout pregnancy to guide additional dosage adjustments. Close follow-up is required since overt hypothyroidism during pregnancy is associated with adverse outcomes, including an increased rate of first-trimester spontaneous abortion, preeclampsia, congenital anomalies, and congenital hypothyroidism.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Decrease her levothyroxine dose:
Incorrect: Thyroid hormone requirements increase during pregnancy. Pregnancy increases plasma thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG) concentrations, decreasing the amount of free (biologically active) T4. As a result, patients will require a higher dose of levothyroxine during pregnancy.  
❌ Discontinue levothyroxine and begin liotrix:
Incorrect: Liotrix consists of levothyroxine (synthetic T4) and liothyronine (synthetic T3). Although liotrix is not associated with adverse maternal or fetal outcomes, the medication also does not provide any additional benefit over levothyroxine.  
❌ Discontinue levothyroxine until after delivery:
Incorrect: Discontinuing levothyroxine would cause uncontrolled maternal hypothyroidism, which would result in adverse fetal and maternal outcomes. Medication should maintain normal maternal thyroid function before conception and throughout pregnancy. Furthermore, patients diagnosed with hypothyroidism before conception will generally require a higher dose of levothyroxine during pregnancy.  
✅ Increase her levothyroxine dose:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Maintain levothyroxine dose:
Incorrect: Thyroid hormone requirements increase during pregnancy. Pregnancy increases plasma thyroxine-binding globulin concentrations, decreasing the amount of free (biologically active) T4. Thus, this patient will require a higher dose of levothyroxine.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is brought by ambulance to the emergency department for evaluation of altered mental status and abdominal and pelvic pain. The patient’s mother arrived at the patient’s house and found her in pain and confused. The patient was recently diagnosed with a sexually transmitted infection and started on oral antibiotics. She has no significant past medical history and takes no daily medications. Temperature is 39°C (102°F), blood pressure is 86/50 mmHg, pulse is 122/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient appears ill and is confused. Physical examination reveals lower abdominal tenderness with guarding and rebound. Pelvic examination demonstrates bilateral adnexal tenderness to palpation, cervical motion tenderness, and mucopurulent cervical discharge. White blood cell count shows leukocytosis.  ESR and CRP are elevated. The patient is started on empiric antibiotics and intravenous fluids. Labs are ordered and pending. Urine HCG is negative for pregnancy. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis
MRI of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient who was recently treated for a sexually transmitted infection is presenting with evidence of sepsis and peritonitis. These findings likely represent a tubo-ovarian abscess (TOA) secondary to PID. A ruptured TOA can be life-threatening, and an emergent gynecology consult should be called for potential exploratory surgery.

Pelvic inflammatory disease, or PID, refers to an inflammatory condition that affects the uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries, and peritoneum. PID is often caused by infection with sexually transmitted organisms such as gonorrhea and chlamydia. However, it may also be caused by microorganisms normally found in the vaginal flora.

The acute management of an unstable patient with PID includes stabilizing the airway, breathing, and circulation. All patients with suspected PID should have an HCG pregnancy test. Unstable patients should have a focused history and physical examination performed, assessing for a history of PID or sexually transmitted infections and associated risk factors (e.g. multiple partners). Patients should have a pelvic examination to assess for the presence of cervical motion, uterine, and adnexal tenderness. Signs of cervicitis and discharge may also be seen. Patients should receive empiric antibiotics. Bloodwork including blood cultures, lactate level, NAAT testing, cbc and cmp should be obtained. A gynecologic surgery consultation should be called for possible exploratory surgery.  

Option Analysis

✅ Gynecological consultation for exploratory surgery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transvaginal ultrasonography:
Incorrect: Transvaginal ultrasonography is indicated in stable patients with evidence of PID to rule out a tubo-ovarian abscess and decide on appropriate discharge planning. This patient is unstable with sepsis and findings consistent with PID, therefore she requires prompt gynecologic consultation.  
❌ CT of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: This patient is unstable with clinical findings consistent with PID and sepsis and requires prompt gynecologic consultation.  
❌ General surgery consultation:
Incorrect: This patient's presentation is consistent with PID and sepsis which may be caused by tubo-ovarian abscess. Gynecologic surgery should be consulted over general surgery.  
❌ MRI of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: This patient is unstable with a possible tubo-ovarian abscess and requires prompt gynecologic surgery consultation.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of pelvic pain for 2 days. She also has nausea and vomiting. The patient has a past medical history of recurrent pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), and she is sexually active with multiple partners. She states that her symptoms feel similar to prior episodes of PID. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 126/76 mmHg, pulse is 62/min, respiratory rate is 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Abdominal exam is significant for lower abdominal tenderness without rebound or guarding. Pelvic examination demonstrates cervical motion tenderness and mucopurulent cervical discharge. Wet mount and nucleic amplification testing for gonorrhea and chlamydia are pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Call gynecological consultation for surgical intervention
Order CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs, symptoms, and physical exam findings consistent with pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). The most appropriate next step in management is to determine her pregnancy status with a urine or serum beta HCG. Beta HCG should be obtained to rule out ectopic pregnancy and complications from an intrauterine pregnancy. PID can occur in early pregnancy and requires hospitalization and intravenous antibiotics.

Patients with a clinical diagnosis of PID should have laboratory evaluations including HCG, microscopy of the vaginal discharge, CBC, chemistries, ESR, CRP, and NAAT for gonorrhea and chlamydia. Although most cases of PID are associated with gonorrhea and chlamydia, other organisms such as Trichomonas vaginalis, bacterial vaginosis, Mycoplasma genitalium, cytomegalovirus, and bacteria that comprise the normal vaginal flora can also cause PID.

Option Analysis

✅ Send urine beta HCG:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perform transvaginal ultrasonography:
Incorrect: Pregnancy testing should be done first to rule out ectopic pregnancy or complications of an intrauterine pregnancy.  
❌ Call gynecological consultation for surgical intervention:
Incorrect: Surgical intervention is reserved for cases of PID and sepsis where tubo-ovarian abscess is suspected.  
❌ Administer ampicillin and gentamicin:
Incorrect: Ampicillin and gentamicin are used to treat complicated PID in hospitalized patients. Patients with simple uncomplicated PID, as seen in this patient, can be treated in the outpatient setting with doxycycline and metronidazole after a dose of ceftriaxone.  
❌ Order CT of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: CT of the abdomen and pelvis is not necessary to diagnose PID.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of pelvic pain. She has also had vaginal discharge and nausea and vomiting for the past 3 days. The patient has multiple sexual partners and uses barrier protection inconsistently. Temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 130/60 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Pelvic examination demonstrates cervical motion tenderness, bilateral adnexal tenderness, and a mucopurulent cervical discharge. Labs including wet mount and nucleic amplification testing for gonorrhea and chlamydia are pending. Urine beta HCG is negative. Transvaginal ultrasonography shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Admit to the hospital for intravenous antibiotics
Administer IM ceftriaxone and discharge on oral doxycycline and metronidazole
CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) and is febrile, nauseous, and vomiting. Therefore she is considered to have severe disease and should be admitted to the hospital and started on intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Patients with severe or complicated PID should be hospitalized and started on broad-spectrum IV antibiotics and IV fluids. This includes patients with severe illness (fever > 38.5°C [101°F], nausea and vomiting), patients with PID complicated by a pelvic abscess (including TOA) seen on transvaginal ultrasound, pregnant patients, and patients who have not been able to tolerate oral medications.

Patients with suspected TOA should be admitted and started on broad-spectrum antibiotics.  Transvaginal ultrasound should be performed and gynecologic surgery consultation should be called if TOA is confirmed. Any patients with PID who are unstable or have sepsis should have gynecologic surgery consultation for a possible exploratory laparotomy.

Patients with mild to moderate PID who can tolerate oral intake and have a normal transvaginal ultrasound without TOA can be given IM ceftriaxone and treated as outpatients with doxycycline and metronidazole. They should have follow-up within 72 hours to ensure clinical improvement.  

Option Analysis

✅ Admit to the hospital for intravenous antibiotics:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Discharge on keflex and metronidazole:
Incorrect: Discharge is inappropriate for this patient who has evidence of severe disease with fever, nausea, and vomiting. She should be admitted to the hospital for intravenous antibiotics.  
❌ Gynecologic surgery consultation:
Incorrect: Gynecological consultation is indicated for complicated PID (e.g. tubo-ovarian abscess, peritonitis, sepsis). This patient has a normal transvaginal ultrasound ruling out complicated disease.  
❌ Administer IM ceftriaxone and discharge on oral doxycycline and metronidazole:
Incorrect: This would be appropriate management for a patient with mild to moderate PID without complications. This patient has severe disease with fever, nausea, and vomiting and should be admitted for IV antibiotics.  
❌ CT of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: CT of the abdomen and pelvis is not part of the diagnostic workup or evaluation of PID.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of vaginal discharge and itching for 2 days. The patient is sexually active with one male partner and takes oral contraceptive pills for contraception. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago and was normal. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she takes no other medication. Vital signs are within normal limits. Genital examination reveals vulvar excoriations. Speculum examination reveals thick, white, curd-like vaginal discharge without evidence of a retained foreign body. The cervix appears normal and there is no cervical motion tenderness. A pregnancy test is negative. Potassium hydroxide microscopy reveals pseudohyphae and spores. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with vulvovaginal itching, excoriations, and thick, white, curd-like vaginal discharge along with a normal cervical exam most likely has candidiasis. Potassium hydroxide microscopy reveals pseudohyphae and spores, confirming the diagnosis of vulvovaginal candidiasis.

Vaginal discharge is one of the most common reasons biologically female patients present for gynecologic care. Abnormal vaginal discharge can cause significant discomfort and pain, and can adversely affect daily activities, sexual functioning, and self-image. Patients who present with abnormal vaginal discharge should first be assessed for retained vaginal foreign bodies. Suppose there is no evidence of a foreign body. In that case, the next step is to assess the presence of vaginal inflammation or infection, known as vaginitis, and to determine the cause of vaginitis by direct treatment.

Vulvovaginal candidiasis is the second most common form of vaginitis after bacterial vaginosis. Infection with yeast leads to inflammation of the vagina and vulva. The most common cause is infection with Candida albicans. Patients typically report thick, white vaginal discharge and vaginal itching. They may also report vulvar itching, pain, redness, or swelling. The physical exam will typically reveal a thick, white, curd-like vaginal discharge. The vulva may appear erythematous and edematous, and there may be excoriations from scratching and fissures may be present. Potassium hydroxide (KOH) microscopy will demonstrate pseudohyphae and spores, confirming the diagnosis. The vaginal pH will typically be between 3.5 to 4.5. Candida PCR or culture can also be used to confirm the diagnosis, but these tests typically take longer for the results to come back.  

Option Analysis

✅ Vulvovaginal candidiasis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Physiologic discharge:
Incorrect: Patients with physiologic discharge have discharge without odor and without vaginal and vulvar irritation. Physical examination typically reveals a white or clear vaginal discharge that is viscous and not white and curd-like as seen with candidiasis. Saline microscopy in patients with physiologic discharge would show mature squamous cells and abundant lactobacilli, and potassium hydroxide microscopy would be negative for pseudohyphae and spores.  
❌ Bacterial vaginosis:
Incorrect: Patients with bacterial vaginosis typically report a thin watery discharge with a “fishy” odor, and the physical exam would show a thin gray-white vaginal discharge with clue cells seen on microscopy. Potassium hydroxide microscopy would be negative for pseudohyphae and spores.  
❌ Vaginal trichomoniasis:
Incorrect: Symptomatic patients with trichomoniasis typically report vaginal discharge with odor, vulvar itching, irritation, and dysuria. Physical examination may reveal a yellow, frothy, vaginal discharge as well as vaginal erythema or cervical erythema with petechiae (strawberry cervix). Saline microscopy shows motile trichomonads and many polymorphonucleocytes. Potassium hydroxide microscopy would be negative for pseudohyphae and spores.  
❌ Chlamydia infection:
Incorrect: Symptomatic patients with chlamydia may report thick vaginal discharge, dysuria, non-menstrual or post-coital spotting, and possibly pelvic pain. They may have a history of recent unprotected sexual activity with a new partner. The physical exam can show mucopurulent cervical discharge, a friable cervix, and cervical motion tenderness. Potassium hydroxide microscopy would be negative for pseudohyphae and spores.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of vaginal discharge and itching. The patient is sexually active with biological males, does not use condoms, and her last sexual encounter was one week ago. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She has no significant past medical history, and she does not take any medication. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows vulvar erythema and a scant amount of thin yellow-green frothy vaginal discharge. The cervix appears erythematous with petechiae. There is no cervical motion tenderness. A pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient with thin yellow-green frothy vaginal discharge, vaginal itching, and findings of vulvar erythema and cervical erythema with petechiae most likely has vaginal trichomoniasis. The most appropriate next step is to perform saline microscopy. If saline microscopy shows motile trichomonads, then trichomonas vaginalis can be diagnosed.

Vaginal trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection that is caused by the protozoan parasite, trichomonas vaginalis. Symptomatic patients with trichomoniasis typically report vaginal discharge with an odor that is accompanied by vulvar itching, irritation, and/or dysuria. The physical exam may reveal a yellow, frothy, vaginal discharge as well as vaginal erythema or cervical erythema with petechiae, known as a strawberry cervix. The diagnosis can be made with saline microscopy that shows motile trichomonads and many polymorphonucleocytes. The pH is typically greater than 4.5 and the “whiff” test is typically positive. If no motile trichomonads are seen, then nucleic acid amplification (NAAT) for T. vaginalis can be performed to confirm the diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Saline microscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Candida PCR test:
Incorrect: Patients with vaginal candidiasis typically present with thick, white, curd-like vaginal discharge. The initial test of choice, in offices with appropriate equipment, is potassium hydroxide wet mount. For this patient with a thin yellow-green frothy vaginal discharge and findings of vulvar erythema and a strawberry cervix, vaginal trichomoniasis is most likely. Saline microscopy should be performed to look for motile trichomonads.  
❌ Clinical observation:
Incorrect: Clinical observation would be appropriate if the vaginal discharge appears to be physiologic and likely related to ovulation or pregnancy. Given this patient’s clinical findings of vulvar erythema, itching, odorous discharge, and strawberry cervix, she most likely has vaginal trichomoniasis and saline microscopy should be performed to look for motile trichomonads.  
❌ Transvaginal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Transvaginal ultrasound is useful to evaluate vaginal discharge in the setting of pelvic pain or when pelvic inflammatory disease is suspected. This patient does not have signs or findings consistent with PID. Given this patient’s clinical findings of vulvar erythema, itching, odorous discharge, and strawberry cervix, she most likely has vaginal trichomoniasis and saline microscopy should be performed to look for motile trichomonads.  
❌ Oral fluconazole:
Incorrect: Oral fluconazole can be used to treat vulvovaginal candidiasis. However, given this patient’s clinical findings of vulvar erythema, itching, odorous discharge, and strawberry cervix, she most likely has vaginal trichomoniasis and saline microscopy should be performed to look for motile trichomonads.

questions.text: A 24-year-old G1P0 woman at 29 weeks gestation presents to the primary care office for evaluation of three days of malodorous vaginal discharge and vaginal itching. She reports an episode of unprotected intercourse with a new biologically male partner two weeks prior. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg. Chaperoned vaginal examination reveals a green, frothy vaginal discharge. There is no cervical motion tenderness or suprapubic pain. The vaginal pH is 4.8.  Saline microscopy of the vaginal fluid reveals motile, pear-shaped microorganisms and many polymorphonuclear white blood cells.  Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Wait until after delivery of the infant to initiate treatment

questions.solution:
This patient’s vaginal pruritus and frothy green vaginal discharge that began after an episode of unprotected sexual intercourse with a new partner is concerning for a sexually transmitted infection.  The presence of motile, pear-shaped microorganisms and many polymorphonuclear white blood cells on saline microscopy confirms Trichomonas vaginalis.  All patients with vaginal trichomoniasis should be treated with antibiotics such as metronidazole, and treatment is especially important in pregnant patients given the potential pregnancy complications associated with the infection. Oral metronidazole is used most commonly, with a seven-day treatment course preferred in both pregnant and non-pregnant women.  

Nitroimidazoles are the class of antibiotics used to treat trichomoniasis. The recommendation for men is treatment with a single high dose of metronidazole.  A single dose of oral tinidazole can also be given to both biologically male and female patients but should be avoided in pregnancy.  All sexual partners should be informed of the diagnosis and encouraged to have testing and treatment.  Reinfection rates are high, and patients should be encouraged to return for any recurrence of symptoms as well as to be retested three months after treatment, regardless of symptom status.  

In addition to antibiotic treatment, patients with vaginal trichomonas should be screened for HIV, gonorrhea, chlamydia, and syphilis. Patients should be counseled on lifestyle modifications including avoiding douching and abstaining from intercourse until they, and all sexual partners, are treated and symptom-free.

Option Analysis

✅ Oral metronidazole :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Oral tinidazole:
