Incorrect: Tinidazole is a treatment option for trichomoniasis in non-pregnant patients, however it crosses the placenta and has been shown to have adverse effects in animal studies. Therefore, it is not recommended for use in pregnancy.
❌ Topical clotrimazole :
Incorrect: Clotrimazole is a treatment for vaginal candidiasis, which is a fungal infection. This patient has trichomoniasis and needs treatment with an antibiotic such as metronidazole.
❌ Topical fluconazole:
Incorrect: Fluconazole is a treatment for fungal infections. This patient has trichomoniasis and needs treatment with an antibiotic such as metronidazole. Additionally, fluconazole is not generally recommended in pregnancy.
❌ Wait until after delivery of the infant to initiate treatment:
Incorrect: Trichomoniasis is associated with increased pregnancy complications and pregnant patients should be promptly treated with metronidazole.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman presents to the gynecologist for a well-patient examination. She has no current complaints. She is sexually active with one biologically male partner, and they use condoms sporadically. She has no chronic medical conditions and does not take daily medications. She has received the meningococcal vaccine, two doses of a COVID-19 vaccine, an annual influenza vaccine, and Tdap within the past 10 years. She has not previously received an HPV vaccine. Her family history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 66/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 110/68 mmHg, oxygen saturation is 98% on room air, and BMI is 28. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following interventions is indicated at this time?
questions.solution:
This 18-year-old patient who has not previously had an HPV vaccine should receive the vaccination series at this time. HPV vaccination can begin as early as age nine and is recommended for everyone up to age 26. The vaccine may be offered up until age 45 depending on patient risk factors and preferences. The HPV vaccine is administered as a series of two or three injections depending on patient factors, including age and immunocompetence.  

The recommended components of a well-patient examination are dependent on the age of the patient as well as risk factors the patient may have for various conditions. The patient’s medical history, social history, and family history will determine a significant portion of their risk factors. In addition to basic screening and counseling for all patients, an 18-year-old should be offered the HPV vaccine if not already given and have a discussion regarding birth control methods. Biological females should be counseled on supplementation with folic acid, and counseling (as well as screening, if indicated) for sexually transmitted infections. Hearing and vision testing can also be considered. Anticipatory guidance regarding cervical cancer screening at age 21 can be offered as well as reviewing safety topics, such as drug, tobacco, and alcohol use; distracted driving; skin cancer risk factors; seatbelt use; and relationship safety.



Option Analysis

✅ HPV vaccine:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Cervical cancer screening:
Incorrect: Cervical cancer screening begins at age 21 and continues until age 65. This patient is not old enough to require cervical cancer screening despite being sexually active. 
❌ Screening mammography:
Incorrect: Screening mammography begins at age 40 unless there is a family history of a first-degree relative with breast cancer diagnosed before the age of 50. If so, then screening should begin 10 years prior to that relative’s age at the time of diagnosis. This patient does not have an indication for early screening.
❌ BRCA testing:
Incorrect: BRCA testing is typically done after age 17 when indicated but is dependent on the patient’s risk factors. Indications for BRCA testing include a known family history of BRCA-positive status, a personal or family history of certain types of cancers, or the presence of certain genetic conditions. This patient does not have risk factors that would require BRCA testing. 
❌ Herpes zoster vaccine:
Incorrect: Herpes zoster vaccine is indicated for all adults age 50 and over as well as adults age 19 and over who are immunocompromised. This patient does not meet the age or risk-factor requirements for herpes zoster vaccination.

questions.text: A 38-year-old G3P2 woman at 31 weeks gestation presents to her obstetrician for evaluation of intense pruritus. The patient reports itching primarily over her palms and soles and states that symptoms worsen at night. She has no abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting. The patient has a history of idiopathic pancreatitis but does not take any daily medication. She has not been drinking alcohol since becoming pregnant and has no history of recreational drug use. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 112/60 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates a gravid abdomen consistent with gestational age, without tenderness to palpation. There are excoriations over the palms and soles. Which of the following laboratory findings would be most indicative of the likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with pruritus of the palms and soles in the third trimester of pregnancy, which is concerning for intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP). A defining characteristic of this condition in laboratory analysis is an elevation in total bile acid levels > 10 µmol/L. An elevated total bile acid concentration is seen in over 90% of patients with ICP.  

ICP is a rare pregnancy-specific liver disease characterized by pruritus and elevated serum bile acid levels. Genetic susceptibility and changes in hormone levels (namely estrogen) in pregnancy disrupt the expression of receptors and transport proteins necessary for maintaining normal bile acid homeostasis, resulting in elevated bile acid concentrations. ICP typically presents in the third trimester with itching on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet, without a rash. However, intense pruritus can lead to excoriations due to scratching.  

When suspected, diagnosis can be confirmed via detection of an elevation in total bile acid levels > 10 µmol/L. Supporting findings may include mild elevations in transaminases, bilirubin, and alkaline phosphatase. Other causes of pruritus and transaminitis, if present, should be ruled out. Ideally, total bile acids should be checked in a fasting state, due to small discrepancy in levels between fasting and random blood work. When elevated, patients should have labs repeated, as rising levels of total bile acid are associated with poorer fetal outcomes, which may change management. 

Option Analysis

✅ Total bile acids > 10 µmol/L:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ 2:1 AST/ALT ratio:
Incorrect: A 2:1 AST/ALT ratio is seen in alcohol misuse. This patient's presentation is consistent with ICP and while mild transaminitis can occur in patients with ICP, a 2:1 ratio would not be expected. An elevated total bile acid concentration is seen in most patients with ICP.
❌ Positive antimitochondrial antibodies :
Incorrect: Positive antimitochondrial antibodies are present in patients with primary biliary cholangitis, which is an autoimmune disorder that affects the small and medium intrahepatic bile ducts leading to cholestasis. This patient's clinical presentation is more consistent with intrahepatic cholestasis in pregnancy, where mild transaminitis and elevated total bile acids are typically seen. 
❌ Thrombocytopenia:
Incorrect: Thrombocytopenia and significant transaminitis are seen in patients with HELLP syndrome. Patients with this condition typically have malaise hypertension and abdominal pain, they do not typically have intense pruritus of the palms and soles which is associated with ICP and elevated bile acids.
❌ Elevated alkaline phosphatase:
Incorrect: An elevated alkaline phosphatase level can be seen in patients with ICP; however, it is not specific given the presence of placental alkaline phosphatase. Elevated bile acid concentrations are seen in most patients with ICP.

questions.text: A 32-year-old gravida 2 para 2 woman is evaluated by an obstetrician after delivering a healthy baby 24 hours ago. The delivery was complicated by protraction in the first labor stage and augmented by an infusion bolus of oxytocin. After delivery, she suffered from excessive postpartum bleeding, which was successfully managed with oxytocin infusion and bimanual uterine massage. Which of the following side effects might develop as a result of oxytocin administration?
questions.solution:
This patient was administered oxytocin for labor induction and to treat her postpartum hemorrhage–increasing the risk of developing associated side effects. One known side effect is the development of hyponatremia.

Oxytocin is a peptide hormone produced by the hypothalamus and stored and released in the posterior pituitary. It stimulates uterine contraction by binding to Gq protein-coupled receptors. Once activated, these receptors activate another molecule called phospholipase C. Phospholipase C cleaves phosphatidylinositol 4,5 bisphosphate into diacylglycerol and inositol triphosphate. Finally, inositol triphosphate promotes the opening of calcium channels in the endoplasmic reticulum, enhancing calcium release into the cytoplasm, which mediates the contraction of the smooth muscle.

Exogenous oxytocin administration is indicated for both ante- and postpartum conditions. In the antepartum period, oxytocin is administered to strengthen uterine contractions to induce or facilitate labor. Oxytocin is also administered to treat postpartum hemorrhage as it mediates the contraction of the uterus and subsequent closure of uterine vasculature.

Side effects of oxytocin include vasodilation, which may result in hypotension and tachycardia. In addition, patients may develop water retention and hyponatremia. This occurs secondary to the ability of oxytocin to act on antidiuretic hormone (ADH) in the renal tubules, promoting free water retention. Finally, oxytocin can lead to tachysystole (5 or more contractions in 10 minutes over a 30-minute duration).
 

Option Analysis

✅ Hyponatremia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypernatremia:
Incorrect: When oxytocin is administered excessively or for prolonged periods, it acts similarly to antidiuretic hormone, promoting free water reabsorption and hyponatremia.  
❌ Hypoglycemia:
Incorrect: Hypoglycemia is not a side effect of oxytocin.  
❌ Venous thromboembolism:
Incorrect: Tranexamic acid (TXA) is sometimes used in patients with severe postpartum hemorrhage. TXA is an antifibrinolytic medication that prevents blood clots from breaking down. VTE is not a known side effect of oxytocin administration.  
❌ Bronchoconstriction:
Incorrect: Bronchoconstriction is a known side effect of prostaglandins and prostaglandin analogs (carboprost).

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman at 31 weeks gestation, gravida 1 para 0, is admitted to the delivery unit due to preterm labor. The patient presented with regular uterus contractions and evidence of cervical dilation. Her pregnancy was uneventful, and she has regularly followed up with her prenatal care. The physician starts the patient on indomethacin and betamethasone. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of indomethacin?

choices.text: Inhibits calcium channels in the myometrium
Stimulates Beta-2 adrenergic receptors in the uterus

questions.solution:
This patient presented in preterm labor and was administered indomethacin to delay labor and allow for timely administration of glucocorticoids.

Indomethacin is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that works by inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzymes (COX), which are responsible for the synthesis of prostaglandins. Prostaglandins are necessary for uterine contraction.

Indomethacin can be used as a tocolytic only if the gestational age is less than 32 weeks. After 32 weeks, prostaglandins are contraindicated, as they may lead to premature closure of the ductus arteriosus. In addition, indomethacin inhibits the synthesis of prostaglandins in other organs like the stomach, increasing the risk of gastritis and gastric bleeding. Indomethacin can also induce placental dysfunction (due to vasoconstriction).
 

Option Analysis

✅ Inhibits the synthesis of prostaglandins:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blocks oxytocin receptors:
Incorrect: Indomethacin is a cyclooxygenase inhibitor that blocks the synthesis of prostaglandins. It does not affect oxytocin receptors.  
❌ Increase the prostaglandin synthesis:
Incorrect: Indomethacin is a cyclooxygenase inhibitor resulting in decreased prostaglandins synthesis.  
❌ Inhibits calcium channels in the myometrium:
Incorrect: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker that inhibits calcium channels in the myometrium, resulting in decreased intracellular calcium and, therefore, inhibition of the uterine contractions.  
❌ Stimulates Beta-2 adrenergic receptors in the uterus:
Incorrect: Terbutaline is another tocolytic that stimulates Beta-2 adrenergic receptors in the uterus. Indomethacin does not exert any effects on this receptor.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the primary care clinic for preconception counseling. She wants to become pregnant within the next year and inquires about the steps she should take to ensure a healthy pregnancy. She has no significant medical or surgical history. She is taking a prenatal vitamin. She has not been pregnant previously and has not tried to conceive in the past. She has no history of STIs and is in a monogamous relationship with her partner. She does not drink alcohol or use recreational substances. She has no pets in the house. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is within normal limits. Which of the following should be performed at this visit?
questions.solution:
Screening for potential risk factors that could affect pregnancy in this patient who has no current medical conditions should include asking about intimate partner violence.

Preconception care focuses on enhancing health, managing changeable risk factors, and offering educational guidance before pregnancy. Its primary aim is to maximize a patient's health for a healthy pregnancy. Asking the patient, "Are you planning to get pregnant in the next year?" can initiate preconception counseling if they respond affirmatively, or lead to a conversation about contraception if they do not. This counseling can occur at a designated appointment or during any interaction with a patient considering pregnancy.

In preconception counseling, comprehensive history and physical examination are essential to address potential risks affecting pregnancy and maternal health. Preconception care includes reviewing the patient’s history for major medical conditions (e.g., thyroid disorders, diabetes mellitus); and screening for substance use, environmental and occupational exposures, risks for infectious diseases, and intimate partner violence.

Physical assessment, tailored to identified risks, typically covers systematic evaluations, focusing on the thyroid, breasts, and pelvic organs. Laboratory testing may include blood tests for rubella and varicella immunity, testing for STIs, and obtaining the status of general health conditions. Genetic carrier screening is considered based on familial or ethnic predispositions. Emphasizing the importance of folic acid supplementation and building a supportive patient-provider relationship is integral to ensuring a healthy pregnancy.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, you can call the U.S. National Domestic Violence Hotline at 1-800-799-SAFE (7233) or text START to 88788 to be connected with a trained staff member for free and confidential support. You can also go to thehotline.org/get/help to chat live with an assistance provider. In Canada, you can visit sheltersafe.ca or call Hope For Wellness 24/7 at 1-855-242-3310 for safety and support services. Additional international support can be found at www.domesticshelters.org/resources.  

Option Analysis

❌ Screening for gestational diabetes:
Incorrect: Screening for gestational diabetes in this patient should be conducted during pregnancy, typically between 24 and 28 weeks gestation. It is not a component of preconception care, which targets current health issues and risks that exist before pregnancy.  
❌ Complete blood count:
Incorrect: A complete blood count (CBC) is not specifically targeted or prioritized in preconception care unless there is a specific clinical indication like a history of chronic diseases.  
❌ Thyroid function tests:
Incorrect: Thyroid function screening is appropriate for patients with pregestational type 1 diabetes, a personal or family history of thyroid disease, age greater than 30, obesity, history of pregnancy loss, preterm delivery, or infertility. This patient does not meet the criteria for preconception screening with thyroid function tests.  
✅ Screening for intimate partner violence:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bone density scan:
Incorrect: Bone density scans are used to diagnose or assess the risk of osteoporosis, a condition not directly related to preconception care or immediate pregnancy planning in patients without a history of osteoporosis or risk factors for osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the primary care clinic for an annual well-visit examination. She expresses a desire to become pregnant within the next year and inquires about steps she should take to ensure a healthy pregnancy. She has a past medical history of hypertension that is well-controlled with lisinopril. She has never been pregnant or has had prior issues with infertility. Temperature is 37 ºC (98.6 °F), heart rate is 66/min, blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 14/min. Physical examination is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Continue lisinopril as it is effectively controlling her blood pressure
Continue lisinopril and add oral folic acid supplementation
Discontinue lisinopril only after a positive pregnancy test
Increase lisinopril dosage to prevent hypertension-related complications in pregnancy

questions.solution:
This patient who is planning on becoming pregnant within the next year should be switched from her current ACE inhibitor to a pregnancy-safe antihypertensive like nifedipine. Agents that block the Renin-angiotensin system, such as ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) are contraindicated in pregnancy and should be discontinued before conception. These medications have been associated with neonatal kidney failure and death.

Hypertension management should be addressed prior to conception, due to the increased risk of adverse events to both the mother and the fetus from uncontrolled hypertension and from medications used to control blood pressure. Pregnant women with uncontrolled hypertension throughout their pregnancy are at an increased risk of developing preeclampsia and intrauterine growth restriction.

Treatment of hypertension is initiated at a blood pressure threshold of 140/90 mmHg using the fewest medications at the lowest effective dose to maintain blood pressure below this level. Renin-angiotensin system blocking agents, such as ACE inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs), and direct renin inhibitors, are contraindicated in pregnancy and should be discontinued before conception. Exposure during the second and third trimesters has been associated with neonatal kidney failure and death.

A key component of preconception counseling is to identify use of medications (including over-the-counter and prescription drugs) that are teratogenic, so that they can be changed to safer agents (eg, nifedipine instead of lisinopril). Antihypertensives that are safe to use in the perinatal period include nifedipine, methyldopa, and labetalol.

Patients with long-standing or uncontrolled hypertension who become pregnant should have vision screening, urine protein evaluation, and an electrocardiogram. They should be counseled that they are at an increased risk of developing preeclampsia and intrauterine growth restriction in pregnancy, and they should be started on low-dose aspirin after 12 weeks of gestation to reduce their risk of preeclampsia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Continue lisinopril as it is effectively controlling her blood pressure:
Incorrect: Renin-angiotensin system blocking agents, such as ACE inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs), and direct renin inhibitors are contraindicated in pregnancy and should be discontinued before conception. Exposure to these medications during the second and third trimesters has been associated with neonatal kidney failure and death.  
❌ Continue lisinopril and add oral folic acid supplementation:
Incorrect: Folic acid supplementation is important for development of the nervous system in the early fetus. However, renin-angiotensin system blocking agents, such as ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) are contraindicated in pregnancy and should be discontinued before conception.  
❌ Discontinue lisinopril only after a positive pregnancy test:
Incorrect: It is important to switch medications before conception to avoid any exposure to lisinopril during early pregnancy and organogenesis.  
❌ Increase lisinopril dosage to prevent hypertension-related complications in pregnancy:
Incorrect: Renin-angiotensin system blocking agents, such as ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) are contraindicated in pregnancy and should be discontinued before conception. Antihypertensive agents that are safe during pregnancy should be used instead.  
✅ Discontinue lisinopril and start nifedipine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 20-year-old G1P0 woman at 12 weeks gestation presents to her obstetrician’s office for routine prenatal care. The patient does not have any concerns at this time. She is sexually active with a new partner since becoming pregnant and is not in a committed monogamous relationship. Her medical history is unremarkable, and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. She smokes cigarettes but does not use alcohol or recreational drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 18/min. Physical examination is normal. Initial sexually transmitted infection screening is ordered and is negative. Which of the following screening tests should be repeated when this patient is in the third trimester?

choices.text: Syphilis, HIV, and herpes simplex virus
Human papillomavirus, HIV, and hepatitis B

questions.solution:
This pregnant patient with high-risk features for sexually transmitted infections (STI) should have repeat screening for chlamydia, gonorrhea, syphilis, HIV, and hepatitis B in the third trimester of her pregnancy.  Having a new sexual partner places her at high-risk of developing STIs.  

Pregnant patients should have baseline screening for sexually transmitted infections at their first prenatal visit. The tests to include in the baseline screening for all pregnant patients who are under age 25 or considered high-risk are syphilis, HIV, hepatitis B and C, gonorrhea, and chlamydia. Patients at increased risk for infections, as well as those who have initially positive screening tests, need to have screening for certain conditions repeated in the third trimester. Human papillomavirus (HPV) screening should follow standard recommendations regardless of pregnancy status. If a pregnant patient is determined to have HIV, screening should then be expanded to include conditions screened for in HIV-positive individuals, such as trichomoniasis and possibly herpes simplex virus (HSV) serology.    

All pregnant women under the age of 25 should have repeat testing for gonorrhea and chlamydia in the third trimester. Repeat testing for chlamydia, gonorrhea, syphilis, HIV and hepatitis B should be done in the third trimester in patients who are considered high-risk. High-risk factors include having new or multiple sexual partners, engaging in transactional sex, having a sexual partner who has other concurrent partners, as well as living in an area with a high prevalence of disease. Repeat screening for hepatitis B and HIV should also be done in the third trimester for any pregnant patients who have recently begun using or currently use intravenous drugs.   

A detailed table adapted from the U.S. Center for Disease Control (CDC) with facts on STI screening in pregnancy can be found below.  



Option Analysis

✅ Chlamydia, gonorrhea, and syphilis :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Chlamydia, gonorrhea, and trichomoniasis :
Incorrect: Chlamydia and gonorrhea should be screened for in the third trimester in this patient with high-risk features. However, screening for trichomoniasis is not recommended in asymptomatic pregnant women. 
❌ Chlamydia, bacterial vaginosis, and syphilis :
Incorrect: Chlamydia and syphilis should be screened for in the third trimester in this patient with high-risk features. However, screening for bacterial vaginosis is not recommended in asymptomatic pregnant women. 
❌ Syphilis, HIV, and herpes simplex virus:
Incorrect: Syphilis and HIV should be screened for in the third trimester in this patient with high-risk features. However, screening for herpes simplex virus is not recommended in asymptomatic pregnant women. 
❌ Human papillomavirus, HIV, and hepatitis B:
Incorrect: HIV and Hepatitis B should be screened for in the third trimester in this patient with high-risk features. However, screening for HPV is not recommended in asymptomatic pregnant women, or in women under age 25.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the office because of vulvar pain and dysuria. She does not have increased urinary frequency or flank pain. She has never experienced similar symptoms before and her past medical history is unremarkable. The patient is sexually active and has had 4 sexual partners in the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. Current medications include a combined oral contraceptive and a hair vitamin. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows grouped shallow ulcers with erythema on the right labia majora. Right inguinal lymph nodes are tender to palpation. After further evaluation, the patient is started on an oral medication that requires a specific thymidine kinase for activation. Which of the following is an important adverse effect of the medication used in this patient when it is administered intravenously?
questions.solution:
This patient’s physical examination findings of grouped shallow genital ulcers with tender lymphadenopathy are consistent with herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. Primary HSV infection is usually treated with acyclovir, which requires thymidine kinase for activation.  

Acyclovir is a guanosine analog that is effective against HSV-1, HSV-2, and varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infections. When used orally, it is only partially absorbed; therefore, it is used for mild mucocutaneous lesions and genital lesions or for herpes prophylaxis in immunocompromised individuals, such as individuals with AIDS. The oral drug is well tolerated but may cause gastrointestinal (GI) distress and headache. On the other hand, intravenous acyclovir is the treatment of more severe herpes infections, such as HSV encephalitis or neonatal HSV infection. Toxic effects of parenteral administration include delirium, tremor, seizures, hypotension, and nephrotoxicity (obstructive crystalline nephropathy and acute kidney injury). Acyclovir has no effect on latent forms of HSV and VZV. Resistance can involve changes in viral DNA polymerase or a mutation in viral thymidylate kinase.

Option Analysis

❌ Bone marrow suppression:
Incorrect: Bone marrow suppression is an important side effect of ganciclovir, which is effective against cytomegalovirus. This patient most likely has an HSV infection.
❌ Pancreatitis:
Incorrect: Pancreatitis is an important side effect of didanosine, a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor. Didanosine is not effective against HSV.
✅ Obstructive crystalline nephropathy:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Acute interstitial nephritis:
Incorrect: Acute interstitial nephritis is usually associated with exposure to beta-lactams and proton pump inhibitors. This patient’s HSV infection is most likely being treated with acyclovir.
❌ Disulfiram-like reaction:
Incorrect: Disulfiram-like reactions can occur commonly with metronidazole or griseofulvin, neither of which is effective against HSV.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the outpatient gynecology clinic with a 6-day history of dysuria and green vaginal discharge. The patient is sexually active with one male partner, who travels frequently for work. She has an intrauterine device (IUD) for contraception that was placed three years ago. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.3°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 118/75 mmHg. Genitourinary examination shows an edematous, friable cervix with mucopurulent discharge. An endocervical swab is sent for nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) to confirm the likely diagnosis. A point-of-care HCG pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: IUD removal followed by antibiotic treatment

questions.solution:
This 28-year-old woman presents with a 6-day history of dysuria, green vaginal discharge, and examination findings consistent with Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. Antibiotic treatment should be given at the initial visit and should consist of intramuscular ceftriaxone and oral doxycycline (to include coverage for chlamydial coinfection).

Intramuscular ceftriaxone is the antibiotic of choice for uncomplicated gonococcal cervicitis.  Because coinfection with Chlamydia trachomatis is exceedingly common in cases of gonorrhea, antibiotic coverage should also include oral doxycycline or oral azithromycin for presumptive coinfection. Patients should be treated on-site to ensure compliance, or they should be referred to a sexually transmitted infection (STI) clinic for same-day treatment. If patients do not respond to first-line treatment, cultures should be sent because of increasing antibiotic resistance.

If a biologically female patient with Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection has an intrauterine device (IUD) in place, as in this case, the IUD does not need to be removed as part of the management plan. However, it is important to note that a new IUD should not be placed for patients with current purulent cervicitis.

In addition to treating the patient with empiric antibiotics, all sexual partners should be referred for evaluation and treatment. In cases where a patient’s partners are not available for evaluation and treatment, expedited partner therapy (EPT) can be prescribed, which permits the provider to provide treatment without requiring them to come in for an examination.  Additional screening for other sexually transmitted infections is recommended, including HIV, syphilis, and Chlamydia trachomatis. Pre-exposure prophylaxis for HIV (PrEP) should also be offered to patients who are HIV-negative because it reduces the risk of acquiring HIV. Finally, patients should be counseled to abstain from sexual intercourse for seven days following completion of treatment, as long as symptoms have resolved and all partners have been treated.

If patients’ symptoms resolve following treatment for uncomplicated N. gonorrhoeae infection, they do not need to be tested for a cure. However, since pharyngitis from N. gonorrhoeae is harder to eradicate, patients with oropharyngeal N. gonorrhoeae infections should have a test for cure.  

Option Analysis

✅ Intramuscular ceftriaxone plus oral doxycycline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ IUD removal followed by antibiotic treatment:
Incorrect: In female patients who have an IUD in place and suspected Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection, removal of the IUD is not required before or after starting antibiotic treatment.  
❌ Intramuscular ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: Monotherapy with intramuscular ceftriaxone is not the appropriate treatment in patients with suspected Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Coinfection with Chlamydia trachomatis has not been excluded in this case, so treatment should include coverage for both pathogens.  
❌ Oral doxycycline:
Incorrect: Monotherapy with oral doxycycline is not appropriate because it is not sufficiently effective against Neisseria gonorrhoeae.  
❌ Oral metronidazole:
Incorrect: Metronidazole targets anaerobic bacteria and protozoa, which makes it appropriate treatment for bacterial vaginosis or trichomoniasis. However, it is not effective against Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which is a concern based on this patient’s clinical presentation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 4 para 2, presents to the office for evaluation of amenorrhea. Menarche was at age 12, and she had a regular 28-day cycle with no dysmenorrhea until four months ago when her cycle stopped. Past medical history is significant for two missed abortions, the last of which was six months ago, managed via dilation and curettage. She has a healthy five-year-old girl and a three-year-old boy born via spontaneous vaginal delivery. She is not taking any medications currently. Family history is significant for hypothyroidism in her mother. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 22 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Speculum examination shows moist vaginal mucosa with no abnormalities. Urine beta-HCG is negative. FSH, TSH, and prolactin levels are normal. A progesterone withdrawal test is performed with no withdrawal bleeding. An estrogen/progesterone withdrawal test is performed. Bleeding is absent again. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings of secondary amenorrhea, a history of an intrauterine procedure (dilation and curettage), routine laboratory findings, and absence of bleeding on progesterone challenge test and estrogen/progesterone withdrawal test make the diagnosis of intrauterine adhesions (Asherman syndrome) most likely.

A 10-day medroxyprogesterone test (progestin challenge) assesses uterine function. It involves administering 10 milligrams of medroxyprogesterone daily for ten days to see if that induces menstrual bleeding. A healthy uterus should bleed. If there’s no bleeding, estrogen is given to thicken the uterine lining, and medroxyprogesterone is added. Failure to bleed strongly suggests endometrial scarring.
   

Option Analysis

❌ Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea:
Incorrect: Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (FHA) is a disorder caused by disruption of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. Common risk factors include stress, anorexia nervosa, and excessive exercise.  The condition is most commonly seen in young athletes. The cause of amenorrhea in this patient with normal lifestyle habits and a healthy body mass index is unlikely. Additionally, this patient’s normal hormone levels and absence of bleeding on the progesterone challenge test suggest an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Endometriosis:
Incorrect:  Endometriosis presents in women of reproductive age with pelvic pain, vaginal bleeding, dysmenorrhea, and deep dyspareunia (due to lesions in the posterior cul-de-sac). This patient has had none of these complaints, making this diagnosis less likely.  
✅ Asherman syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Primary ovarian insufficiency:
Incorrect: Accelerated follicular depletion can be due to primary ovarian insufficiency or secondary to follicular atresia due to other causes (radiation, chemotherapy, autoimmune). It commonly presents with irregular menstrual cycles, hot flashes, vaginal dryness, and elevated FSH levels, none seen in this patient. Additionally, this patient’s normal hormone levels and absence of bleeding on the progesterone challenge test suggest an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Hypothyroidism:
Incorrect: Although amenorrhea can be seen in hypothyroidism, it is usually accompanied by fatigue, weight gain, constipation, cold intolerance, and other findings not seen in this patient. Additionally, this patient’s normal hormone levels make this cause less likely. The absence of bleeding on progesterone challenge tests suggests an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman, G1P0, who is 14 weeks pregnant, presents to the clinic for her first prenatal visit. She has no significant medical history and takes only prenatal vitamins. This is her first pregnancy, and it has been uneventful, except for mild nausea. She is currently employed as a graphic designer and lives with her partner, who does not smoke. She has been smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 5 years. She mentions several unsuccessful, unaided attempts to quit smoking in the past year, citing increased stress at work as a major trigger for her continued tobacco use. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg. On physical examination, she is awake and alert and in no distress. Which of the following is the most appropriate question to ask next?

choices.text: "How would you describe your current desire and willingness to quit smoking?"
"Can you provide more details about your dietary habits?"
"How often do you engage in physical activity?"
"Do you think it's responsible to continue smoking during pregnancy?"
"Why haven't you been able to stop smoking despite knowing the risks in pregnancy?"

questions.solution:
This patient has divulged a great deal about her tobacco use during the initial prenatal visit, including how much she smokes, for how long, and previous attempts and obstacles to quitting. The best next step in follow-up is to inquire about her current desire and willingness to quit smoking.

Tobacco use during pregnancy is a significant health concern, both for the mother and the developing fetus. It is associated with a range of adverse outcomes, including increased risks of preterm birth, low birth weight, miscarriage, and stillbirth. Routine screening for tobacco, alcohol, and substance use at each prenatal visit is an essential component of comprehensive prenatal care. This approach ensures that these behaviors are consistently monitored and addressed throughout the pregnancy.

When assessing tobacco use during pregnancy, it is essential to approach the conversation in a nonjudgmental and supportive manner as this fosters open communication and encourages honest disclosure. Questions should be framed to elicit detailed information while conveying empathy and understanding. Incorporating the five major steps to intervention (the "5 A’s") into the interview process provides a structured and effective approach for assessing and assisting a patient. The 5 A’s include: Ask about past and current use of nicotine; Advise patients to stop, provide advice about quitting (such as a “quit line” number or a referral to a counselor that specializes in tobacco cessation), and inform patients about the risks of tobacco use in pregnancy; Assess your patient’s willingness to quit; Assist your patient if they are interested in quitting; and Arrange follow-up visits to track progress.  

Option Analysis

✅ "How would you describe your current desire and willingness to quit smoking?":
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ "Can you provide more details about your dietary habits?":
Incorrect: This question shifts the focus away from the patient's tobacco use, which is the most pertinent health concern given her current pregnancy and smoking. While dietary habits are important to discuss in prenatal care, they are not directly relevant to addressing her tobacco use and her attempts to quit, which are more critical for fetal health at this time.  
❌ "How often do you engage in physical activity?":
Incorrect: This question shifts the focus away from the patient's tobacco use, which is the most pertinent health concern given her current pregnancy and smoking. While physical activity is important in prenatal care, it is not directly relevant to addressing her tobacco use and her attempts to quit, which are more critical for fetal health.  
❌ "Do you think it's responsible to continue smoking during pregnancy?":
Incorrect: While addressing her tobacco use is necessary, this question is inappropriate as it carries a judgmental tone, which could make the patient feel blamed or shamed. In a clinical setting, it is important to maintain a non-judgmental and supportive approach, especially when discussing sensitive topics, like smoking during pregnancy.
❌ "Why haven't you been able to stop smoking despite knowing the risks in pregnancy?":
Incorrect: While addressing her tobacco use is necessary, this question is inappropriate as it carries a judgmental tone, which could make the patient feel blamed or shamed. In a clinical setting, it is important to maintain a non-judgmental and supportive approach, especially when discussing sensitive topics, like smoking during pregnancy.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, at 10 weeks of gestational age presents to the emergency department at noon with heavy vaginal bleeding and severe pelvic pain. This morning, she soaked through four pads in an hour and passed multiple large clots, some of which appeared to contain tissue—though she has been using the same pad for the past two hours. The pain is currently rated a 5 on a 10-point scale, though at its peak, it was a 9 and radiated to her lower back and thighs. An ultrasound performed two weeks ago showed a viable fetus with cardiac activity. The medical history is notable for three prior uncomplicated vaginal deliveries. Temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 122/78 mmHg. On exam, the cervical os is closed and several small blood clots are visible in the vagina. Lab results are shown below. An ultrasound shows a thickened endometrial lining without an intrauterine fluid collection; the adnexa appear grossly normal. IV fluids and analgesics are administered. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

 Laboratory test  Result 
 Blood type  A-negative 
 Hemoglobin  10.8 g/dL 
 Platelets  304,000/mm3 
 Prothrombin time  12 sec 
 Activated partial thromboplastin time  30 sec
questions.solution:
This patient has a complete miscarriage (closed os and empty uterus after heavy bleeding), and she is Rh negative. Therefore, expectant management and treatment with Rh immune globulin to prevent alloimmunization in future pregnancies is the most appropriate management.    

The management choice is determined by the type of miscarriage. Expectant management is indicated for stable patients with threatened or complete miscarriage, while surgical management is indicated for unstable patients and those with infections.    

For stable patients with asymptomatic (i.e. missed), inevitable, or incomplete pregnancy loss, all three management strategies (i.e. expectant, medical, and surgical) are appropriate and patient preference should guide the decision. Medical management of an early miscarriage involves the use of misoprostol, which induces uterine contractions to expel the products of conception. If available, pre-treatment with mifepristone is recommended because it reduces the risk of retained products of conception. This option allows patients to better control the timing and setting of their miscarriage while avoiding a surgical procedure. A suction dilation and curettage (D&C) is considered definitive management with the lowest failure rate and is associated with lower amounts of bleeding and faster resolution of symptoms. Some patients may determine these benefits outweigh the inherent risks of surgery.  

All patients, including those undergoing expectant management, should be counseled on warning signs that require evaluation. These include heavy bleeding (soaking at least two pads per hour for at least two hours in a row), prolonged bleeding (bleeding persisting beyond two to three weeks), pain uncontrolled with pain medication, fever, or abnormal/foul-smelling discharge.    

Additionally, regardless of the management option chosen, Rh immune globulin should be administered to all Rh-negative patients at risk of alloimmunization. This includes all patients undergoing a procedure during pregnancy (e.g. D&C for early pregnancy loss) and those with uterine bleeding, especially after 7 weeks of gestational age. Alloimmunization refers to the development of antibodies in maternal serum against antigens on fetal red blood cells, which can occur when fetal and maternal blood come into contact with one another. Once alloimmunized, these maternal antibodies may attack any future Rh-positive fetus, resulting in severe fetal anemia and/or pregnancy loss. In the U.S., Rh immune globulin is usually given routinely to any Rh-negative patient who experiences bleeding during pregnancy. However, it should be noted that international guidelines regarding the use of Rh immune globulin in the first trimester vary.  



Option Analysis

✅ Rh-immune globulin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Blood transfusion:
Incorrect: This patient is hemodynamically stable and her bleeding has slowed, so a blood transfusion is not needed at this time. It is important to remember, however, that lab values may be falsely reassuring in patients with acute hemorrhage. This is why it is important to look at the entire clinical picture, especially the vital signs and exam findings.
❌ Serum human chorionic gonadotropin level (hCG):
Incorrect: This patient had a prior ultrasound at 8 weeks that showed fetal cardiac activity (FCA). FCA confirms fetal viability, so once FCA has been seen on an ultrasound, hCG levels are no longer necessary. If drawn, however, low levels would support the diagnosis of pregnancy loss.
❌ Misoprostol:
Incorrect: This patient is stable and has a complete miscarriage, so expectant management is recommended. The endometrium will often appear thick initially; however, it will return to normal over the next few days to weeks as bleeding resolves. Medical (or surgical) management is not required simply to address a thickened endometrial lining in an otherwise stable patient.
❌ Suction dilation and curettage (D&C):
Incorrect: This patient is clinically stable despite the amount of bleeding she had at home. Expectant management is appropriate at this time, though a D&C may be indicated later if bleeding does not continue to improve or if she becomes unstable, develops an infection, or has evidence of retained products of conception.

questions.text: A 31-year-old G2P1 woman at 25 weeks gestation presents to the primary care clinic due to one month of worsening fatigue that has caused her to miss work the past few days. Temperature is 37.0ºC (98.6ºF), pulse is 96/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 112/75 mmHg. The patient has no significant past medical history. She stopped taking her prenatal vitamin during the first trimester because of nausea and vomiting and has not been consistently taking it since. The patient is in no acute distress but appears pale. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal, and abdominal exam shows a gravid uterus appropriate for gestational age. Serum hemoglobin is 9.0 g/dL with a mean corpuscular volume of 76 fL. Serum haptoglobin is within normal limits. Ferritin is low. Which of the following is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with no known medical comorbidities or malabsorptive conditions has microcytic anemia with low ferritin likely caused by iron deficiency. Iron deficiency anemia is the most common cause of anemia in pregnancy.  

A mild degree of dilutional anemia is physiologic during pregnancy. However, specific trimester-related cutoffs should be used to define anemia in pregnancy. For patients in the first or third trimester of pregnancy, a hemoglobin less than 11 g/dL is diagnostic of anemia. For patients in the second trimester, a hemoglobin of less than 10.5 g/dL is diagnostic of anemia. Pregnant patients should be screened for anemia of pregnancy in the first and second trimesters, and if present, patients should be treated before birth where blood loss can worsen anemia and lead to maternal and fetal complications. All pregnant patients should also be screened for hemoglobinopathies using hemoglobin electrophoresis at the start of their pregnancy.  

Causes of anemia of pregnancy include nutritional deficiencies, resulting in impaired red blood cell production. In addition, inherited mutations of hemoglobin structure, known as hemoglobinopathies, or conditions resulting in increased destruction of red blood cells can also cause anemia during pregnancy. Patients with malabsorption syndromes (e.g. celiac disease, prior gastric bypass) may develop folate or B12 deficiency. Patients with multiple medical comorbidities may develop anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. Physical examination should assess for scleral icterus (e.g. hemolysis) and neurologic signs, such as ataxia (e.g. B12 deficiency).  

Pregnant patients with anemia may present with fatigue, shortness of breath, or restless legs (especially in iron deficiency). When evaluating a patient with anemia of pregnancy, history should focus on determining the underlying cause by assessing dietary intake, use of prenatal vitamins, family history of hemoglobinopathies, history of nausea and vomiting, and signs of blood loss. Iron deficiency anemia is the most common pathologic cause of anemia in pregnancy due to multiple factors. Iron requirements increase significantly in pregnancy and inadequate iron intake (often in resource-limited places), blood loss from prior deliveries, and conditions that prevent intake or impair absorption (like nausea and vomiting) in pregnancy can lead to iron deficiency.  
 



Option Analysis

✅  Iron deficiency:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Family history of pernicious anemia:
Incorrect: Pernicious anemia can lead to inadequate absorption of B12 with subsequent macrocytic anemia. This patient has microcytic anemia.
❌ Lack of balance and coordination:
Incorrect: Ataxia, or lack of balance or coordination, can be caused by inadequate vitamin B12 intake, which can lead to macrocytic anemia. This patient has microcytic anemia. 
❌ Comorbid medical diseases:
Incorrect: Anemia of chronic disease is a common cause of anemia in nonpregnant patients. It can also be seen occasionally in pregnant patients. Anemia of chronic disease typically results in normocytic anemia. This patient has microcytic anemia.
❌ Scleral icterus:
Incorrect: Scleral icterus indicates hyperbilirubinemia, which can be seen with hemolytic anemia. However, this patient has a normal haptoglobin and microcytic anemia, making hemolysis unlikely.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of moderate to severe pelvic pain that is crampy and occurs recurrently during menstruation. She also experiences headaches and nausea during menstruation. Her first menstruation occurred nine months ago. She has no vaginal discharge and no acyclic vaginal bleeding. The patient has missed several school days each month due to her symptoms. She is not sexually active and has no significant past medical history. She has no known allergies. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a well-appearing adolescent girl with a benign abdominal examination. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy adolescent girl with menarche 9 months ago presents with recurrent crampy pelvic pain during menstruation and can be diagnosed with primary dysmenorrhea. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen, naproxen, or celecoxib are considered first-line treatment for primary dysmenorrhea.    

Primary dysmenorrhea is a clinical diagnosis and can be made in patients with symptoms and history that are consistent with primary dysmenorrhea and without underlying evidence of pelvic abnormalities. NSAIDs are considered first-line treatment. They can be started a day or two before menses are expected. Acetaminophen can be tried in patients who cannot tolerate or are allergic to NSAIDs. Hormonal therapies can be considered when first-line treatments fail to control symptoms (e.g. oral contraceptive pill, progestin implant, depot medroxyprogesterone acetate). Choice of hormonal therapy should be based on patient preference and eligibility, and the side effects of the different therapies. In addition, patients may also consider alternative and complementary therapies such as exercise, heat therapy, dietary supplements, and smoking cessation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ibuprofen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Progestin-only implant:
Incorrect: Hormonal therapies can provide pain relief for patients with primary dysmenorrhea; however, NSAIDs are considered first-line treatment. Hormonal agents can be started if conservative treatment with ibuprofen and other NSAIDs fails. 
❌ Acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Acetaminophen can be used in patients who have contraindications to or cannot tolerate NSAIDs. NSAIDs are considered first-line treatment.
❌ Combined oral contraceptive pill:
Incorrect: Hormonal therapies can provide pain relief for patients with primary dysmenorrhea. However, these agents should be considered if conservative treatment with ibuprofen or other NSAIDs fails. 
❌ Intramuscular depot medroxyprogesterone acetate:
Incorrect: Hormonal therapies can provide relief to patients with primary dysmenorrhea. However, these agents should be considered if conservative treatment with ibuprofen or other NSAIDs fails.

questions.text: A 59-year-old postmenopausal woman presents to her gynecologist with a 3-month history of increased abdominal girth, pelvic pressure, pelvic pain, anorexia, and fatigue. She does not have abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, vaginal discharge, change in urination, or change in bowel habits. Her medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia and hypertension controlled with enalapril and lovastatin. Her family history is significant for a parent with colon cancer. Temperature is 37.2 °C (98.9 °F), heart rate is 74 beats per minute, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 132/80 mmHg. Abdominal examination reveals distension and diffuse mild tenderness without rebound. A fluid wave and shifting dullness are present. Pelvic examination reveals a 10 cm fixed right sided irregular mass. Which of the following historical elements, if present, would be consistent with the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Family history of a sister with cervical cancer
History of 3 spontaneous normal vaginal deliveries

questions.solution:
This postmenopausal patient presents with increased abdominal girth, pelvic pressure and pain, and physical examination findings of an irregular, fixed pelvic mass and ascites, which supports a diagnosis of ovarian cancer. Early satiety is a symptom frequently experienced by patients with ovarian cancer.

Patients with epithelial ovarian cancer can present with a broad spectrum of vague non-specific symptoms that can easily be dismissed. Early satiety is a symptom that should be further investigated. Compression of the stomach from metastases to the upper abdomen or from associated ascites can reduce gastric capacity and lead to the feeling of fullness after eating only a small amount of food. In addition, small bowel adhesions and metastases producing varying levels of bowel obstruction and interfering with normal gastrointestinal mobility and function can further contribute to this sensation.

Given this patient’s history and physical exam findings, there is a high likelihood of finding advanced stage III or IV cancer at the time of surgical exploration. Unfortunately, patients with epithelial ovarian cancer often present at an advanced stage. Other symptoms that may be present include constipation, urinary frequency, dyspnea, and weight loss. Vaginal bleeding, when present, may reflect uterine metastases or the presence of a hormonally active ovarian tumor.

Several risk factors are known to either increase or decrease the chances of developing epithelial ovarian cancer. Those that heighten risk include older age, inherited mutations in BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes, Lynch syndrome type II, nulliparity, infertility, early menarche, and late menopause. Conversely, those that lower risk include oral contraceptive use, childbirth, breastfeeding, and undergoing bilateral tubal ligation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Family history of a sister with cervical cancer:
Incorrect: This patient most likely has ovarian cancer. Most cases of ovarian cancer are sporadic and not inherited, even in patients with a strong family history. Hereditary ovarian cancer can be site-specific, part of breast-ovarian cancer syndrome, or connected to Lynch syndrome type II.  
❌ History of 3 spontaneous normal vaginal deliveries:
Incorrect: Increasing parity has been shown to protect against ovarian cancer as it results in a decrease in incessant ovulation, which is thought to be a possible cause of ovarian cancer. Women who have had one or more full-term pregnancies have a lower risk of developing ovarian cancer compared to nulliparous women.  
❌ History of bilateral tubal ligation:
Incorrect: Bilateral tubal ligation has been associated with a decreased relative risk of ovarian cancer.
❌ History of cigarette smoking:
Incorrect: This patient likely has an advanced stage of the most common epithelial tumor of the ovaries, serous cystadenocarcinoma, for which, the risk is not increased by cigarette smoking.  
✅ History of early satiety:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman comes to her physician’s office for evaluation of a 6-month history of amenorrhea with associated vaginal dryness and hot flashes. She has been attempting to conceive for the past year without success. Her past medical history is significant for Hashimoto thyroiditis for which she takes daily levothyroxine. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 24 kg/m2. Hair growth and pattern are normal, and breast development is normal. Pelvic examination is normal and there is no evidence of bleeding, masses, or cervical motion tenderness. Laboratory studies are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  

Estradiol
<5 pg/mL  
Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)  
65 mU/mL (60 U/L)  
Luteinizing hormone  
60 mU/mL (60 U/L)  
Total testosterone  
25 ng/dL  
Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)  
2.3 μU/mL (2.3 mU/L)  
Prolactin
18 ng/mL (18 µg/L)  
Human chorionic gonadotropin  
Negative
questions.solution:
This patient presents with 6 months of signs and symptoms of estrogen deficiency (e.g., vaginal dryness, hot flashes, amenorrhea, and infertility), and laboratory testing revealed elevated luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone levels and a low estradiol level. This presentation in a 33-year-old woman is consistent with a diagnosis of primary ovarian insufficiency.

Premature ovarian insufficiency (POI) is characterized by the loss of normal ovarian function before the age of 40. Patients typically present with signs and symptoms of estrogen deficiency (such as hot flashes, vaginal dryness, and amenorrhea). The diagnosis is supported by laboratory results that demonstrate low estradiol and elevated levels of FSH and LH. The elevated gonadotropins (FSH and LH) indicate that the dysfunction is at the level of the ovaries rather than pituitary or hypothalamic level. POI can be secondary to autoimmune disease, which is the most likely etiology in this patient who has a history of autoimmune thyroid disease (Hashimoto thyroiditis). Genetic abnormalities and toxin exposure (chemotherapy, radiation therapy) can also be the cause of POI. Most cases are idiopathic.  

Option Analysis

✅ Primary ovarian insufficiency:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea:
Incorrect: Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea occurs from low energy availability (decreased caloric intake, excessive energy expenditure, or both) and/or stress. It is characterized by amenorrhea with normal or low serum gonadotropin concentrations and low serum estradiol concentrations. This patient has elevated levels of FSH and LH.  
❌ Polycystic ovarian syndrome:
Incorrect: Patients with polycystic ovarian syndrome typically have signs of hyperandrogenism (such as hirsutism), oligomenorrhea/amenorrhea, and obesity. Laboratory testing may reveal elevated testosterone levels. This patient shows no evidence of hyperandrogenism and has a normal serum total testosterone level and normal BMI, making PCOS unlikely.  
❌ Hypothyroidism:
Incorrect: Patients with hypothyroidism may have irregular menstrual cycles or amenorrhea; however, this patient has a normal TSH on thyroid replacement therapy.  
❌ Prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma:
Incorrect: A prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma typically presents with galactorrhea and menstrual irregularities. Patients with prolactinomas typically have prolactin levels that are way above normal. This patient has a normal prolactin level.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with several hours of nausea, vomiting, and severe left lower quadrant colicky abdominal pain that started after she returned from jogging earlier that morning. The patient reports a similar issue a few years ago requiring surgery for “untwisting” the ovary. She has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37.7 ºC (99.9 ºF), pulse is 114/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, blood pressure is 156/91 mmHg, and SpO2 is 100% on room air. Beta hCG is negative. Abdominal exam reveals moderate tenderness to palpation at the left lower quadrant of the abdomen with guarding and no rebound. A transvaginal ultrasound is performed and shows a left adnexal mass with a whirlpool sign. Laparoscopy confirms left adnexal torsion. The ovary is viable and there is no evidence of ovarian cyst or neoplasm. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden and severe left lower abdominal pain that began after jogging. She has what sounds like a history of adnexal torsion. The diagnosis of adnexal torsion is confirmed with transvaginal ultrasound. Since this has occurred before and there is no ovarian pathology on laparoscopy, laparoscopic detorsion is the most appropriate management.  

Patients with adnexal torsion generally present with sudden onset abdominal or pelvic pain, which is often intermittent/colicky. Beta hCG will be negative in most patients. Transvaginal (pelvic) ultrasound is the best diagnostic modality for making the diagnosis. An asymmetrically enlarged ovary with absent Doppler flow indicates adnexal torsion. A whirlpool sign (twisted pedicle) may also be seen. If pelvic ultrasound is consistent with adnexal torsion, diagnostic laparoscopy should be performed for laparoscopic detorsion in most cases.

If a benign mass is found and the adnexa is viable, then cystectomy is typically performed along with detorsion. If the adnexa is viable and there have been multiple recurrent torsions and no ovarian or adnexal pathology, then oophoropexy may be considered, to prevent recurrences. It also may be considered in cases of torsion where the patient does not have a contralateral ovary. However, there is no long-term efficacy data on this approach. If ovarian malignancy is suspected, then oophorectomy with salpingectomy should be performed. If the adnexa is non-viable and necrotic, then it should be removed. 

Option Analysis

❌ Oophoropexy  :
Correct: Oophoropexy may be considered in patients with adnexal torsion who have only one ovary to prevent recurrence from occurring in that remaining ovary. It may also be considered in patients with 2 or more episodes of adnexal torsion. However, there are no studies on the long-term efficacy of this approach.
❌ Oophorectomy:
Incorrect: Oophorectomy should be considered if there is adnexal pathology like a large cyst or neoplasm and/or the ovary is non-viable with evidence of necrosis. This patient has a viable ovary without pathology, therefore the next best step is detorsion.
❌ Oophorectomy and salpingectomy:
Incorrect: Oophorectomy can be considered if there is adnexal pathology and/or non-viable adnexa. If adnexa are non-viable, salpingectomy can be performed, especially if there is a potential malignant mass seen. This patient has viable adnexa with no adnexal pathology and thus the ovary can be salvaged.
❌ Cystectomy:
Incorrect: If there is a large cyst noted on the torsed ovary, then it can be excised as it may have been the cause of torsion. 
✅ Detorsion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 32 weeks of gestation presents to Labor and Delivery Triage with worsening swelling in her feet over the last 8 hours. The patient denies headaches, visual changes, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, contractions, loss of fluid, bleeding, or decreased fetal movement. Medical history is notable for two prior uncomplicated vaginal deliveries at term. She takes prenatal vitamins and iron supplements. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 148/90 mmHg. On exam, the lungs are clear to auscultation, the abdomen is non-tender, the deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally, and 2+ pitting edema is noted to the knees. The cervix is 1 cm dilated, 50% effaced, and -3 station. The fetal heart rate pattern is reassuring and no contractions are noted on cardiotocographic monitoring. Which of the following sets of laboratory findings would be consistent with the management strategy of initiating magnesium sulfate and immediate induction of labor?
questions.solution:
The combination of LDH > 600 IU/L, elevated liver enzymes greater than twice the upper limit of normal, and platelets < 100,000/mm3 in a hypertensive pregnant patient indicates HELLP syndrome. Management of HELLP syndrome includes immediate delivery, preferably via the vaginal route; initiation of magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis; and close maternal and fetal monitoring throughout labor and the immediate postpartum period. Answer E showing LDH of 750 IU/L, AST of 98, and platelets of 95,000/mm3 is consistent with HELLP syndrome in this pregnant patient with hypertension.

Hypertensive disorders in pregnancy exist on a spectrum. An appropriate evaluation, including a focused history, exam, laboratory, and fetal well-being assessments, can help determine the severity of disease and will guide management. Critical components of the evaluation that help make the diagnosis and guide the management are detailed below:
 

Once the evaluation is complete, a diagnosis can be made based on the results. The features defining each pregnancy-related hypertensive diagnosis and associated management are detailed in Table 2.
 

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: This patient would have preeclampsia without severe features because they have mild range blood pressures and a P/C ≥ 0.3, but there are no symptoms or lab findings that indicate severe features. Anemia alone is not a criteria for early delivery. Patients with preeclampsia without severe features can be monitored as outpatients with antenatal fetal surveillance and delivered at 37 weeks.   
❌ :
Incorrect: In a patient with mild range blood pressures, the elevated P/C ≥ 0.3 indicates preeclampsia, and the platelet count of < 100,000/mm3 indicates severe features. Patients with preeclampsia with severe features should be monitored closely as inpatients and delivered at 34 weeks with intrapartum magnesium sulfate.   
❌ :
Incorrect: In a patient with mild range blood pressures, the elevated P/C ≥ 0.3 indicates preeclampsia, and the creatinine of > 1.1 mg/dL indicates severe features. Patients with preeclampsia with severe features should be monitored closely as inpatients and delivered at 34 weeks with intrapartum magnesium sulfate.   
❌ :
Incorrect: In a patient with mild range blood pressures, the elevated P/C ≥ 0.3 indicates preeclampsia, and the AST elevated beyond twice the upper limit of normal indicates severe features. The LDH is also elevated ≥ 600 IU/L; however, the platelets are normal. Therefore, the patient does not meet criteria for HELLP syndrome. Patients with preeclampsia with severe features should be monitored closely as inpatients and delivered at 34 weeks with intrapartum magnesium sulfate.   
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman, gravida 1, at 32 weeks of gestation presents to Labor and Delivery triage with a severe headache for the last six hours that has not responded to acetaminophen at home. The headache is severe, bilateral, throbbing, and rated 8 on a 10-point scale. She has mild photophobia but no scotomata, blurred vision, or other visual disturbances. She also has no chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, abdominal pain, contractions, loss of fluid, bleeding, or decreased fetal movement. Past medical history is noncontributory, and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 150/105 mmHg. On exam, there are no focal neurologic deficits, the lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally, the abdomen is non-tender, and there is 2+ bilateral pitting edema of the lower extremities to the mid-calves. The patient is monitored in triage and labs are drawn. Serial blood pressures remain elevated (systolic range 146-158, diastolic range 90-108), and her headache improves. In addition to initiating magnesium sulfate and giving antihypertensive agents as needed, which of the following is the most appropriate management plan for this patient?

choices.text: Admit for magnesium sulfate and immediate cesarean delivery (CD)
Admit for magnesium sulfate and immediate induction of labor (IOL)
Admit for inpatient monitoring, corticosteroids, and IOL at 34 weeks with intrapartum magnesium sulfate
Close outpatient monitoring, antenatal fetal surveillance, and IOL at 37 weeks
Close outpatient monitoring, antenatal fetal surveillance, and cesarean delivery at 37 weeks

questions.solution:
The patient in the vignette has preeclampsia with severe features based on her persistently elevated blood pressures over 4 hours, proteinuria (P/C ≥ 0.3), occasional severe range blood pressures (≥ 160 systolic or ≥ 110 diastolic), and creatinine > 1.1 mg/dL. Her headache is also a concerning feature; however, it responded to medication. This patient is stable enough for inpatient monitoring and expectant management with corticosteroids and magnesium sulfate continued through 24 hours postpartum.

Management of hypertensive disorders in pregnancy varies based on the severity of disease, which is detailed in the table below. Patients with the most severe forms of the disease, including HELLP syndrome and eclampsia, require immediate delivery, magnesium sulfate, and IV antihypertensives to control any severe range blood pressures. Patients with preeclampsia with severe features require steroids (if preterm), anti-hypertensives as needed, and inpatient monitoring until delivery at 34 weeks with intrapartum magnesium sulfate. Patients with preeclampsia without severe features and gestational hypertension can be monitored as outpatients with antepartum fetal surveillance until delivery at 37 weeks; intrapartum magnesium is not required for these patients.

All patients diagnosed with hypertensive disorders in pregnancy who do not require immediate delivery should be monitored for disease progression with regular blood pressure checks, assessments for the development of warning symptoms, and serial labs. Antenatal fetal surveillance with NSTs and periodic ultrasounds to assess fetal growth and amniotic fluid volume are also recommended to monitor fetal well-being, which can be negatively impacted by hypertensive disorders.

Postpartum, all patients should have short-interval follow-up for a blood pressure check and be given strict return precautions. For patients managed with an oral antihypertensive agent during pregnancy, it may be necessary to continue it postpartum.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Admit for magnesium sulfate and immediate cesarean delivery (CD):
Incorrect: Immediate delivery would be appropriate for patients with HELLP syndrome and eclampsia; however, this patient has preeclampsia with severe features, so inpatient monitoring until 34 weeks is indicated. Additionally, the vaginal route is preferred in patients with preeclampsia with severe features who lack contraindications to vaginal delivery (like the one in the vignette).  
❌ Admit for magnesium sulfate and immediate induction of labor (IOL):
Incorrect: Immediate IOL would be appropriate for patients with HELLP syndrome and eclampsia, but close inpatient monitoring until 34 weeks is preferable in patients like this one with preeclampsia with severe features.  
✅ Admit for inpatient monitoring, corticosteroids, and IOL at 34 weeks with intrapartum magnesium sulfate  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Close outpatient monitoring, antenatal fetal surveillance, and IOL at 37 weeks:
Incorrect: This management plan would be appropriate for patients with gestational hypertension or preeclampsia without severe features. This patient has preeclampsia with severe features, so inpatient monitoring until 34 weeks and intrapartum magnesium sulfate is indicated.  
❌ Close outpatient monitoring, antenatal fetal surveillance, and cesarean delivery at 37 weeks:
Incorrect: Outpatient monitoring with antenatal fetal surveillance and delivery at 37 weeks is appropriate for patients with gestational hypertension or preeclampsia without severe features. This patient has preeclampsia with severe features, so inpatient monitoring until 34 weeks is indicated. Additionally, the vaginal route is preferred in patients who lack contraindications to vaginal delivery, like the one in the vignette.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist with heavy and prolonged menstrual bleeding that began 2 years ago and has been worsening during the past 6 months. Her periods previously lasted  5 days and now last 9 to 11 days. She often uses more than 100 tampons per month and soaks through pads at night. She reports constant aching pelvic pain that significantly worsens with menstruation. The pain is partially relieved with naproxen but interferes with her daily activities. She denies postcoital bleeding but has occasional spontaneous intermenstrual spotting. She also has mild dyspareunia. She does not have changes in urination or bowel habits, fever, or vaginal discharge. Her medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes controlled by diet. She has had 3 uncomplicated pregnancies and deliveries. Her last PAP smear 9 months ago was normal. Family history is significant for a sister with fibroids. Abdominal exam reveals mild lower abdominal tenderness without rebound. Pelvic examination reveals a mobile, soft, tender uterus, uniformly enlarged to 12 cm, and no adnexal tenderness or masses. hCG is negative. Which of the following findings on ultrasound will help confirm the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Hypoechoic, well-circumscribed mass within the myometrium
Homogeneously hypoechoic pelvic mass with posterior acoustic enhancement
Complex cystic pelvic mass with echogenic components
Myometrial cyst, with a heterogeneous myometrium and asymmetric myometrial thickness

questions.solution:
This 41-year-old patient who presents with prolonged, heavy menstrual bleeding, constant aching pelvic pain that worsens with menstruation, intermenstrual spotting, dyspareunia and pelvic examination findings of a uniformly enlarged soft tender uterus likely has adenomyosis. The pelvic ultrasound findings of a myometrial cyst, heterogeneous myometrium, and asymmetric myometrial thickness supports the diagnosis of adenomyosis. However, definitive diagnosis can only be made by pathologic evaluation of a hysterectomy specimen.  

Adenomyosis is a benign uterine condition characterized by the presence of ectopic endometrial stroma and glands in the myometrium. The presence of this ectopic tissue in the myometrium causes it to appear heterogeneous. Varying amounts in different areas create the asymmetric thickness, while the cysts represent dilated endometrial glands. These characteristic ultrasound findings help to differentiate adenomyosis from other causes of chronic pelvic pain and bleeding such as leiomyomata and endometriosis. Other ultrasound findings may include striated projections from the endometrium, an obscured endometrial echo border and a globally enlarged uterus. In addition, affected areas of the myometrium may show diffuse vascularity with color doppler.  

Most cases of adenomyosis are diagnosed in parous women in their 40s and 50s, with regression noted following menopause. Adenomyosis can be seen in association with leiomyomata, endometriosis and even endometrial hyperplasia. A possible explanation is that all four are considered estrogen dependent diseases, with growth and symptoms influenced by higher tissue estrogen levels.  

Option Analysis

❌ Hypoechoic, well-circumscribed mass within the myometrium:
Incorrect: This is a typical ultrasound finding for an intramural leiomyoma. Leiomyomata can be subserosal, intramural or submucosal. Although they can cause pain and bleeding, the presence on pelvic examination and a uniformly enlarged uterus, rather than an irregularly shaped uterus, suggests adenomyosis.
❌ Homogeneously hypoechoic pelvic mass with posterior acoustic enhancement :
Incorrect: This is a classic ultrasound description of an endometrioma seen with endometriosis, also known as a chocolate cyst. Although endometriosis can cause pain, dyspareunia, and bleeding, pelvic examination, findings of nodularity, adnexal tenderness, and/or masses would be expected. This patient’s exam is most consistent with adenomyosis.
❌ Complex cystic pelvic mass with echogenic components:
Incorrect: This would be the finding of a benign cystic teratoma with the echogenic components representing hair, teeth, and fat. They can present with pain but are not associated with this bleeding pattern. Also, this patient does not have an adnexal mass but rather an enlarged tender uterus, findings seen with adenomyosis.  
✅ Myometrial cyst, with a heterogeneous myometrium and asymmetric myometrial thickness:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Thickened fluid-filled tubular structure:
Incorrect: This is a classic description of a hydrosalpinx seen in patients with a history of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Pelvic inflammatory disease can cause pelvic pain but is not typically associated with the severe abnormal vaginal bleeding seen in this patient. This patient’s history and pelvic examination are consistent with a diagnosis of adenomyosis and not PID.

questions.text: A 34-year-old G1P1 woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of persistent vaginal bleeding 30 minutes after a prolonged labor and vaginal delivery at home. The placenta was delivered at home and was intact. Past medical history is unremarkable.
