Incorrect: Magnesium sulfate and opioids are common causes of minimal variability, which is defined as normal fluctuations of the FHR having an overall amplitude of 5 bpm or less. This patient has fluctuations of 10 bpm, indicating moderate variability, which is normal.
❌ Fetal growth restriction (FGR):
Incorrect: FGR is associated with placental insufficiency, which increases the risk of late decelerations. Late decelerations begin, peak, and recover after the onset, peak, and end of a contraction, respectively. In this vignette, the decelerations mirror the contraction, consistent with early decelerations. This is a normal finding that indicates head compression, commonly seen at advanced cervical dilation.
❌ Intrapartum fever:
Incorrect: Intrapartum fever is typically associated with fetal tachycardia, defined as a baseline FHR > 160 bpm. A baseline rate of 160 bpm is normal, even when normal fluctuations (known as variability) rise above 160.

questions.text: A 33-year-old primigravid woman presents for a routine antenatal appointment at 41 weeks estimated gestational age (EGA) to discuss a birth plan. The patient prefers a natural delivery with spontaneous labor. She has not experienced any contractions, loss of fluid, vaginal bleeding, or decreased fetal movement. The pregnancy has been uncomplicated and has included all recommended assessments. The patient’s past medical history is unremarkable, and the only medication is a daily prenatal vitamin. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 116/72 mmHg. The patient appears well. The abdomen is non-tender, and the symphysis-fundal height is 40 cm. Fetal heart rate is 150 bpm. A growth ultrasound 1 week ago showed an estimated fetal weight at the 18th-percentile. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 33-year-old patient presents at 41 weeks EGA interested in discussing her natural birth plan. The risk of stillbirth increases after 41 weeks’ gestation. For this reason, patients who prefer to avoid induction of labor should undergo antenatal fetal surveillance to confirm fetal well-being. A biophysical profile (BPP) is an appropriate choice for antenatal testing.       

A complete BPP includes a non-stress test (NST) plus a limited obstetric ultrasound that examines fetal breathing, tone, movement, and amniotic fluid volume (AFV). A modified BPP, which includes only the NST and assessment of AFV, is also acceptable. Neither test has been shown to be superior; a complete BPP is indicated if a modified BPP is inconclusive. Delivery is indicated when antenatal fetal testing is not reassuring.       

A growth ultrasound is indicated if there is clinical suspicion of macrosomia or fetal growth restriction, such as abnormal fundal height. Late- or post-term gestation alone is not generally an indication for a growth ultrasound.       

Option Analysis

✅ Biophysical profile  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Growth ultrasound:
Incorrect: This patient had a normal growth ultrasound just one week ago, and any expected change in weight over one week would be minimal and likely to fall within the margin of error. Instead, growth scans are repeated every 3 to 4 weeks. Moreover, late- or post-term gestation is not an indication for repeating a growth ultrasound. 
❌ Umbilical artery Doppler velocimetry:
Incorrect: Umbilical artery (UA) Doppler velocimetry is used to assess fetal well-being in cases of growth-restriction, which is not present in this vignette. UA Doppler studies have no proven benefits in the assessment of a normally grown late- or post-term fetus. 
❌ Cervical length:
Incorrect: Cervical length (CL) screening serves as a key component in the evaluation of preterm labor – defined as labor occurring before 37 weeks’ gestation. A shortened CL increases the risk of spontaneous preterm birth. The patient in the vignette is late-term at 41 weeks, and the CL is irrelevant at this point. 
❌ Reassurance and routine labor precautions:
Incorrect: The risk of stillbirth increases after 41 weeks’ gestation. For patients preferring spontaneous labor, regular fetal surveillance, such as a biophysical profile (BPP) or modified BPP 2 to 3 times per week, is recommended.

questions.text: A 25-year-old G1P0 woman at 14 weeks and 3 days gestation (by last menstrual period) presents to the obstetrical office to establish care and discuss fetal aneuploidy screening. The patient's past medical history is unremarkable, and the only medication is a prenatal vitamin. An ultrasound confirms dating and a viable intrauterine pregnancy. After appropriate counseling of fetal aneuploidy screening, the patient requests noninvasive testing with a high detection rate. Which of the following is the most appropriate fetal aneuploidy screening strategy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Fetal aneuploidy screening is a noninvasive assessment of risk for chromosomal abnormalities in the fetus. Screening options depend on gestational age, individual risk factors, and patient preference. This patient is presenting in the second trimester. Among the screening options available after the first trimester, cell-free DNA testing has the highest detection rate of fetal aneuploidy.        

Options for fetal aneuploidy screening include ultrasound assessment of nuchal translucency (NT) in the first trimester, one-step serum tests, and combined protocols (integrated, contingent, and sequential stepwise) that use specimens from both trimesters. One-step serum tests encompass the first trimester analyte screen (beta-hCG and pregnancy-associated plasma protein A, or PAPP-A), cell-free DNA analysis, and the quad screen (hCG, alpha-fetoprotein, inhibit A, and unconjugated estriol). The methods associated with the highest detection rates include cell-free DNA analysis, integrated screening, contingent screening, and sequential stepwise screening.        

All pregnant patients should be offered fetal aneuploidy screening regardless of their age or baseline risk. Counseling should cover each patient’s specific risk of carrying a fetus affected by aneuploidy and the fact that positive results require confirmatory diagnostic testing. Confirmatory tests include chorionic villus sampling and amniocentesis, both of which are invasive.   

Option Analysis

✅ Cell-free DNA:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Nuchal translucency (NT) scan only:
Incorrect: While an NT scan can detect fetal aneuploidies and structural abnormalities, its detection rate is low. Additionally, the patient is outside the recommended gestational age range of 10 to 14 weeks. Therefore, it is not the most appropriate fetal aneuploidy screening test for this patient.  
❌ Amniocentesis:
Incorrect: Amniocentesis is an invasive diagnostic procedure used to confirm fetal aneuploidy. This patient is requesting a noninvasive screening test. Therefore, amniocentesis is not appropriate. 
❌ Integrated screening test:
Incorrect: Integrated screening requires NT testing and a serum analyte screen for free beta-hCG and pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A) in the first trimester. While it has a high detection rate for fetal aneuploidy, this patient is already in the second trimester. Without first-trimester labs, integrated screening is not feasible.  
❌ Genetics counseling referral:
Incorrect: A genetics counseling referral is generally reserved for patients with abnormal fetal aneuploidy screening results or specific high-risk factors. This patient does not have risk factors, so a referral is not indicated. If screening results are positive, however, referral would be appropriate.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman presents to the gynecology office with daily light vaginal bleeding for the past month. The patient’s last menstrual period was 3 years ago. Past medical history is significant for menarche at age 14, polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), uterine fibroids, and heterozygous factor V Leiden mutation. The patient does not take any medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. A chaperoned pelvic examination reveals a normal-sized uterus, normal adnexa, and a small amount of blood at the cervical os. An endometrial biopsy shows crowded endometrial glands with solid components, marked nuclear atypia, and significant glandular irregularities. Which of the following risk factors most significantly contributes to this patient’s likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has postmenopausal bleeding and an endometrial biopsy consistent with endometrial cancer. In individuals with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), there is unopposed estrogen exposure from chronic estrogen production without ovulation. This leads to an increased risk of developing endometrial cancer.

Unopposed estrogen exposure is a major risk factor for the development of endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia (EIN) and endometrial cancer. Unopposed estrogen can be endogenous or exogenous. Endogenous unopposed estrogen may result from chronic anovulation, as seen in PCOS, or from peripheral conversion of androgens to estrone in adipose tissue, as seen in obesity. Exogenous unopposed estrogen can occur in patients using estrogen therapy without progesterone, which is not recommended in those with a uterus.

Additional risk factors for the development of endometrial cancer include nulliparity, early menarche (<12 years of age), late menopause, personal or family history of Lynch syndrome, and type 2 diabetes mellitus.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Polycystic ovary syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Age of menarche:
Incorrect: The patient was 14 years old at menarche, which falls within the normal range. Early menarche (< 12 years old) is a risk factor for endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia and endometrial cancer.
❌ Age of menopause:
Incorrect: The patient’s last menstrual period was at age 50, and the average age of menopause is 51.4 years. Late menopause would be a risk factor for developing endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia and endometrial cancer.
❌ Uterine fibroids:
Incorrect: Uterine fibroids can cause abnormal uterine bleeding in premenopausal patients. However, fibroids are not a risk factor for endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia and endometrial cancer.
❌ Heterozygous factor V Leiden mutation:
Incorrect: Factor V Leiden mutation increases the risk of thrombosis. If a patient with factor V Leiden is on an anticoagulant, that can be a cause of uterine bleeding. However, it is not associated with endometrial cancer.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the gynecology office with abnormal uterine bleeding. The patient reports heavy bleeding with menstruation, soaking through more than one pad per hour for 10 days. This has been occurring every 4 weeks for the past 6 months. There is no associated fatigue, shortness of breath, or chest pain. Past medical history includes type 2 diabetes, and family history is significant for Lynch syndrome. Vital signs are within normal limits. A chaperoned physical examination reveals a non-tender, enlarged, globular uterus. Transvaginal ultrasound rules out structural causes of abnormal uterine bleeding. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study to obtain now?

choices.text: Complete blood count (CBC) and iron studies

questions.solution:
This patient, who is over 45 years of age, has abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) based on the reported volume and duration of monthly menstrual bleeding. Transvaginal ultrasound has ruled out structural causes of AUB, and the patient has risk factors for endometrial cancer (i.e., type 2 diabetes, family history of Lynch syndrome). The most appropriate next diagnostic test is an endometrial biopsy.

Endometrial biopsy is used to assess the endometrial tissue for benign glandular cells, endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia (EIN), or endometrial carcinoma. There are several ways to obtain a sample of the endometrial tissue, but the most common method is with an endometrial pipelle, which can be performed in the office. Hysteroscopy with direct biopsy of endometrial tissue can also be performed if results of a pipelle biopsy are inadequate, if a patient is unable to tolerate the office procedure, or if suspicion for EIN or endometrial carcinoma is high enough.

Endometrial biopsy is recommended for all patients who are ≥45 years of age with AUB, and for all postmenopausal patients with an endometrial thickness >4 mm, due to the increased risk of endometrial carcinoma. In premenopausal patients, endometrial thickness does not correlate with the risk of endometrial cancer. In patients with AUB who are under 45 years of age, biopsy is indicated if risk factors for EIN or endometrial cancer are present. These include a history of unopposed estrogen exposure, type 2 diabetes, nulliparity, early age of menarche, late age of menopause, and a personal or family history of Lynch syndrome. In patients of any age with persistent AUB despite medical management, endometrial biopsy is also warranted.   

Option Analysis

✅ Endometrial biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pelvic magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):
Incorrect: Pelvic MRI is primarily used to further evaluate structural abnormalities such as fibroids or adenomyosis when ultrasound findings are inconclusive or in preoperative planning. In this case, transvaginal ultrasound did not reveal any structural abnormalities. Given this patient’s risk factors (i.e. family history of Lynch syndrome) for endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia (EIN) and endometrial cancer, an endometrial biopsy is the most appropriate next step.
❌ Complete blood count (CBC) and iron studies:
Incorrect: These tests may be useful in assessing for anemia and iron deficiency due to blood loss; however, they do not identify the underlying cause of abnormal uterine bleeding. An endometrial biopsy is the best diagnostic test to perform now.
❌ Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH):
Incorrect: TSH is part of the general workup for abnormal uterine bleeding. However, this patient's bleeding pattern and personal and family risk factors raise concern for endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia (EIN) or endometrial cancer. Therefore, an endometrial biopsy is the most appropriate next step.
❌ Follicle stimulating hormone (FSH):
Incorrect: FSH can be used to help assess whether a patient is postmenopausal, but levels can fluctuate widely in a perimenopausal patient, making it less accurate. This patient is still having regular periods, which confirms she is not postmenopausal.

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravid woman at 31 weeks’ gestation presents to the OB/GYN clinic with a 2-day history of left calf pain and swelling. The pain is moderate in intensity and has progressively worsened. There is no chest pain, shortness of breath, or recent trauma. Past medical history is significant for chronic hypertension. The pregnancy has been uncomplicated to date. The patient is currently taking prenatal vitamins and labetalol. There is no relevant family history of clotting disorders, and the patient does not smoke. Heart rate is 88/min, and respirations are 18/min. On physical examination, there is notable edema, erythema, and tenderness in the left calf. A thin, cord-like structure is palpable in the popliteal fossa. Which of the following exam findings would best support the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Difference in calf circumference of 2 cm

questions.solution:
In the setting of unilateral calf pain, swelling, erythema, and tenderness, a difference in calf circumference of 2 cm or more is highly suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).     
Venous thromboembolism (VTE), which includes DVT and pulmonary embolism (PE), is a significant concern during pregnancy due to changes in hemodynamics and coagulation, including venous stasis from the gravid uterus and hypercoagulability from elevated estrogen levels. Compared to non-pregnant individuals, thrombi in pregnancy are more often proximal, typically involving the iliac or iliofemoral veins, and more commonly affect the left lower extremity.    

A focused history and physical examination are crucial. Important risk factors for VTE in pregnancy include a personal history of thrombosis, personal or family history of thrombophilia, cesarean delivery, obesity, hypertension, and prolonged immobilization. On physical examination, findings suggestive of DVT can include unilateral leg tenderness, swelling, erythema, and warmth, along with a difference in calf circumference. A palpable, thrombosed vein may occasionally be felt in the popliteal fossa. A portion of the thrombus may embolize to the lungs. A large PE may cause signs of hemodynamic compromise, including tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, and hypoxia. Lung auscultation may reveal rales or diminished breath sounds.    

Option Analysis

✅ Difference in calf circumference of 2 cm  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ 3+ bilateral pitting edema :
Incorrect: Bilateral pitting edema is more commonly associated with systemic conditions such as heart failure, renal disease, or preeclampsia. In contrast, deep vein thrombosis (DVT) typically presents with unilateral findings, as seen in this case. 
❌ Blood pressure of 140/90 mm Hg:
Incorrect: While elevated blood pressure is significant in the context of chronic hypertension or preeclampsia, it is not a specific finding for deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The diagnosis of DVT relies more on localized findings in the affected limb. 
❌ Reduced urine output :
Incorrect: Reduced urine output may suggest renal dysfunction, hypovolemia, or severe hypertensive disorders in pregnancy, but it is not a clinical sign of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). 
❌ Fever:
Incorrect: While a fever can be seen in the setting of venous thromboembolism (the likely diagnosis), it is a non-specific finding. More often, fever indicates an infection or inflammatory process. The patient’s “cord-like structure” in the popliteal fossa is more consistent with deep vein thrombosis (DVT), rather than cellulitis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 8 days after reporting a sexual assault. The patient reports persistent anxiety but no current physical injury. Medical history is unremarkable, and no medications are taken. There is no history of substance use or prior trauma. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient is alert and oriented with no visible injuries. Physical examination reveals mild vaginal erythema without bleeding. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Referral to mental health services for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD)
Empiric treatment for chlamydia, gonorrhea, and trichomonas

questions.solution:
In cases of sexual assault occurring more than 7 days prior, management shifts from immediate post-exposure interventions to addressing potential sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and evaluating the patient for pregnancy. Since prophylactic measures like HIV PEP and emergency contraception are only effective within specific timeframes (72 hours for HIV PEP and 120 hours for emergency contraception), they are not recommended after this period. Instead, patients should be offered comprehensive STI testing and empiric treatment for common pathogens such as chlamydia, gonorrhea, and trichomonas to prevent long-term complications. Additionally, pregnancy testing should be performed, the patient should be assessed for ongoing safety, and support should be provided.    

Effective management of sexual assault involves a stepwise, evidence-based approach that includes immediate medical assessment and treatment of injuries, testing and empiric treatment for STIs and pregnancy, and providing emotional and social support. It also emphasizes the importance of trauma-informed care, patient autonomy, and connecting patients with appropriate mental health and community resources for long-term recovery.    

If the assault occurred recently, patients should be offered HIV PEP, emergency contraception, and a forensic examination, as appropriate. It is also important to discuss mandatory reporting requirements (e.g. abuse in a minor) with the patient, offer support, and comply with all local legal reporting requirements.    

P.S. If you or someone you know has experienced a sexual assault, you can call RAINN National Sexual Assault Telephone Hotline at 800.656.HOPE (4673) or visit https://rainn.org/ to be connected with a trained staff member from a sexual assault service provider in your area.   

Option Analysis

❌ Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV):
Incorrect: HIV PEP must be started within 72 hours of exposure to be effective. At 8 days post-assault, initiation would not provide benefit. 
❌ Referral to mental health services for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD):
Incorrect: Referral to mental health services is essential but not the most urgent next step in this context. Immediate medical management focuses on addressing potential infections and pregnancy risks. 
❌ Emergency contraception:
Incorrect: Emergency contraception is most effective if administered within 120 hours (5 days) of the assault. Because 8 days have passed, it is no longer indicated or effective in preventing pregnancy. Pregnancy testing should be performed, but empiric sexually transmitted infection (STI) treatment is the priority. 
❌ Sexual assault forensic exam:
Incorrect: Most forensic evidence collection protocols recommend performing the exam within 72 hours of the assault. At 8 days, the likelihood of obtaining useful biological evidence is low, though documentation of findings may still be considered. This is not the most appropriate next step in this case. 
✅ Empiric treatment for chlamydia, gonorrhea, and trichomonas:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency room with nausea, vomiting, and severe abdominal pain. The pain began 6 hours ago and has become more severe over the last 2 hours. She noticed vaginal spotting this morning. Past medical history is significant for two rounds of ovulation induction therapy in the past six months. Her last menstrual period was six weeks ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 90/75 mmHg. Abdominal examination reveals tenderness in the right lower quadrant. Transabdominal ultrasound shows free fluid in the pelvis and does not detect an intrauterine gestational sac. Emergency exploratory laparoscopy is performed, and the mesosalpinx is incised to remove the pathological specimen involved. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on histological examination of the specimen?

choices.text: Simple cuboidal epithelium with hair follicles and sebaceous glands

questions.solution:
This patient presented with symptoms of amenorrhea, pelvic pain, vaginal bleeding, and history of ovulation induction therapy. She most likely has a ruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy.    

Ectopic pregnancy is an extrauterine pregnancy and commonly occurs in the uterine tubes. It should be suspected in women of reproductive age with risk factors for a tubal pregnancy, including the previous history of tubal pregnancy, IUD use, sterilization, and history of tubal disease. Laboratory investigations would reveal a rising beta hCG level, and imaging could reveal an extra ovarian adnexal mass/ extrauterine gestational sac on transvaginal ultrasound.    

The fallopian tubes are situated in the upper margin of the broad ligament of the uterus and are divided anatomically into 4 divisions; the infundibulum, the ampulla, the isthmus, and the intramural or interstitial part of the tube. The isthmus forms the medial one-third of the tube. The ampulla forms the lateral two-thirds and is the site of fertilization. The infundibulum forms the lateral end of the uterine tube and is attached to the tubal pole of the ovary.    

Due to its close proximity to the ovary, ovarian torsion or rupture are often considered in the differential diagnosis of an acute abdomen in a woman of reproductive age. However, these differentials are unlikely to cause abnormal vaginal bleeding or amenorrhea. A transvaginal ultrasound can further aid in distinguishing ovarian pathologies from a tubal pregnancy. Ovarian torsion on a pelvic ultrasound would reveal an adnexal mass with the absent flow on a doppler USG.  



Option Analysis

✅ Simple ciliated columnar epithelium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Simple cuboidal epithelium :
Incorrect: Simple cuboidal epithelium covers the epithelial surface of the ovary. Although ovarian torsion would necessitate an oophorectomy, it is unlikely to present with amenorrhea and vaginal bleeding.   
❌ Simple squamous epithelium :
Incorrect: The peritoneum is lined with simple squamous epithelium (mesothelium) and is rarely the site of an ectopic pregnancy.  
❌ Stratified squamous non keratinized epithelium :
Incorrect: The vagina and the ectocervix are lined with stratified squamous non keratinized epithelium and cervical ectopic pregnancies are rare. A tubal ectopic pregnancy is much more likely to be encountered.   
❌ Simple cuboidal epithelium with hair follicles and sebaceous glands :
Incorrect: Mature teratomas on histology reveal simple cuboidal ovarian epithelium with tissues from multiple germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm). They are commonly found in women between the ages of 20-30 and can cause ovarian torsion. Ovarian torsion is unlikely to present with amenorrhea and vaginal bleeding.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, presents to the emergency department at 25 weeks gestation with a severe headache and epigastric pain for the past few hours. She has had no chronic problems, and her pregnancy was uneventful until now. She does not smoke or use alcohol or illicit drugs. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37.33°C (99.2°F), pulse is 58/minute, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg. On physical examination, the patient is uncomfortable and has mild epigastric tenderness. 3+ pitting edema is present in bilateral legs. Fetal heart sounds are normal. Dipstick urine shows 3+ protein. After stabilization, which medications should be administered for blood pressure control in this patient?
questions.solution:
This pregnant woman with a severe headache, epigastric pain, and blood pressure (BP) of ≥140/80, combined with urine dipstick protein of 3+ at ≥20 weeks gestation, is most likely suffering from preeclampsia with severe features. After initial stabilization, this patient's administration of intravenous hydralazine is recommended to control her BP.  

Hydralazine is an antihypertensive drug that works by increasing the level of cGMP in smooth muscle cells, the mechanism of which is not fully understood. It dilates arteries and arterioles more than veins, thereby predominantly reducing afterload. It should be combined with beta-blockers to prevent reflex tachycardia (secondary to systemic arterial dilation). Intravenous hydralazine is indicated in treating acute hypertensive emergencies (e.g,  preeclampsia or hypertension in pregnancy). In contrast, oral hydralazine is used to treat chronic hypertension when other antihypertensive medications are contraindicated or ineffective. In addition, it can be used in combination with nitrates to treat chronic heart failure. Common adverse effects of its use include flushing, headache, edema, angina, drug-induced lupus, and reflex tachycardia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Magnesium sulfate:
Incorrect: Magnesium sulfate is an anti-epileptic drug indicated in patients with severe preeclampsia to prevent seizures and in eclampsia to treat it. It plays no role in lowering blood pressure.  
❌ Lisinopril:
Incorrect: Lisinopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor contraindicated in pregnancy due to its association with fetal renal abnormalities when administered in the second half of pregnancy.  
✅ Hydralazine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Labetalol:
Incorrect: Although labetalol is one of the first-line drugs to manage hypertension in pregnancy, it should be avoided in this patient with bradycardia.  
❌ Nitroprusside:
Incorrect: Although nitroprusside is preferred for managing hyperactive emergencies in non-pregnant individuals, it should be avoided during pregnancy due to its tendency to cause fetal cyanide poisoning.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for evaluation of one week of vaginal discharge and pain with intercourse. She does not have fever or pelvic pain. She has had a new biologically male sexual partner for two months and they do not use condoms. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 144/84 mmHg. Chaperoned vaginal examination reveals a green, frothy vaginal discharge and cervical petechiae. There is no cervical motion tenderness or suprapubic pain. The vaginal pH is 5.1. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient, who has a new sexual partner, presents with dyspareunia and frothy, green vaginal discharge with an elevated vaginal pH. She should have testing for sexually transmitted infections including trichomoniasis.  Nucleic acid amplification testing is highly sensitive and can confirm a diagnosis of trichomoniasis, as well as test for other common sexually transmitted infections such as gonorrhea and chlamydia.    

Vaginal trichomoniasis is primarily diagnosed with saline microscopy or nucleic acid amplification testing.  Rapid, point-of-care tests are also available for detecting Trichomonas vaginalis. Saline microscopy done on a sample of vaginal fluid is cost-effective and can provide an immediate diagnosis if motile trichomonads and many polymorphonuclear white blood cells are seen. However, not all facilities are equipped for this test.  Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) is more expensive and will take longer to receive results, but it is highly sensitive and allows for simultaneous testing for other sexually transmitted infections, candidiasis, and bacterial vaginosis. The vaginal pH can assist in diagnosis as well, as the pH is typically elevated in vaginal trichomoniasis.   

Option Analysis

✅ Nucleic acid amplification testing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Vaginal culture:
Incorrect: Vaginal cultures can detect Trichomonas vaginalis, but these are rarely used for diagnosis, as NAAT testing has higher sensitivity and better detection rates and is therefore the preferred diagnostic test.
❌ Metronidazole therapy:
Incorrect: There is significant overlap in the presentation of sexually transmitted infections, therefore obtaining an accurate diagnosis is important for selection of the correct antibiotic and for partner notification. Empiric treatment should be considered for gonorrhea and chlamydia depending on patient preference, but it is not typically offered as part of the treatment of trichomonas unless there is a known exposure. 
❌ Pelvic ultrasound :
Incorrect: Pelvic ultrasound can be done when there is clinical concern for pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). This patient does not have symptoms or physical exam findings that are concerning for PID. Imaging is not routinely indicated in the management of vaginal trichomoniasis. 
❌ Recommend douching :
Incorrect: Douching is not a treatment for vaginal trichomoniasis, and it actually causes patients to be at higher risk of contracting the infection due to the disruption of normal flora.

questions.text: A 20-year-old biologically female patient presents to the clinic for evaluation of one week of watery vaginal discharge. She has noticed scant vaginal bleeding after vaginal intercourse as well. She has not had abdominal pain, sore throat, difficulty swallowing or fever. She is sexually active with a new partner who is biologically male, and they do not use condoms. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 118/74mmHg. Chaperoned vaginal examination reveals watery discharge without notable odor.  There is no cervical motion tenderness. A cervical swab is collected for nucleic acid amplification testing. Which of the following additional tests should be done at this time?

choices.text: Pharyngeal swab for nucleic acid amplification testing

questions.solution:
This patient’s symptoms of watery vaginal discharge and post-coital bleeding in the setting of having a new sexual partner and lack of use of barrier protection make a sexually transmitted infection such as chlamydia highly likely.  In addition to sending nucleic acid amplification testing, a pregnancy test should always be collected in biologically female patients with reproductive potential who are suspected of having a sexually transmitted infection. Pregnancy status will determine which treatment options are available and the necessary frequency of follow-up testing.    

Chlamydia trachomatis can cause infection in a number of areas of the body including the eyes, pharynx, cervix, vagina, urethra, prostate and epididymis. The gold standard for making a diagnosis is with nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT).  A swab can be collected from the affected area, or first-catch urine can be used in suspected genitourinary infections.  Testing the urine is not as sensitive for detecting infection in biologically female patients, and a patient or provider-collected vaginal or cervical swab is preferred.  In addition to NAAT, all biologically female patients with reproductive potential should have a pregnancy test collected at the time the NAAT is done.    

Because of the high incidence of asymptomatic infections, as well as the potential for long-term consequences in untreated patients, screening should be performed at least yearly in high-risk populations, which includes sexually active women under the age of 25 and men who have sex with men.  Biologically female patients over the age of 25 who have risk factors such as new or multiple sexual partners should also be tested yearly. Screening for chlamydia should be done as part of the routine prenatal care for all pregnant women.   

Option Analysis

✅ Urine pregnancy test:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Vaginal culture:
Incorrect: Vaginal culture was historically used for diagnosis of sexually transmitted infections, but is rarely performed anymore. Rather, nucleic acid amplification tests are used for screening and diagnosis.
❌ KOH test:
Incorrect: A KOH test is useful when evaluating for vaginal candida infections or bacterial vaginosis.  This patient’s sexual history and the nature of her symptoms makes chlamydia and gonorrhea high on the differential. Sending a nucleic acid amplification test for both is the best initial test along with a pregnancy test. 
❌ Pelvic ultrasound:
Incorrect: Pelvic ultrasound is useful when pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is suspected.  Although chlamydia infections can cause PID, this patient does not have symptoms of PID or cervical motion tenderness on exam.  Imaging is not necessary in routine cases of chlamydia infection. 
❌ Pharyngeal swab for nucleic acid amplification testing:
Incorrect: Chlamydia infection can occur in the pharynx and any symptomatic location should be swabbed and sent for nucleic acid amplification testing; however, this patient is not reporting symptoms in the throat, therefore it is reasonable to perform focused testing on the vaginal area only.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician due to significant pain during her menstrual cycles. The patient tells the physician that this started eight months ago and has been interfering with her activities of daily living. After an appropriate workup, the diagnosis of endometriosis is made. The physician decides to start the patient on a medication that has pro-androgenic effects and anti-estrogenic effects. Which of the following is the most likely medication used in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is diagnosed with endometriosis, a condition in which the endometrial gland grows outside the uterine cavity. Many options can be used in treating endometriosis, one of which is danazol.

Danazol is a synthetic androgen with androgen agonist and antagonist effects on estrogen. Danazol suppresses ovarian function through both direct and indirect effects. It directly inhibits ovarian function by inhibiting the ovary's steroidogenesis and indirectly decreases estrogen synthesis by decreasing the production of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) from the pituitary gland. It also has androgenic agonist effects, as it stimulates androgen receptors.

Danazol has been proven to be effective in treating endometriosis. By creating amenorrhea and hypoestrogenism, danazol causes atrophy and regression of the ectopic endometrial tissues. Its use in treating endometriosis has decreased pain and improved fertility.

However, it is not usually used as a first-line treatment option because of its androgenic side effects i.e. acne, voice changes (e.g., deepening of the voice, hoarseness), decreased breast size, and hirsutism. Additionally, it may lead to menstrual irregularities, flushing, and sweating. Sometimes, patients can have nausea, vomiting, and a rise in blood pressure.  

Option Analysis

✅ Danazol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Leuprolide:
Incorrect: Leuprolide is a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist that can sometimes be used to treat endometriosis; it has no androgenic effects.  
❌ Combined oral contraceptive pills:
Incorrect: Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) are the first-line treatment of endometriosis and be efficacious in reducing pain. However, they have no androgenic effects.  
❌ Progestin-only pills:
Incorrect: Progestin-only pills can also be used in treating endometriosis, but they have no androgenic effects.  
❌ Ibuprofen:
Incorrect: NSAIDs are usually used to control pain in endometriosis patients; however, they do not directly influence the hormones in the body.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for evaluation of increased vaginal discharge and an abnormal odor from the vagina, which has been present for one week. There is no associated pelvic pain or fever. The patient has never been sexually active but reports recently trying douching. She is leaving tomorrow to travel for a semester abroad. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, blood pressure is 114/72 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 18/min. Chaperoned vaginal examination reveals a thin, grayish-white, watery discharge with a vaginal pH of 4.7. There is no cervical motion tenderness. Which of the following is the best initial diagnostic test?

choices.text: Diagnosis can be made without further testing

questions.solution:
This patient presents with thin, grayish-white vaginal discharge; an abnormal vaginal odor; and a vaginal pH above 4.5 suggesting bacterial vaginosis. She should have saline microscopy of vaginal fluid done next to evaluate for clue cells along with a KOH whiff test. If >20% clue cells are present on microscopy or the whiff test is positive, then three out of four Amsel criteria would be met and the patient can be diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis. Douching is a risk factor for developing bacterial vaginosis.    

Bacterial vaginosis (BV) can be diagnosed in a number of ways. The use of Amsel criteria is a low-cost and time-efficient method that can be done in the office and involves meeting at least three of the following four criteria: thin, grayish-white vaginal discharge, vaginal pH above 4.5, a positive whiff test, and identification of clue cells on saline microscopy.  

Nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT) and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) are another way to diagnose bacterial vaginosis and are becoming increasingly more popular as they allow simultaneous testing for other microbes and require less office equipment. However, they are more expensive and take longer to provide results. Nugent scoring is a reliable test for BV but requires a Gram stain of the vaginal discharge and is primarily used in research settings. Choice of which test is best depends on patient factors, such as timing and financial concerns as well as consideration of the resources available in the office at the time of the examination. 

Option Analysis

✅ Saline microscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nucleic acid amplification test:
Incorrect: Nucleic acid amplification can be used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis and sexually transmitted infections, but it is much more expensive and takes more time to reach a diagnosis than saline microscopy. This patient has never been sexually active and will be traveling soon, making saline microscopy and the use of the Amsel criteria the best choice for making a prompt diagnosis. 
❌ Culture of vaginal fluid:
Incorrect: Culture of vaginal fluid may show growth of Gardnerella vaginalis, but this is part of normal flora, so culture alone would not be diagnostic for bacterial vaginosis and would take significant time to get back. The percentage of clue cells seen on saline microscopy is more helpful for making a diagnosis and less costly and time consuming. 
❌ Pelvic ultrasound:
Incorrect: Pelvic ultrasound can be performed when there is concern for pelvic inflammatory disease. This patient does not have pelvic pain or cervical motion tenderness and does not report sexual activity, making PID unlikely. Imaging is not indicated for routine cases of bacterial vaginosis. 
❌ Diagnosis can be made without further testing:
Incorrect: In this patient, two of the Amsel criteria are met with the nature of the vaginal discharge and vaginal pH; however, three out of four criteria are needed to make a diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. Therefore, either clue cells on saline microscopy or a positive whiff test is needed to make the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis in this patient.

questions.text: A 35-year-old gravida 2 para 1 woman at 34 weeks gestation comes to her obstetrician for follow-up. She was diagnosed with gestational diabetes mellitus, which is well-controlled with diet modification and metformin. Her past medical history includes asthma, but she does not take any medications for asthma control. Her previous delivery occurred via spontaneous vaginal delivery.  The patient was noted to have placenta previa on ultrasonography at the 28th week of gestation. Repeat ultrasound reveals the placenta in a normal anatomic location and is no longer covering the cervical os. The fetus is positioned in a transverse lie. Which of the following is a contraindication to oxytocin administration for labor induction?
questions.solution:
Oxytocin is a peptide hormone produced by the posterior pituitary that stimulates uterine contractions. Exogenous oxytocin administration is indicated to initiate or facilitate vaginal delivery and treat postpartum hemorrhage.

Oxytocin administration is contraindicated in a few settings. Patients with hypersensitivity to oxytocin cannot receive this medication. In addition, oxytocin is contraindicated in any patient with a contraindication to vaginal delivery. This includes patients with unfavorable fetal position or presentation (e.g. transverse lie or cord presentation), active genital herpes, invasive cervical carcinoma, placenta previa, vasa previa, or cord prolapse.  

Option Analysis

✅ Transverse lie:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Placenta previa:
Incorrect: Although this patient had placenta previa, the placenta has now ascended to its normal anatomic location. This patient has a different contraindication to oxytocin administration.  
❌ Gestational diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Gestational diabetes mellitus is neither a contraindication for vaginal delivery nor oxytocin induction of labor. This patient has a different contraindication to oxytocin administration.  
❌ Asthma:
Incorrect: Asthma is not a contraindication to oxytocin administration. This patient has a different contraindication to oxytocin administration.  
❌ Patient age:
Incorrect: Patient age is not a contraindication for oxytocin administration. This patient has a different contraindication to oxytocin administration.

questions.text: A 28-year-old gravida 2 para 2 woman develops severe vaginal bleeding after delivery. The patient had gestational diabetes mellitus during pregnancy and delivered a 9 lb 3 oz infant. Uterine massage is applied, and oxytocin is administered without hemorrhage control. Three units of packed red blood cells are administered, and she is also provided with dinoprostone. Which of the following side effects are most commonly associated with dinoprostone?
questions.solution:
This patient has developed postpartum hemorrhage likely due to uterine atony. She was administered dinoprostone, a prostaglandin analog.

Prostaglandin analogs like misoprostol (PGE2) and dinoprostone (PGE1) are effective in stimulating uterine contractions for the management of postpartum hemorrhage and in facilitating labor or inducing abortion. They act by stimulating receptors on the uterine smooth muscle. These receptors are coupled with Gq, and once stimulated, they induce the release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, causing muscle contraction.

Side effects of prostaglandin analogs include nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. They can also cause uterine pain and hyperstimulation. Because dinoprostone can stimulate prostaglandin receptors on the smooth muscle of the bronchioles, it can also cause bronchoconstriction and must be avoided in patients with underlying asthma.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Bronchoconstriction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hyponatremia:
Incorrect: Oxytocin can cause hyponatremia if administered excessively or for prolonged periods due to its structural similarity to antidiuretic hormone. However, hyponatremia is not a known side effect of dinoprostone.  
❌ Gastric ulcers:
Incorrect: Gastric ulcers can develop as a side effect of prostaglandin inhibitors. However, dinoprostone is a prostaglandin analog and is protective against gastric ulcers.  
❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: Hypertension is a known side effect of ergonovine; it is not associated with dinoprostone use.  
❌ Venous thromboembolism:
Incorrect: Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic drug that can be used to treat postpartum hemorrhage and can cause venous thromboembolism.

questions.text: A 24-year-old gravida 2 para 1 woman comes to the obstetrician for evaluation of painful uterine contractions. The patient is in the 32<sup>nd</sup> week of gestation. She describes her contractions as regular and increasing in frequency. The patient has a history of preterm delivery in her previous pregnancy. She did not have any complications during this pregnancy. Examination reveals cervical dilation. The physician decides to administer terbutaline. Which of the following is a possible side effect of terbutaline?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with preterm labor, defined as regular uterine contractions before 37 weeks of gestation. Preterm labor carries significant morbidity and mortality to neonates, especially before the 34th week of gestation. Patients with onset of labor before 34 weeks of gestation are administered tocolytics to delay labor and provide time for corticosteroid administration to stimulate fetal lung maturation.

Tocolytics are a group of medications that delay the onset of labor in patients presenting with preterm labor. Specifically, Terbutaline is a beta-agonist that is used for tocolysis. Beta-2 receptors are found in the walls of the uterine smooth muscles. These are Gs protein-coupled receptors and, once activated, induce cyclic AMP formation (cAMP) by activating adenylyl cyclase. Once cAMP is formed, it phosphorylates protein kinase A and deactivates myosin light-chain kinase, inhibiting smooth muscle contraction.

Terbutaline is a selective Beta-2 adrenergic receptor agonist used to delay labor by inhibiting uterine contractions. It is used for short-term tocolysis and uterine tachysystole.

Adverse effects of terbutaline occur secondary to its effects on beta-receptors. In the mother, terbutaline can cause tachycardia, arrhythmias, myocardial ischemia, hypotension, and pulmonary edema. Finally, terbutaline can lead to hyperglycemia and is contraindicated in patients with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Hyperglycemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypoglycemia:
Incorrect: Hyperglycemia, not hypoglycemia, is a known side-effect of terbutaline, as it is a beta-agonist.  
❌ Premature closure of ductus arteriosus:
Incorrect: Closure of ductus arteriosus is a known effect of indomethacin due to inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis, but terbutaline does not affect prostaglandins.  
❌ Gastritis:
Incorrect: Gastritis is a known complication of indomethacin use but is not associated with terbutaline.  
❌ Bradycardia:
Incorrect: Terbutaline is a beta-agonist, leading to tachycardia and tachyarrhythmias, not bradycardia.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 4 para 3, at 7 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department for evaluation of persistent nausea and vomiting. The patient had multiple daily episodes of vomiting during this pregnancy and early in her previous three pregnancies. Her second pregnancy was complicated by preeclampsia. The patient has no other significant past medical history. She is taking a daily prenatal vitamin. The patient smoked cigarettes until her first pregnancy at age 22. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 105/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, blood pressure is 102/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. BMI is 18. Her weight has been increasing appropriately. Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Abdominal exam shows a gravid abdomen appropriate for gestational age. Which of the following is a risk factor for developing the likely underlying condition?

choices.text: History of nausea and vomiting in prior pregnancies

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of nausea and vomiting during pregnancy, which is common and can occur early in pregnancy. The exact cause is unknown, though it is thought to be due to increased human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) associated with early pregnancy, as well as the effects of estrogen and progesterone on the gastrointestinal tract. Known risk factors for the development of this condition include a history of nausea and vomiting in previous pregnancies, having multiple pregnancies, history of migraines or motion sickness, and history of chronic gastrointestinal disorders (e.g. GERD).  

Nausea and vomiting during pregnancy have a wide spectrum of presentations from mild symptoms to severe disease and hyperemesis gravidarum, which may require hospitalization. It is defined as nausea and/or vomiting related to pregnancy. Patients who first experience nausea and vomiting after 10 weeks typically have another cause of their symptoms. The majority of patients experience symptoms between weeks 5-10 of pregnancy with symptoms subsiding by weeks 16-20. Patients can present with nausea, malaise, vomiting, and difficulty tolerating oral intake. On physical examination, patients can have evidence of dehydration including dry mucous membranes, tachycardia, and poor skin turgor; and they may have weight loss. 

Option Analysis

✅ History of nausea and vomiting in prior pregnancies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Single gestation:
Incorrect: Multiple gestation and not single gestation is associated with an increased risk of developing nausea and vomiting during pregnancy. 
❌ History of preeclampsia :
Incorrect: A history of preeclampsia is not a significant predictor of developing nausea and vomiting during pregnancy. Known risk factors include a history of migraines, multiple gestations, and history of acid reflux or other gastrointestinal disorders.
❌ Smoking history :
Incorrect: Smoking history is not a significant predictor of developing nausea and vomiting during pregnancy. Smoking is associated with low birth weight, preterm birth, and placental complications (like placenta previa and abruption).
❌ Low body mass index:
Incorrect: Body mass index does not correlate with developing nausea and vomiting of pregnancy. Low BMI is associated with preterm birth and delivering a baby with low birth weight. It may increase the risk of intrauterine growth restriction and potential developmental delays in the infant.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, at 8 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department for evaluation of persistent nausea and vomiting for one week. The patient has been taking pyridoxine and doxylamine for her symptoms without relief, and she cannot tolerate oral intake of solids or liquids. She has no abdominal pain or urinary symptoms. The patient has a past medical history of migraines for which she takes acetaminophen. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 111/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, blood pressure is 102/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Current weight is 118 pounds. Pre-pregnancy weight was 125 pounds. Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes and poor skin turgor. Abdominal and cardiopulmonary examinations are within normal limits. Which of the following additional findings would indicate hyperemesis gravidarum?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of nausea and vomiting during pregnancy, which is a common condition that exists on a spectrum, from mild disease to the most severe form known as hyperemesis gravidarum. While there is no consensus definition of demarcating hyperemesis gravidarum from milder forms of nausea and vomiting during pregnancy, common criteria for diagnosis include persistent vomiting accompanied by weight loss exceeding 5 percent of pre-pregnancy body weight and ketonuria unrelated to other causes. In this patient with persistent vomiting and weight loss of 5.6% of pre-pregnancy weight, the presence of ketonuria would indicate hyperemesis gravidarum.   

Patients with mild nausea and vomiting during pregnancy typically have intermittent nausea and/or vomiting, normal vital signs, and normal physical and laboratory examinations. Milder forms of the disease do not typically require pharmacologic therapy and can be managed with lifestyle modifications. Patients with moderate nausea and vomiting during pregnancy typically have persistent nausea with vomiting and may need pharmacotherapy to help them tolerate fluid and food intake.  

Patients with severe symptoms demonstrate persistent nausea and vomiting, are often unable to tolerate oral intake, and on physical examination can have signs of dehydration including dry mucous membranes, poor skin turgor, and orthostatic hypotension. They can also experience weight loss. Patients with hyperemesis gravidarum may have electrolyte abnormalities including hypokalemia, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, and ketonuria. Patients with hyperemesis gravidarum typically require hospitalization for initiation of pharmacotherapy, rehydration, and electrolyte repletion. 

Option Analysis

✅ Ketones on urinalysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Transaminitis:
Incorrect: Transaminitis can be seen in hospitalized pregnant patients with hyperemesis. However, it can be caused by other pregnancies and non-pregnancy-related causes and is not considered part of the criteria for hyperemesis gravidarum.
❌ Hypomagnesemia:
Incorrect: Hypomagnesemia is more commonly identified in patients with diarrhea. It is not considered part of the criteria for hyperemesis gravidarum.
❌ Nitrite on urinalysis:
Incorrect: The presence of urine nitrite is highly suggestive of a urinary tract infection, which more commonly presents with dysuria, hematuria, or associated flank pain in the setting of ascending infection/pyelonephritis. 
❌ Elevated blood urea nitrogen:
Incorrect: An elevated BUN can be seen in nausea and vomiting during pregnancy with dehydration. However, it can be caused by other pregnancies and non-pregnancy-related causes and is not considered part of the criteria for hyperemesis gravidarum.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is seen for routine evaluation. The patient feels well. She has been sexually active with one male partner in a monogamous relationship for the last year and has been previously treated for human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. She has no other significant medical history. She is currently a resident at a correctional facility. She smokes one pack of cigarettes per day but does not regularly consume alcohol or use recreational drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 120/82 mmHg, respiratory rate is 18/min, and pulse is 84/min. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following would be an indication to screen this patient for trichomoniasis?
questions.solution:
This sexually active female who is under the age of 25 should be offered appropriate screening for sexually transmitted infections (STIs) as part of a well-check. Patient risk factors determine which tests are indicated. For non-pregnant women without HIV, gonorrhea, and chlamydia, screening should be done annually in all sexually active patients who are less than 25 years old, and in sexually active patients 25 years of age or older who are at increased risk for infection. Trichomonas screening is recommended in patients who are in high-prevalence settings, such as STI clinics and correctional facilities; and for asymptomatic patients at high risk for infection, such as those with multiple sex partners, those who engage in transactional sex or drug use, or those who have a history of STIs or HIV.  

STI screening should be considered in all patients. Factors from the history and physical examination will determine which, if any, tests are indicated. Primary factors to consider are the patient’s age, pregnancy status, HIV status, sexual practices, known exposure to an STI, and symptoms.  When a possible exposure has occurred, important details to gather include timing of sexual exposure, previous screenings or treatment results, and partner’s treatment status.    

The physical examination also plays an important role in determining what tests are indicated.  Cervical or urethral discharge as well as genital lesions should prompt further conversation about possible STI exposures and testing. STIs should be included in the differential for skin rashes as well, as secondary syphilis can cause a variety of skin lesions and rashes that may mimic other conditions.  



Rash on the palms of both hands due to secondary syphilis from Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is licensed under public domain. Accessed 12/26/2023. Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

✅ Residence in a correctional facility :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Age:
Incorrect: Routine screening for sexually transmitted infections (STIs) like gonorrhea and chlamydia is recommended for sexually active patients under the age of 25. However, trichomoniasis is not included in the list of diseases for which women under 25 years of age should be regularly screened.
❌ History of HPV infection:
Incorrect: HPV status does not affect the recommendation for screening for trichomoniasis.
❌ Monogamous sexual partner:
Incorrect: This patient has one sexual partner in a monogamous relationship and does not meet criteria to be screened for trichomoniasis based on this fact. Patients at high risk of infection should be screened, which includes having multiple sexual partners.
❌ Tobacco use:
Incorrect: Screening for trichomoniasis is indicated for asymptomatic women at high risk for the infection, such as those who use recreational drugs.  Tobacco use is not considered a high-risk activity for contracting this infection.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for passing clots and experiencing fevers and chills for two days. The patient delivered a healthy baby girl one week ago via cesarean section at 38 weeks gestation. The patient has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 100/67 mmHg, pulse is 98/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals a well-healing Pfannenstiel incision without overlying tenderness or drainage. Bimanual exam reveals moderate uterine tenderness and malodorous vaginal discharge. Urinalysis is negative. Laboratory studies are shown below. The patient is admitted to the obstetric unit and given ceftriaxone, doxycycline, and metronidazole. On day three of hospitalization, the patient reports worsening pelvic pain with continued passage of large clots, and she had persistent fevers. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

Laboratory value
Result
Hemoglobin
9.8  g/dL
Hematocrit
35 %
Leukocyte count
21,100 /mm3
Platelet count
256,000/mm3
aPTT
35 s
PT/INR
1.5
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation for secondary postpartum hemorrhage. The findings of malodorous vaginal discharge, fever, and uterine tenderness are highly suggestive of endometritis. The patient was started on appropriate empiric antibiotic therapy. However, there has been no improvement in her condition. When patients with suspected endometritis fail to improve despite appropriate antibiotic therapy, they should have a pelvic ultrasound to evaluate for the presence of retained placenta membranes/tissue.

For patients like this one with secondary postpartum hemorrhage, history, examination, and lab work should be performed to determine the cause. Blood work may show an elevated white blood cell count with endometritis or abnormal coagulation studies with coagulopathy. If coagulopathy is suspected, confirmatory genetic testing can be performed. If the examination is inconsistent with uncomplicated endometritis or if the patient worsens on treatment, they should have ultrasonography to evaluate for retained products of conception. When findings are inconclusive for more common causes of delayed postpartum hemorrhage, subinvolution of the placental site, neoplasia, vascular malformation or hypoestrogenism should be considered.  

Option Analysis

✅ Pelvic ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Genetic testing:
Incorrect: This patient has a normal coagulation profile, making an inherited coagulopathy unlikely. This patient treated for suspected endometritis who continues to have fever, pain, and passage of clots should be evaluated with pelvic ultrasound for associated retained placental tissue.
❌ MRI pelvis:
Incorrect: MRI pelvis is not indicated in the diagnostic workup for delayed postpartum hemorrhage. Pelvic ultrasound should be the first imaging study performed on this patient who is not improving on antibiotics for presumptive endometritis.  
❌ Estrogen level testing:
Incorrect: Hypoestrogenism is a rare cause of delayed postpartum hemorrhage. Once more common etiologies (e.g. retained products of conception) have been ruled out, it is reasonable to assess for less common causes of delayed postpartum hemorrhage.  
❌ Hysterectomy:
Incorrect: Hysterectomy should be considered as a treatment for severe refractory postpartum hemorrhage, only when all other medical modalities have failed.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of malodorous vaginal discharge. The patient reports discharge with an unpleasant fishy smell that is more prominent after vaginal intercourse. Review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory, and she takes no medications. The patient is sexually active with one male partner and has a copper-containing intrauterine device. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a thin, gray discharge that coats the vaginal walls. No erythema or edema is present on the vaginal walls or vulva. There is no cervical or adnexal tenderness. On saline wet-mount examination, clue cells are seen, and no white blood cells or motile organisms are seen. Which is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of gray vaginal discharge with a fishy odor in combination with clue cells on microscopy and the absence of vulvovaginal inflammation is most likely due to overgrowth of the anaerobic bacterium Gardnerella vaginalis leading to bacterial vaginosis (BV). Treatment of symptomatic BV is either metronidazole or clindamycin, regardless of the pregnancy status.  

Clindamycin is a lincosamide that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by blocking the peptide transfer (translocation) at the 50S ribosomal subunit. It is bacteriostatic and can be given perorally, parenterally, or as a topical cream. It is mainly used to treat anaerobic bacterial infections of the oropharynx (e.g. dental abscess) and lungs (e.g. aspiration, abscess), as its spectrum of activity covers Bacteroides, Clostridium perfringens and invasive group A Streptococcus. It can also treat BV. Common side effects include gastrointestinal distress (e.g., nausea, vomiting, diarrhea), the reversible elevation of aspartate aminotransferase and alanine aminotransferase, and skin rashes. Clindamycin use can also cause bacterial superinfection by Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile leading to pseudomembranous colitis. Mechanisms of resistance include methylation of the binding site on the 50S ribosomal subunit and enzymatic inactivation.



Option Analysis

❌ Fluconazole:
Incorrect: Fluconazole is used to manage vulvovaginal candidiasis, which usually presents with thick white vaginal discharge and pseudohyphae seen on microscopy. Predisposing risk factors like corticosteroid use, antibiotic use, or diabetes mellitus are typically present.
✅ Clindamycin:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Acyclovir:
Incorrect: Acyclovir can treat herpes simplex virus infection, which usually presents with painful genital ulcers and not vaginal discharge.
❌ Benzathine penicillin G:
Incorrect: Benzathine penicillin G can be used to manage syphilis, which may present with painless genital lesions (e.g., chancre or condyloma lata). Syphilis does not cause vaginal discharge.
❌ Azithromycin:
Incorrect: Azithromycin is effective against Chlamydia trachomatis cervicitis, which can present with malodorous vaginal discharge. Microscopy, however, shows numerous white blood cells rather than clue cells.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the urgent care clinic with a two-week history of dysuria. The patient has also experienced a sore throat, difficulty swallowing, vaginal pruritus, and vaginal discharge. She is sexually active and has had two different male sexual partners in the past four weeks. She does not use condoms. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.3°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 122/79 mmHg. Examination of the oropharynx reveals erythema and cervical lymphadenopathy without pharyngeal exudates. Speculum examination reveals an edematous, friable cervix with mucopurulent discharge. Urine hCG pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation?
questions.solution:
This sexually active 23-year-old woman presents with evidence of pharyngitis and cervicitis with mucopurulent discharge after unprotected sexual intercourse. This constellation of findings is suggestive of gonorrhea, an infection caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The first step in the evaluation of patients with suspected N. gonorrhoeae infections is to perform nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT).

Sexually active biological females presenting with signs and symptoms of cervicitis (as in this case), or with other symptoms suggestive of gonorrhea, should have nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) for diagnosis. This can be performed using self-collected or provider-collected specimens from affected areas (e.g., endocervical swab, first-void urine collection, pharyngeal swab, vaginal swab). NAAT is the most sensitive and preferred diagnostic test for both genital and extragenital gonorrhea infections in males and females. Advantages of NAAT include rapid results, the ability to test asymptomatic patients, and its high sensitivity. Alternatively, samples can be sent for gram stain and culture, which was once the gold standard for diagnosis, but this method is less sensitive than NAAT. It does offer the advantage of antibiotic susceptibility testing if treatment resistance is a concern.

Of note, the majority of gonococcal infections are asymptomatic, particularly in biologically female patients, and annual screening is recommended for high-risk populations, including females under the age of 25 and males who have sex with males.  

Option Analysis

✅ Nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT)  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Complete blood count (CBC):
Incorrect: A CBC may be helpful in assessing a patient with suspected gonococcemia, but it is not useful in the initial evaluation of a patient presenting with acute gonococcal infection. Nucleic acid amplification testing is the preferred diagnostic test for N. gonorrhoeae.  
❌ Gonorrhea culture:
Incorrect: Gonorrhea culture is rarely done, and nucleic acid amplification testing is the preferred diagnostic test for N. gonorrhoeae. Culture may be helpful if resistance is a concern.  
❌ Urinalysis:
Incorrect: A urinalysis can be used to diagnose urinary tract infections, which typically present with dysuria. However, this is not the first step in diagnosing a woman with suspected N. gonorrhoeae infection. Nucleic acid amplification testing is the preferred diagnostic test for N. gonorrhoeae.  
❌ Wet mount microscopy:
Incorrect: Wet mount microscopy is a diagnostic tool used for certain vaginal infections, including bacterial vaginosis or trichomoniasis. However, this patient’s symptoms and examination are more consistent with gonorrhea and nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) should be performed.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, comes to the physician for a routine follow-up six weeks after an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The patient has no active complaints at this visit but would like to discuss contraception. Past medical history is noncontributory, and the patient takes no medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. After discussing the risks and benefits of multiple contraceptive options, the patient elects to start depot medroxyprogesterone. The patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Depot medroxyprogesterone is an injectable, progestin-only contraceptive that provides highly effective, reversible contraception for three months. It causes menstrual irregularities such as prolonged bleeding or spotting, especially during the first six months of use. Medroxyprogesterone is a synthetic progestogen called progestin.  Progestins can be divided into two groups: the progesterone derivatives and the testosterone derivatives.

Progestins suppress ovulation by inhibiting the release of gonadotropin-releasing hormone from the hypothalamus, induce atrophic changes in the endometrium, and thicken the cervical mucus. While they can stabilize the endometrium, they can’t support pregnancy effectively as endogenous progesterone does.

Common indications include:
 
  • Contraception, either alone or in combination with an estrogen 
  • Used in combination with estrogen in hormone replacement therapy after menopause in women with an intact uterus to prevent endometrial hyperplasia or endometrial cancer 
  • Diagnosis and treatment of various gynecological conditions such as secondary amenorrhea, abnormal uterine bleeding, and endometriosis. 
Side effects associated with progestins include fatigue, mood changes, menstrual irregularities, edema, vaginal dryness or atrophy, headaches, nausea, breast tenderness, and decreased libido. Progestins with androgenic activity can also cause acne, hirsutism, seborrhea, voice deepening, changes in liver protein production, and weight gain.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Menstrual irregularities:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Type 2 diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Although estrogen oral contraceptive pills have shown to increase the risk of glucose intolerance, progestins have not been linked to the development of type 2 diabetes mellitus.  
❌ Breast cancer:
Incorrect: The data for progestin-only contraceptives are inadequate to make a definitive conclusion regarding the risk of breast cancer.  
❌ Endometrial hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Progestins reverse endometrial hyperplasia via activation of progesterone receptors, which results in stromal decidualization and subsequent thinning of the endometrium. It is used to prevent endometrial hyperplasia and cancer by mitigating the effect of estrogen on the endometrium.  
❌ Migraine headaches:
Incorrect: Estrogen therapy often improves both symptoms for women with hot flashes and estrogen-associated migraines (which typically worsen during perimenopause). Migraine headaches (with or without aura) are not a complication of progestin therapy.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 7 weeks 3 days of gestation by last menstrual period (LMP) comes to the emergency department with a three-day history of intermittent vaginal bleeding and worsening pelvic and low back pain. Past medical history is notable for polycystic ovary syndrome with irregular menstrual cycles, ranging from 25 to 45 days in length, and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. The patient’s previous pregnancy was uncomplicated and resulted in a vaginal delivery at term. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 110/72 mmHg. On exam, a small trickle of dark blood is coming from a closed external cervical os, and there is no significant uterine tenderness. A urine human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is positive. The ultrasound shows an intrauterine gestational sac with a fetal pole measuring 6 mm from crown to rump without evidence of cardiac activity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Ultrasound in one to two weeks

questions.solution:
This pregnant patient with a history of irregular menstrual cycles presents at 7 weeks 3 days gestation by LMP with vaginal bleeding, cramping, a closed cervical os, and ultrasound findings of a 6 mm crown-rump length (CRL) without cardiac activity. She is experiencing a threatened miscarriage (also referred to as threatened pregnancy loss or a threatened abortion), and because she is hemodynamically stable, the patient should be managed expectantly with a repeat ultrasound in one to two weeks.  

A threatened miscarriage is characterized by bleeding and/or cramping in the first half of pregnancy with a closed cervical os on exam and without confirmed sonographic evidence of pregnancy loss. In a fetus that measures at least 7 mm from crown to rump, cardiac activity should be present; if the fetus is less than 7 mm, as seen in this patient, cardiac activity may or may not be present yet. If pregnancy loss cannot be confirmed, the patient may still have a viable, early pregnancy that could develop normally. In addition, it is also important to note that patients with a history of irregular menstrual cycles may have an inaccurate gestational age by LMP, so expectations of fetal sizing by dates may not be accurate.  

Expectant management is appropriate for patients with a threatened miscarriage who are hemodynamically stable. However, the patient will need a follow-up ultrasound within one to two weeks to either confirm fetal viability or diagnose pregnancy loss.  



Option Analysis

✅ Ultrasound in one to two weeks:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pelvic magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):
Incorrect: Ultrasound is the preferred imaging modality in pregnancy. A pelvic MRI may be obtained in pregnancy to better characterize atypical uterine anatomy; however, it would not provide additional details in this case.
❌ Intravenous ampicillin, gentamicin, and clindamycin:
Incorrect: Antibiotics are used in the treatment of septic miscarriage, which is characterized by fever, tachycardia, hypertension, purulent drainage from the cervix, and uterine tenderness on exam. A single dose of pre-operative antibiotics may also be given in patients with early pregnancy loss who undergo surgical management. This stable patient’s threatened miscarriage should be managed expectantly with repeat ultrasound in one to two weeks.
❌ Misoprostol:
Incorrect: Misoprostol +/- mifepristone is an appropriate management option for patients with confirmed pregnancy loss. However, this patient may still have a viable, early pregnancy: her menstrual cycles are irregular, so her gestational age by LMP may be inaccurate. Pregnancy loss is confirmed if the crown-rump length (CRL) is at least 7 mm with no detectable heartbeat.
❌ Type and crossmatch:
Incorrect: A type and crossmatch is indicated in patients who are hemodynamically unstable and may require a blood transfusion. This patient is clinically stable, so a simple blood type with Rh status would be appropriate.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents to the primary care office requesting contraception. She is planning to begin a three-month treatment with terbinafine for toenail fungus and needs a reliable method of pregnancy prevention while taking this medication. The patient would like to continue the contraception for one year while she completes graduate school and then plans to try to conceive a child after finishing. Her last menstrual period was two weeks ago. She has never had a sexually transmitted infection and has no chronic medical conditions. She smokes one pack of cigarettes per day. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 73/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 126/82 mmHg, and BMI is 22 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. She is awake and alert on examination, and in no distress. A pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate form of contraception for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is over the age of 35 and smokes cigarettes, making the use of combined hormonal contraception unsafe in any form. A copper IUD is a highly effective, non-hormonal method of contraception that will also allow the patient to return to fertility immediately after removal, making it the best option for this patient.

There are many options available for patients who desire reversible contraception, including hormonal and non-hormonal methods. Hormonal methods may contain a combination of estrogen and progestin, or progestin alone, and can be administered in a variety of ways including via pill, patch, vaginal ring, topical gel, implant, injection, and IUD. Advantages to combined hormonal contraception include regular, lighter, and shorter menses, reduced menstrual cramps, and decreased risk of uterine, ovarian, and colon cancer. Disadvantages vary by method. Contraindications to combined hormonal contraception include migraines with aura, hypertension, tobacco use, breast cancer, undiagnosed abnormal uterine bleeding, and acute liver disease.
