A high PVR volume of urine (typically defined as > 150 mL) strongly supports the diagnosis. When the bladder is extremely full, symptoms of stress and/or urgency urinary incontinence (UI) can occur as well. 

The evaluation of UI should include a focused history and exam, urinalysis and culture, measurement of the PVR volume, and a cough stress test. On history, the frequency, volume, and symptoms associated with voiding and UI episodes should be carefully assessed. Using a validated incontinence questionnaire and/or having the patient complete a voiding diary can also be helpful.    

Option Analysis

✅ Postvoid residual volume of 200 mL:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Positive urine culture:
Incorrect: A positive urine culture is unlikely given the negative leukocyte esterase and negative nitrites on urinalysis. This patient’s results are more suggestive of poorly controlled diabetes, which may result in neuropathy leading to overflow incontinence and an elevated postvoid residual volume. 
❌ Urethral mobility of 45 degrees:
Incorrect: Urethral hypermobility (defined as displacement of the urethra-bladder neck angle by ≥ 30 degrees with Valsalva maneuver) is seen with stress urinary incontinence. However, this patient’s history is more consistent with overflow rather than stress incontinence. 
❌ Positive cough stress test:
Incorrect: A cough stress test is considered positive when urine leakage is visualized from the urethra with a cough. It is seen with stress urinary incontinence. However, this patient’s history is more consistent with overflow rather than stress incontinence. 
❌ Large fibroid uterus:
Incorrect: A large fibroid uterus may lead to bladder outlet obstruction and symptoms of overflow incontinence. Although this patient’s presentation is most consistent with overflow incontinence, fibroids are stimulated by estrogen and rarely grow (and more often involute) after menopause. Therefore, diabetic neuropathy and not fibroids is the most probable cause of overflow incontinence in this patient.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, presents with a 6-month history of worsening urinary incontinence. She experiences a sudden, strong urge to void and leaks a large volume of urine if she does not void within 30 to 60 seconds. She does not typically leak when she coughs or sneezes. When she voids, she has no hesitancy or postvoid dribbling, and she has a strong urine stream. Medical history is notable for two uncomplicated vaginal births. She has regular monthly menstrual cycles and no history of sexually transmitted infections or abnormal cervical cancer screening. Vital signs are within normal limits. An examination demonstrates 1 to 2 cm of apical and anterior vaginal wall prolapse but no observed urine leakage with Valsalva maneuver. The vagina and cervix appear normal, and the uterus and adnexa are non-tender and normal in size and shape. The urinalysis and urine culture are negative, and a postvoid residual volume is 30 mL. In addition to pelvic floor physical therapy and behavior modification, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with urinary incontinence that occurs after a sudden, intense urge to void which is consistent with urgency urinary incontinence (UUI). First-line management includes pelvic floor physical therapy, behavioral modification, and, if desired by the patient, pharmacotherapy with an antimuscarinic or beta-3-adrenergic agent. These medications reduce the detrusor overactivity that leads to UUI.

Treatment of urinary incontinence should follow a stepwise approach, considering the severity of symptoms, medical comorbidities, and patient preferences. Most patients with urinary incontinence will benefit from pelvic floor exercises that can assist in suppressing urgency and improving pelvic floor strength and continence. Patients with UUI should also remove bladder irritants from the diet, such as alcohol, caffeine, and acidic foods. Additionally, smoking cessation and healthy weight loss in individuals with obesity have been shown to reduce incontinence episodes. Bladder training with timed voiding may also provide some benefit.

If these interventions do not provide adequate relief of UUI, or if the patient prefers to initiate pharmacologic therapy concurrently with conservative approaches, a medication that inhibits detrusor contractions should be added. Options include antimuscarinic agents, such as oxybutynin, and beta-3-adrenergic agonists, such as mirabegron.
 
  

Option Analysis

✅ Antimuscarinic agent:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intravaginal estrogen:
Incorrect: Topical estrogen therapy is unlikely to be beneficial in a premenopausal patient, who naturally makes significantly higher levels of estrogen than those contained in topical preparations. 
❌ Pessary:
Incorrect: Pessaries are considered first-line non-surgical management of stress urinary incontinence (SUI) with pelvic organ prolapse. Unlike the patient in the vignette, SUI presents with urine loss after sudden increases in intrabdominal pressure (e.g., cough, sneeze). 
❌ Mid-urethral sling:
Incorrect: A mid-urethral sling is a long-term treatment option for patients with stress urinary incontinence (SUI) who desire definitive surgical management. Unlike the patient in the vignette, SUI presents with urine loss after sudden increases in intrabdominal pressure (e.g., cough, sneeze). 
❌ Sacral nerve stimulation:
Incorrect: An electrical stimulation device can be implanted to stimulate the sacral nerves in patients with urgency and overflow incontinence. However, in patients with urgency urinary incontinence, sacral nerve stimulation is only considered if pharmacotherapy with antimuscarinic and beta-3-adrenergic agonists is unsuccessful.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presents to the gynecologist’s office for evaluation of vulvar itching for three months. Over the same time, she has noticed raised areas on the skin of the vulva. She has used multiple courses of topical over-the-counter antifungal medications thinking it could be a yeast infection. However, there has been no improvement in symptoms. Past medical history is significant for a colposcopy done for abnormal cervical cytology and human papillomavirus (HPV) detected on a pap smear ten years ago. The biopsy taken from colposcopy returned cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) 2 that required a loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP) and more frequent pap smears. She has also been treated once for chlamydia and has a history of uterine leiomyomas. Vital signs are within normal limits. Chaperoned examination of the vulva reveals several small skin-colored raised lesions. Biopsy of the lesions shows atypical koliocytes in the upper layers of the epithelium. Which of the following is the greatest risk factor for the patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient's chronic vulvar irritation, findings of raised skin-colored vulvar lesions on exam, and atypical koliocytes on biopsy are consistent with low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL), which is a type of vulvar dysplasia. Most cases of LSIL are associated with prior HPV infection. Additional risk factors for LSIL include tobacco use and immunodeficiency.

Vulvar dysplasia includes a group of benign vulvar lesions (most commonly LSIL) and premalignant vulvar lesions (HSIL and differentiated vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia). Patients with vulvar dysplasia may experience pruritis or chronic irritation in the area. However, a sizable portion of patients are asymptomatic, and lesions are incidentally noted during examination. Abnormal pap smear cytology without a corresponding abnormality on diagnostic cervical biopsy should also prompt investigation for pathology of the vagina and vulva as these areas can be the source of the abnormal cells seen on pap smear.

Condylomata acuminata or genital warts are the most generic form of LSIL. In general, the diagnosis of condylomata acuminate can be made without a biopsy and topical medications can be started empirically. However, if patients have findings of condyloma acuminate and are postmenopausal or if the lesions do not respond to treatment, then a biopsy is needed. Biopsy of LSIL will reveal atypical koilocytes in the upper layers of the epithelium. LSILs are not precursors to cancer and should not be considered premalignant. Most LSILs are caused by HPV.

High-grade vulvar intraepithelial lesions (HSILs), however, are precancerous. HSILs are typically localized and well isolated with a raised, slightly rough texture. They are generally found on the posterior, hairless area of the vulva and perineal body, but can occur anywhere. Colposcopy findings on HSILs can include leukoplakia or hyperpigmentation, along with an atypical vascular pattern. Biopsy results will show cytologic atypia from two-thirds to full thickness of the epithelium, without invasion.

Option Analysis

✅ Prior human papilloma virus (HPV) infection:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Inadequate vulvar cleansing:
Incorrect: There are many over-the-counter hygiene products, including vaginal sprays, washes, douches, perfumes, and deodorants. In general, they are not recommended as they can cause significant vulvar irritation. While this patient does have vulvar irritation, her exam and biopsy findings are consistent with vulvar dysplasia, which is not caused by inadequate vulvar cleansing but can be caused by HPV infection. 
❌ History of chlamydia:
Incorrect: Chlamydia and HPV are both spread through sexual contact; however, chlamydia is not a risk factor for the development of vulvar dysplasia. HPV infection increases the risk for vulvar dysplasia.  
❌ Uterine leiomyomas:
Incorrect: Symptomatic uterine leiomyomas can cause various issues, such as heavy bleeding and pelvic pressure or pain. Leiomyomas are not associated with HPV and do not cause vulvar irritation or vulvar lesions. 
❌ Over-the-counter topical antifungal medication:
Incorrect: While some patients may experience rash as a side effect of topical antifungal medications, biopsy results of this patient’s skin lesions are consistent with vulvar dysplasia. HPV is associated with an increased risk of vulvar dysplasia.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, presents to labor and delivery at 32 weeks estimated gestational age (EGA) with sudden-onset lower abdominal pain and cramping that began four hours ago. The symptoms have not resolved with rest and hydration at home. She reports an episode of spotting, and she feels less fetal movement than she usually does this time of day. This pregnancy is complicated by a velamentous umbilical cord insertion and gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) controlled with insulin. Past medical history is notable for two prior low transverse cesarean births. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 184/94 mmHg. On examination, the patient is alert, oriented, conversant, and lungs are clear on auscultation bilaterally. The uterus is mildly tender to palpation, firm, and has a smooth anterior contour. Vaginal examination reveals intact fetal membranes and a closed cervix. A non-stress test shows a baseline fetal heart rate (FHR) of 135/min; minimal variability; occasional late decelerations; and high frequency, low amplitude contractions. Which of the following patient factors most likely led to the acute condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with painful vaginal bleeding and uterine irritability after 20 weeks EGA can be diagnosed with a placental abruption. Findings such as risk factors, characteristic fetal monitoring patterns, and lab and ultrasound findings can support the diagnosis. One of the most significant risk factors for placental abruption is hypertensive disorders of pregnancy, which the patient in the vignette meets criteria for based on her severely elevated blood pressure. Other risk factors for abruption include abdominal trauma, advanced maternal age, leiomyomas, prelabor rupture of membranes, and tobacco or cocaine use. 

Placental abruption refers to the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall due to rupture of the maternal vessels within the basal layer of the uterus. This can lead to bleeding from the placental attachment site, typically causing abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. Uterine irritability or hypertonicity, high frequency-low amplitude contractions, and non-reassuring fetal heart rate patterns are also common. However, it is possible for an abruption to occur in the center of the placenta, where the blood loss is fully concealed behind the placenta and the patient does not experience vaginal bleeding.   

Option Analysis

✅ Elevated blood pressure:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Gestational diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: GDM is a risk factor for macrosomia, shoulder dystocia, polyhydramnios, hypertensive disorders of pregnancy, and stillbirth. However, GDM is not a significant risk factor for placental abruption, which is the most likely diagnosis in this vignette.  
❌ Past cesarean births:
Incorrect: A history of prior cesarean birth(s) is the most significant risk factor for uterine rupture, which can also present with painful uterine bleeding. However, placental abruption is more likely in this patient given that the symptoms started spontaneously at 32 weeks in the setting of severely elevated blood pressures (a major risk factor for abruption) rather than during labor, which is when uterine rupture is most likely to occur. 
❌ Multiparity:
Incorrect: On its own, multiparity is not significantly associated with placental abruption. However, abruption is more likely in patients with advanced maternal age, who are often multiparous. 
❌ Velamentous umbilical cord insertion:
Incorrect: Velamentous umbilical cord insertion refers to umbilical vessels that insert into the placenta without the protection of Wharton’s jelly. These vessels are directly attached to the chorion and can rupture when the membranes rupture, leading to rapid fetal exsanguination and painless, rather than painful, bleeding.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 41 weeks estimated gestational age (EGA) presents for an elective late-term induction of labor (IOL). She has no contractions, loss of fluid, vaginal bleeding, or decreased fetal movement. The pregnancy has been uncomplicated, and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. She has a history of term vaginal birth following spontaneous labor. Vital signs are within normal limits. On exam, the abdomen is gravid and non-tender; the cervix is in a mid-position, 1 cm dilated, 50% effaced, and at –1 cm station. The baseline fetal heart rate is 140/min. Chart review shows a fundal placenta, and the clinician determines there are no contraindications to IOL. Which of the following additional pieces of information will be most helpful in determining the need for cervical ripening in this patient?
questions.solution:
When a patient presents for induction of labor (IOL), it is important to assess how favorable the cervix is for the procedure. Cervical favorability is determined by calculating the Bishop score, which is based on cervical dilation, effacement, position, and consistency, and the station of the presenting fetal part.

To calculate the Bishop score, points are assigned to each of the five parameters (outlined in the table below) and added together to determine the final score. An unfavorable cervix is defined as a Bishop score of 6 or less. When the cervix is unfavorable, cervical ripening is indicated to improve the chance of a successful IOL within 24 hours. If the Bishop score is 7 or higher, the cervix is favorable, and IOL can be started with oxytocin and/or membrane rupture, without cervical ripening.
 

The patient in this vignette has 1 point for dilation, 1 for position, 1 for effacement, and 2 for station. With knowledge of cervical consistency, a final Bishop score can be calculated and the most appropriate initial management determined.

Option Analysis

✅ Cervical consistency:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Amniotic fluid volume:
Incorrect: The need for cervical ripening is typically based on the bishop score, which is calculated entirely from findings on the cervical exam. If the amniotic fluid volume is low (i.e., oligohydramnios), there is a higher chance of fetal intolerance to labor. However, this does not directly impact the need for cervical ripening. 
❌ Fetal position:
Incorrect: Fetal position refers to the orientation of the presenting fetal part in relation to the maternal pelvis. A similar term, fetal lie, refers to the orientation of the fetus compared to the maternal spine (e.g., longitudinal, transverse, oblique); a transverse fetal lie is a contraindication to vaginal birth and IOL. However, because the vignette states there are no contraindications to IOL, the specific position is irrelevant when determining the initial IOL management. 
❌ Clinical pelvimetry:
Incorrect: Clinical pelvimetry refers to assessment of the pelvic shape and relevant diameters of the bony pelvis that a fetus must pass through during the birth process. An adequate pelvis is necessary for a trial of labor. However, if no contraindications to vaginal birth exist, as stated in the vignette, clinical pelvimetry is not used to determine the need for cervical ripening during IOL. 
❌ Estimated fetal weight (EFW):
Incorrect: An EFW should be obtained as part of the clinical assessment prior to admitting a patient for labor because a high enough EFW may be an indication for cesarean birth. However, if no contraindications to vaginal birth exist, as stated in the vignette, the EFW is not used to determine the need for cervical ripening during IOL.

questions.text: A 36-year-old patient, gravida 3, para 2, presents at 39 weeks estimated gestational age (EGA) for an elective induction of labor. She has no contractions, loss of fluid, vaginal bleeding, or decreased fetal movement. The pregnancy was complicated by group B Streptococcus (GBS) bacteriuria in the first trimester and was treated with antibiotics in the first trimester. History is notable for two prior uncomplicated vaginal births at term. The patient takes no medication and has no allergies to medication. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is gravid and non-tender; the cervix is initially in a mid-position, soft, 1 cm dilated, 25% effaced, at –3 cm station. A non-stress test is reactive and reassuring. A dose of misoprostol is placed vaginally, and four hours later the cervix is still in a mid-position, 3 cm dilated, 50% effaced, and at –1 cm station. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate step in management?

choices.text: Oxytocin, penicillin, and artificial rupture of membranes (AROM)
Repeat dose of misoprostol and placement of a Foley balloon
Oxytocin and artificial rupture of membranes (AROM)

questions.solution:
The patient undergoing an induction of labor (IOL) must be regularly assessed for forward labor progress, which is defined as progressive dilation, effacement, softening, and anterior movement of the cervix, plus fetal descent. Typically, cervical ripening can be discontinued once the Bishop score reaches at least 7. In the vignette, the patient’s repeat Bishop score is 8: she receives 2 points for dilation, 1 for effacement, 2 for station, 1 for position, and 2 for consistency. With a Bishop score ≥7, the next steps are typically oxytocin and artificial rupture of membranes (AROM). However, AROM should not be performed in GBS positive patients (like in the vignette) until at least 4 hours after their first dose of prophylactic antibiotics. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in the vignette is to initiate oxytocin to induce regular contractions and to start penicillin for GBS prophylaxis. AROM would then be appropriate in 4 hours.

Alternatively, if the initial round of cervical ripening does not produce an adequate response (repeat Bishop score is ≤6), additional cervical ripening is indicated. If an adequate response is still not achieved despite prolonged cervical ripening, cesarean birth is indicated (unless the patient is undergoing a purely elective IOL, in which case discharge home may be appropriate if monitoring is reassuring and the membranes are still intact).
   

Option Analysis

✅ Oxytocin and penicillin:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Oxytocin, penicillin, and artificial rupture of membranes (AROM) :
Incorrect: This patient had GBS bacteriuria during this pregnancy and therefore requires GBS prophylaxis during labor regardless of whether she was treated. AROM should be postponed until at least 4 hours following the initial dose of prophylactic antibiotics. 
❌ Repeat dose of misoprostol and placement of a Foley balloon:
Incorrect: If an initial round of cervical ripening results in adequate labor progress, like the progress seen in the vignette, it is better to move forward with oxytocin with or without an amniotomy.  
❌ Foley balloon and penicillin:
Incorrect: If an initial round of cervical ripening results in adequate labor progress, like the progress seen in the vignette, it is better to move forward with oxytocin. Due to her history of GBS bacteriuria during this pregnancy, it is appropriate to start penicillin.
❌ Oxytocin and artificial rupture of membranes (AROM):
Incorrect: This patient had GBS bacteriuria during this pregnancy and thus requires GBS prophylaxis during labor regardless of whether she was treated. AROM should be postponed until at least 4 hours following the initial dose of prophylactic antibiotics.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, presents to the clinic for her first antenatal appointment at 6 weeks of estimated gestational age. She is asymptomatic and feels well. Past medical history is notable for sickle cell disease, managed with hydroxyurea, as well as an uncomplicated vaginal delivery two years ago. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mmHg. On physical exam, the patient is in no distress. The uterus is mildly enlarged, and the pelvis is normal. Screening laboratory results are shown in the table below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? 

 Laboratory value      Result     
 Serum chemistries           
 Hemoglobin      10.1 g/dL     
 Hematocrit      31 %     
 Leukocyte count      7,100 /mm3     
 Platelet count      227,000/mm3     
 Mean corpuscular volume      77 fL     
 Serum ferritin      normal     
 Total-iron-binding capacity      normal
questions.solution:
This pregnant patient with sickle cell disease should be treated with high-dose folic acid supplementation. In patients with sickle cell disease, the abnormal hemoglobin, known as hemoglobin S (HbS), causes red blood cells to bend into an abnormal sickled shape that is easily destroyed. To compensate, red cell production is increased, which leads to depletion of folic acid stores. Folic acid is critical for normal fetal development, especially early in gestation during development of the neural tube. For this reason, pregnant patients with SCD require high-dose folic acid supplementation during pregnancy.        

Hemoglobinopathies are associated with multiple increased risks during pregnancy. Therefore, prenatal management is more intense and more frequent than when caring for non-affected individuals. The risks and associated management recommendations for severe hemoglobinopathies are detailed in the table above.       

Option Analysis

✅ High-dose folic acid supplementation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Iron supplementation:
Incorrect: This patient’s anemia is secondary to sickle cell disease (SCD) rather than iron deficiency anemia, given her known SCD and normal iron labs. She is at greater risk of transfusion-related iron overload rather than iron deficiency and should not have supplemental iron. 
❌ Increased hydroxyurea dose:
Incorrect: Hydroxyurea is teratogenic and can lead to congenital anomalies and pregnancy loss. Instead of increasing the hydroxyurea dose, the risks and benefits of decreasing the dose or discontinuing hydroxyurea should be discussed with the patient at this time. 
❌ Exchange transfusion:
Incorrect: An exchange transfusion may be appropriate in patients with sickle cell disease experiencing a pain crisis that does not respond to more conservative management. In an exchange transfusion, the abnormal sickled cells causing the vasoocclusions are removed while unaffected blood is transfused into the patient. This patient is not having a pain crisis. 
❌ Iron chelation therapy:
Incorrect: Iron chelation therapy is indicated in patients with severe thalassemias or in patients with sickle cell disease who have transfusion-related iron overload. With thalassemias, abnormal intracellular inclusions of clumped excess globin chains weaken the red cell membranes, leading to intravascular hemolysis and iron overload.

questions.text: A 32-year-old nulligravid woman presents for a colposcopy exam after routine screening came back with atypical squamous cells, cannot exclude high-grade (ASC-H) and positive high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV). The patient reports that she and her partner are planning to attempt conception next year, and she is concerned about the impact of any procedures on her cervix. After patient-centered counseling, she consents to the procedures today. She is healthy and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or other recreational substances. Family history is notable for a hysterectomy in her mother due to endometrial cancer at age 60. Vital signs are normal, and a urine pregnancy test is negative. On colposcopy exam, acetic acid is applied to the cervix and abnormalities are noted surrounding the cervical os. Representative biopsies are taken and return as cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) 3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient given her fertility desires?

choices.text: Observation with repeat colposcopy in 6 months

questions.solution:
This 32-year-old patient who desires future fertility is found to have cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) 3, which describes the presence of severely atypical cellular changes that extend through at least two thirds of the epithelial thickness (without invading through the basement membrane). It is considered an immediate precursor to cancer. Treatment is recommended and observation is considered unacceptable, even when patients are planning future pregnancies as in the vignette. This patient should have an excisional treatment like loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP).       

When treatment of high-grade dysplasia is planned, excision is preferred over ablation because the excised tissue can be assessed for unsuspected invasive cancer that may be present. It also allows for assessment of the specimen margins, which can determine whether the entire lesion was excised. Additionally, if the margins are positive, closer surveillance or retreatment is recommended. Excisional treatments include loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP), cold knife conization (CKC), and laser cone biopsy. However, ablative procedures, including cryotherapy, laser ablation, and thermoablation, are acceptable alternatives when excisional procedures are unavailable.        

In contrast, close observation is appropriate for patients with CIN 2 and desire for future pregnancies and in people with high-grade cytology but only CIN 1 on biopsy.   

Option Analysis

✅ Loop electrosurgical excision procedure:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Observation with repeat colposcopy in 6 months:
Incorrect: Observation with careful surveillance is only appropriate in patients with specified CIN 2. Due to the increased risk of cancer with CIN 3, as seen in the vignette, excision procedures are recommended, even when future pregnancy is planned. 
❌ Cryotherapy:
Incorrect: With CIN 3, treatment is preferred. Cryotherapy is an ablative procedure that uses liquid nitrogen to destroy abnormal tissue. However, an excisional procedure is preferred over ablative therapy because it allows the specimen to be examined for occult disease and for disease present at the margins of the specimen. 
❌ Laser ablation:
Incorrect: With CIN 3, treatment is preferred. Laser ablation is an ablative therapy that uses lasers to destroy abnormal tissue. However, an excisional procedure is preferred over ablative therapy because it allows the specimen to be examined for occult disease and for disease present at the margins of the specimen. 
❌ Trachelectomy:
Trachelectomy refers to excision of the entire cervix. This is too invasive of a procedure for CIN-3 and would significantly increase fertility risks. A loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP), cold knife conization (CKC), or laser cone biopsy is preferred.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, presents for evaluation of painful menstruation that has progressively worsened over the past 2 years. Her periods are regular with heavy flow. The pain typically begins with the onset of menstruation and lasts 3 to 4 days, although she occasionally experiences similar pain when she is not bleeding. Review of systems is notable for frequent constipation, increased urinary urgency, and occasional deep dyspareunia. She is otherwise healthy and has a history of one spontaneous preterm vaginal birth. The patient’s mother had a hysterectomy in her 40s due to heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pain. Vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal palpation is significant for mild tenderness and an irregular pelvic mass extending from the suprapubic region to the left lower quadrant. The pelvic exam shows a typical parous cervix and normal physiologic discharge. The uterus is mobile, grossly enlarged, mildly tender to palpation, and has a bulky, irregular contour. The adnexa are not confidently palpated. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following will most likely be seen on pelvic ultrasound?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with dysmenorrhea, heavy menstrual bleeding, bulk symptoms, and an enlarged uterus with an irregular contour; this presentation is suggestive of a uterine leiomyoma. Uterine leiomyomas are readily visible on pelvic ultrasound and appear as well-circumscribed, homogenous, solid myometrial masses.         

Uterine leiomyomas, also known as uterine fibroids, are benign encapsulated tumors that originate from smooth muscle cells of the uterus. They can arise anywhere within the myometrium and can vary widely in size and number. Pelvic pain may be cyclic (i.e. dysmenorrhea), random, or chronic. Menstrual bleeding is often heavy, and intermenstrual bleeding can also be seen. Additionally, larger leiomyomas can cause bulk symptoms such as pelvic pressure, increased urinary frequency, constipation, and deep focal dyspareunia.       

Although uterine leiomyomas can often be suspected based on history and exam findings, a pelvic ultrasound should be performed to confirm the diagnosis and help guide management decisions, as treatment options vary depending on the number, size, and location of the leiomyomas.   

Option Analysis

✅ Solid myometrial mass:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Myometrial cysts:
Incorrect: Myometrial cysts are seen in adenomyosis, which can also cause dysmenorrhea and heavy menstrual bleeding. However, bulk symptoms, such as constipation and urinary urgency, are typically absent, and the uterine contour is smooth with adenomyosis. An irregular contour, seen in the vignette, suggests a uterine leiomyoma. 
❌ Solid adnexal mass:
Incorrect: Other potential causes of this patient's pain include a broad ligament or pedunculated leiomyoma, a sex-cord stromal or germ cell ovarian tumor, and non-ovarian cancer that has metastasized to the ovary. These diagnoses are all much less common than uterine leiomyomas, which are extremely common and most likely in this case. 
❌ Cystic adnexal mass:
Incorrect: Cystic adnexal masses can be functional cysts, endometriomas, ectopic pregnancies, benign and malignant ovarian neoplasms, pelvic abscesses, theca lutein cysts, and hydrosalpinx. However, the enlarged uterus with an irregular contour, heavy menstrual bleeding, and bulk symptoms seen in this patient make uterine leiomyoma a more likely diagnosis. 
❌ Abnormal fluid collection:
Incorrect: Adnexal fluid collections can be seen with hydrosalpinx or pelvic infection, while an intrauterine fluid collection can be seen in pregnancy, pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), or obstruction of the uterine outflow tract. The normal vagina and cervix on examination make obstruction unlikely in this case. The enlarged uterus with an irregular contour and bulk symptoms are more consistent with uterine leiomyoma.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, presents in spontaneous labor at 38 weeks’ gestation. She is healthy, and her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. She has a history of two prior cesarean births—the first for malpresentation and the second was an elective repeat procedure. After extensive counseling, she elects to undergo a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC). An epidural is in place, although she has become more uncomfortable over the past hour. Vital signs are within normal limits, and the most recent cervical exam shows 6 cm dilation, 75% effacement, and 0 station. The fetal heart rate (FHR) tracing shows a baseline rate of 130 bpm, without rapid fluctuations from baseline or visually apparent accelerations. There are recurrent abrupt decreases in FHR of 30 to 60 bpm below baseline that last approximately 30 seconds and begin at the onset of each contraction. Contractions are regular and occur every 2 to 4 minutes. How should this FHR pattern be classified?
questions.solution:
This patient presents in labor in the setting of a TOLAC, and fetal heart rate (FHR) tracing shows absent variability with recurrent variable decelerations, which is classified as a category III FHR tracing. This concerning pattern is associated with fetal acidemia and requires urgent management.

Intrapartum FHR monitoring detects inadequate fetal oxygenation during labor and enables intervention before fetal acidemia causes permanent injury. FHR tracings can be classified as category I, II, or III.

Category I is reassuring and includes only tracings with a normal baseline FHR, moderate variability, and absent late and variable decelerations. On the other hand, category III is associated with fetal acidemia and necessitates prompt evaluation and intervention. Category III is defined by absent variability with either bradycardia or recurrent late or variable decelerations. A sinusoidal pattern, which appears as a smooth sine wave-like pattern (sometimes described as a “sawtooth pattern”) with a cyclic frequency of 3-5 waves per minute, is also considered category III. Finally, category II is considered indeterminate and includes everything not classified as either category I or III.  

Definitions, interpretations, and management of these categories are outlined in the table.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Category I:
Incorrect: Category I is reassuring and is defined by a normal baseline FHR, moderate variability, and the absence of late or variable decelerations. In this case, the recurrent variable decelerations in the setting of absent variability are particularly concerning and would be considered category III.
❌ Category II:
Incorrect: Category II is considered indeterminate and includes patterns that do not meet criteria for either category I or III. In this case, the recurrent variable decelerations in the setting of absent variability are particularly concerning and would be considered category III.
✅ Category III:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reactive:
Incorrect: A “reactive” pattern is defined by the presence of at least two accelerations of at least 15 bpm lasting at least 15 seconds within a 20-minute period. Accelerations are not present in this vignette.
❌ Indeterminate:
Incorrect: Indeterminate patterns are classified as category II. Recurrent variable decelerations with absent variability are abnormal and are classified as category III.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravid woman presents in labor at 38 weeks’ gestation. Her membranes have grossly ruptured, and she is having contractions every 30 minutes. The pregnancy has been uncomplicated. She has a history of chronic hypertension managed with nifedipine. Labor is progressing spontaneously, and she has an epidural in place. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 128/92 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. She appears well, and cervical exam reveals 7 cm dilation with 80% effacement, and the fetal vertex is at 0 station. The baseline fetal heart rate (FHR) is 150 bpm with beat-to-beat variability of 10 bpm. There are no accelerations. The patient soon develops recurrent decelerations with each contraction that descend abruptly and become progressively deeper. Contractions are now occurring every 2 to 3 minutes. The nurse repositions the patient and administers an IV fluid bolus with no improvement in the decelerations. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Variable decelerations are caused by umbilical cord compression. An amnioinfusion could help relieve pressure on the umbilical cord and is the best next step in managing the patient in this vignette. An amnioinfusion refers to an infusion of sterile saline into the uterine cavity through an intrauterine pressure catheter (IUPC), cushioning the umbilical cord.  

Labor management is guided by the fetal heart rate (FHR) category. Category I tracings are reassuring and can be managed with routine care. On the other hand, category III tracings are abnormal and require prompt resuscitation and delivery if there is an inadequate response.

Category II tracings indicate an indeterminate fetal well-being and warrant further evaluation. Patients with these tracings should first be assessed for the presence of accelerations and moderate variability, both of which are associated with a normal fetal acid-base status. When these reassuring features are present, intrauterine resuscitation is usually appropriate. This can include repositioning the patient, administering an IV fluid bolus, and, in cases of recurrent variable decelerations, performing an amnioinfusion. Additionally, patients should be assessed for signs of infection, abruption, cord accident, or maternal hypotension and treated accordingly if any are found.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Amnioinfusion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Supplemental oxygen:
Incorrect: Supplemental oxygen does not improve fetal outcomes and is no longer recommended as part of routine intrauterine resuscitation in patients with a normal oxygen saturation.
❌ Tocolysis:
Incorrect: Tocolysis can be considered for patients not receiving uterotonic agents who develop tachysystole and category II tracings. It may also be appropriate for category III tracings, prolonged decelerations, or bradycardia. Tachysystole is defined as > 5 contractions in a 10-minute period---more than the patient is having in this vignette.
❌ Vibroacoustic stimulation:
Incorrect: Vibroacoustic stimulation (VAS) is used to evaluate fetal status in patients with a category II tracing that lacks accelerations and shows minimal or absent variability. If an acceleration occurs or variability increases after VAS, this indicates a lower risk of fetal acidemia. In this patient, the moderate variability is reassuring, making amnioinfusion the preferred next step.
❌ Consider prompt delivery:
Incorrect: Prompt delivery should be considered when fetal well-being cannot be confirmed or when FHR patterns suggest fetal acidemia. This patient has moderate variability, which indicates a low risk of fetal acidemia, making prompt delivery inappropriate.

questions.text: A 27-year-old patient, gravida 3, para 2, presents to the obstetrical office at 14 weeks estimated gestation age (EGA) based on her last menstrual period. She has chosen to pursue an elective abortion. Her past medical history includes heavy menstrual bleeding, anemia, and a hemorrhagic ovarian cyst. Vitals are within normal limits. A chaperoned exam shows an enlarged uterus, and a bedside ultrasound confirms a live intrauterine pregnancy consistent with her estimated due date. The patient prefers to avoid an overnight hospital admission because she has two small children at home. Which of the following management options should be discussed with the patient as the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
This patient is at 14 weeks EGA and prefers an elective abortion without an overnight hospital stay. Medication abortion at home is generally only available through 10 weeks’ gestation. Although medication abortions can be performed beyond that timeframe, they carry a higher risk of severe bleeding and other complications, which is why patients undergoing second-trimester medication abortion are usually admitted to the hospital. Therefore, a procedural abortion via uterine evacuation is most appropriate for this patient.        

Procedural abortion can be performed in the office or operating room using uterine aspiration and suction curettage or, at more advanced gestational ages, by dilation and evacuation (D&E). Before a D&E, misoprostol or mifepristone may be given to help soften and dilate the cervix, reducing the risks associated with mechanical dilation during the procedure. In addition, antibiotics, specifically doxycycline, are indicated prior to any procedural abortion to reduce the risk of infection.        

Elective abortions are extremely safe, especially in the first trimester when the vast majority occur. In the United States, approximately 90% of induced abortions occur in the first trimester; fewer than 10% occur between 13 and 20 weeks, and fewer than 1% occur after 20 weeks’ gestation. 



Option Analysis

✅ Uterine evacuation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Misoprostol alone:
Incorrect: While misoprostol alone can be used in some circumstances, it is less effective than the combination of mifepristone and misoprostol. Additionally, this patient is beyond 10 weeks EGA, so a procedural abortion is generally preferred. 
❌ Mifepristone and misoprostol:
Incorrect: The combination of mifepristone and misoprostol is the most effective method for a medication abortion, but it is generally for pregnancies up to 10 weeks' gestation. At 14 weeks EGA, a procedural abortion is more appropriate. 
❌ Intrauterine device (IUD) placement:
Incorrect: While an IUD can be used for emergency contraception, it is not considered a reliable method for inducing an abortion. It is an excellent option for post-abortion contraception, but it cannot be placed until elective abortion is complete. An IUD can be placed at the time of a procedural abortion or as early as 1 week after a medication abortion. 
❌ Complete blood count (CBC):
Incorrect: Although checking a CBC can be useful in evaluating a patient with heavy menstrual bleeding or anemia, it is not a required step in the management of an elective abortion in this context.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the obstetrical office with concerns about feeling down. The patient delivered a healthy term infant via vaginal delivery 8 weeks ago; the delivery was complicated by a postpartum hemorrhage that did not require a blood transfusion. The pregnancy was also complicated by mild anemia and advanced maternal age. Today, the patient reports feeling depressed, experiencing fatigue, difficulty concentrating, insomnia, and weight gain over the past 2 weeks. The patient has not had anxiety or excessive worry and reports no suicidal or homicidal ideation. The patient also notes that her supportive partner returned to work 4 weeks ago, and she does not have anyone else to help in the area. Past medical history is significant for a pregnancy loss at 16 weeks and hypothyroidism with normal thyroid function tests last week. Physical examination is noncontributory. Which of the following is the greatest risk factor for the patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s depressed mood, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, insomnia, and weight gain are consistent with postpartum depression. A poor social support network is her greatest risk factor for this condition. Other risk factors for postpartum depression include a history of intimate partner violence, a personal or family history of depression or anxiety, and current military service or veteran status.        

Perinatal depression and anxiety affect many patients during pregnancy and up to a year after childbirth. Screening for, diagnosing, and treating these conditions is important because they are associated with adverse maternal and fetal outcomes. Screening is performed using a validated tool, such as the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS), which is most often used during pregnancy and postpartum because it assesses for both depression and anxiety and includes a question about self-harm. Screening should be conducted at the first prenatal visit, during the third trimester, and again postpartum. For patients with risk factors, such as a poor social support network, screening can be performed more frequently.       

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/  for international resources. You are not alone.   

Option Analysis

✅ Poor social network:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Postpartum hemorrhage :
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms are consistent with postpartum depression. While a postpartum hemorrhage and other pregnancy complications can be risk factors for postpartum anxiety, they are not considered risk factors for postpartum depression. 
❌ Advanced maternal age :
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms are consistent with postpartum depression. Advanced maternal age (AMA) is associated with several obstetrical complications, such as miscarriage, hypertensive disorders, and gestational diabetes. However, AMA is not a risk factor for postpartum depression. 
❌ History of pregnancy loss:
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms are consistent with postpartum depression. While a history of pregnancy loss is a risk factor for postpartum anxiety, it is not considered a risk factor for postpartum depression. 
❌ Hypothyroidism:
Incorrect: While hypothyroidism can mimic depression symptoms, this patient’s recent normal thyroid function tests indicate that it is a less likely cause of her condition.

questions.text: A 27-year-old G3P1112 woman presents for a 6-week postpartum visit. The patient had an uncomplicated repeat cesarean delivery following a pregnancy complicated by gestational diabetes managed with diet and exercise. There is a history of preterm delivery at 34 weeks due to preterm rupture of membranes with cord prolapse that required an emergent cesarean delivery. Since delivery, the patient reports excessive anxiety and worry, along with irritability, restlessness, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating. Similar symptoms occurred after the first delivery but resolved after six months without intervention. The patient reports no other history of anxiety or depression. Vital signs are within normal limits, and a chaperoned examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Perinatal anxiety is the most likely diagnosis based on the patient’s symptoms of excessive anxiety and worry, irritability, restlessness, and difficulty concentrating for more than two weeks. A standardized screening tool, such as the General Anxiety Disorder-7 (GAD-7) or Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS) with positive anxiety indicators, can aid in confirming the diagnosis.        

Patients with perinatal anxiety present during pregnancy or within the first 12 months after delivery with symptoms similar to generalized anxiety disorder. These symptoms include excessive anxiety and worry along with at least three of the following: restlessness or feeling on edge, fatigue, difficulty concentrating or a mind that goes blank, irritability, muscle tension, or sleep disturbances. Risk factors include personal or family history of anxiety, prior pregnancy loss, an unplanned or complicated pregnancy, intimate partner violence, or a history of childhood abuse.       

Perinatal anxiety is a predictor for perinatal depression. Treatment includes self-care measures such as adequate sleep, exercise, and balanced nutrition. Both psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy are effective first-line treatments, with added benefits when used together. Psychotherapy includes cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and interpersonal psychotherapy (IPT). The preferred pharmacotherapy is selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs); sertraline is often preferred, although escitalopram is an acceptable alternative. Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), such as venlafaxine, can also be used. While benzodiazepines are often used for anxiety outside of pregnancy, they should be used sparingly in perinatal anxiety and only as a temporary bridge until psychotherapy, SSRIs, or SNRIs take full effect. A collaborative treatment approach may involve a mental health professional and, if indicated, hospitalization.    

Option Analysis

✅ Perinatal anxiety:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Mild perinatal depression (postpartum blues):
Incorrect: Mild perinatal depression, or postpartum blues, typically occurs within 2 days up to 2 weeks after delivery. Symptoms include dysphoric mood, crying, mood lability, anxiety, sleeplessness, loss of appetite, and irritability. This patient’s symptoms have persisted beyond 2 weeks and are more consistent with perinatal anxiety. 
❌ Perinatal depression:
Incorrect: Although fatigue and concentration difficulties are present, the predominant symptoms—excessive anxiety, worry, restlessness, and irritability—align more with perinatal anxiety. Continued monitoring is advised, as perinatal anxiety can be a predictor for perinatal depression.  
❌ Postpartum psychosis:
Incorrect: Postpartum psychosis is rare but serious. Symptoms can include agitation, delusions, disorganized thoughts, bizarre behavior, auditory or visual hallucinations, and intrusive thoughts of suicide or infanticide. None of these features are evident here, and the patient’s presentation is more consistent with perinatal anxiety. 
❌ Bipolar disorder:
Incorrect: While it is important to rule out bipolar disorder before starting medication for perinatal depression and anxiety, this patient does not have a history of manic or hypomanic episodes consistent with this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, presents to the obstetrics clinic at 28 weeks’ gestation with two days of dysuria, urinary frequency, and urgency. There is no associated hematuria, vaginal bleeding, uterine contractions, or decreased fetal movement. Pregnancy to date has been uncomplicated. Her prior pregnancy was delivered via cesarean delivery at term for breech presentation. Temperature is 37.0ºC (98.6ºF), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/82 mmHg. The patient appears well, has no costovertebral tenderness, and no pooling on a speculum exam. Bedside testing for ruptured membranes is negative. Which of the following findings would warrant treatment with oral antibiotics?

choices.text: Red blood cells (RBCs) on urine microscopy
A hyperechoic focus with posterior shadowing in the bladder on ultrasound

questions.solution:
Acute cystitis is an infection of the bladder that typically presents with dysuria, urinary frequency, urgency, nocturia, or urinary incontinence. A pregnant patient with these symptoms should be evaluated with a urinalysis and urine culture. Empiric oral antibiotics are indicated when the urinalysis supports the diagnosis of acute cystitis, such as positive nitrites (produced by some uropathogens and highly specific for infection), positive leukocyte esterase (an enzyme produced by white blood cells), and pyuria (white blood cells in the urine).        

The diagnosis of acute cystitis is confirmed when the urine culture grows at least 100,000 CFU/mL of a single pathogen, and culture sensitivities should then guide any necessary adjustments to antimicrobial therapy. Additionally, some experts will also treat symptomatic patients whose cultures yield between 100 CFU/mL and 100,000 CFU/mL because of the higher risk of ascending infection and the morbidity associated with pyelonephritis during pregnancy.       

A renal ultrasound is reserved for those whose presentation and urinalysis suggest nephrolithiasis. However, it is not indicated solely for uncomplicated cystitis.   

Option Analysis

✅ Nitrites on urinalysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Fever:
Incorrect: A febrile patient with urinary symptoms in pregnancy should be treated with intravenous antibiotics for presumed pyelonephritis, not oral therapy. 
❌ Red blood cells (RBCs) on urine microscopy:
Incorrect: Isolated microscopic hematuria without bacteriuria or other evidence of infection is more suggestive of nephrolithiasis and does not by itself justify antibiotics. 
❌ Hydronephrosis on renal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Physiologic hydronephrosis is normal during pregnancy. Excessive hydronephrosis may indicate nephrolithiasis, which is managed with hydration and analgesics rather than antibiotics. 
❌ A hyperechoic focus with posterior shadowing in the bladder on ultrasound:
Incorrect: This would likely represent a renal calculus that has passed into the bladder. Nephrolithiasis is managed with hydration and analgesics rather than antibiotics.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 1, presents in labor at 39 weeks’ gestation with an uncomplicated pregnancy. The patient's medical history includes one prior uncomplicated vaginal birth and one septic abortion at 10 weeks’ gestation managed with antibiotics and dilation and curettage (D&C). Labor progresses normally, and the patient delivers a 3,600 g (8 lb) healthy neonate. Immediately after delivery, vital signs are stable, the uterine fundus is firm at the umbilicus, and a second-degree laceration is noted that is slowly oozing blood. Five minutes later, there is a sudden increase in vaginal bleeding. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 122/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 84/60 mmHg. The patient's skin is cold and clammy. A bimanual examination reveals a firmly adherent placenta. Intravenous (IV) fluids are initiated, labs are drawn, and O-negative blood is requested. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Transfusion of blood products as needed based on lab results

questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden, massive blood loss in the setting of a firmly adherent placenta following vaginal birth; this presentation suggests placenta accreta spectrum (PAS), in which the placenta abnormally attaches to or invades the uterine wall. PAS can rapidly lead to severe postpartum hemorrhage and shock. A patient in hemorrhagic shock from PAS requires immediate assessment and management of the airway, breathing, and circulation, and should be transferred immediately to the operating room for definitive hemostasis.

Although PAS is often diagnosed on antenatal ultrasound, it may present unexpectedly after delivery. These patients typically have delayed placental delivery and/or severe postpartum hemorrhage during the third stage of labor that does not respond to uterotonic agents. Bleeding can become life-threatening, and patients can rapidly develop signs of shock.

In these situations, vital signs must be closely monitored and intubation performed if there is any evidence of airway compromise. Aggressive resuscitation with IV fluids and blood products should begin and a massive transfusion protocol activated, if available. Temporary measures, such as bimanual uterine compression and administration of uterotonic agents, may help limit bleeding as the patient is transferred to the operating room for D&C or laparotomy. Hysterectomy is often required.

Option Analysis

✅ Transfer to the operating room:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Repair of the obstetric laceration:
Incorrect: Blood loss from this obstetric laceration is minimal compared to the hemorrhage coming from the firmly adherent placenta (placenta accreta). This patient should be moved to the operating room for emergent surgical intervention to control the hemorrhage.
❌ Transfusion of blood products as needed based on lab results:
Incorrect: Hemorrhage secondary to placenta accreta can evolve rapidly and quickly become life-threatening. Transfusion is guided by clinical status (e.g. vital signs, symptoms, exam findings) rather than laboratory values. This patient should be moved to the operating room for emergent surgical intervention to control the hemorrhage.
❌ Uterotonic agents and close observation:
Incorrect: Although uterotonic agents may be appropriate to give in this setting, observation alone is insufficient. Hemodynamic instability from placenta accreta necessitates prompt surgical intervention. Therefore, the priority is to transfer the patient to the operating room.
❌ Manual extraction of the placenta:
Incorrect: This patient likely has unexpected placenta accreta spectrum (PAS), indicating that the placenta is firmly adherent to the uterine wall and may be invading into or through the myometrium. Attempts at manual extraction will likely tear the placenta and worsen hemorrhage. Surgical management is required, necessitating transfer to the operating room.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old primigravid woman presents at 16 weeks’ gestation with hematuria. The patient has no dysuria or increased urinary urgency. Medical history is notable for infertility, and the patient conceived following a procedure involving multiple myomectomies and in vitro fertilization. The patient is otherwise healthy and only takes a prenatal vitamin. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 112/70 mmHg. On examination, the patient appears well. There is no uterine or suprapubic tenderness. Speculum exam shows no vaginal bleeding and a closed cervix. An ultrasound demonstrates a single viable fetus and an anterior placenta covering the internal os. There are multiple placental lacunae, loss of the hypoechoic clear zone between the placenta and uterine wall, and retroplacental myometrial thinning. An area of hypervascularity over the posterior bladder wall is noted. Urinalysis results are displayed below. Which of the following strategies would be most appropriate for reducing the risk of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) in this patient?

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Urinalysis    
 Color     Clear    
 Specific gravity     1.013    
 Glucose     Negative    
 Blood     3+    
 Leukocyte esterase     Negative    
 Nitrites     Negative

choices.text: Pre-delivery occlusion of the internal iliac arteries
Antenatal medical management of the bladder lesion
Antenatal surgical management of the bladder lesion
Dilation and curettage (D&C) immediately following delivery of the neonate

questions.solution:
This patient with an antenatal diagnosis of placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) requires a multidisciplinary team and careful delivery planning to minimize postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) and associated complications. Strategies to reduce blood loss include occlusion of the internal iliac arteries (which provide the primary blood supply to the uterus) and the use of Cell Saver technology (to recycle blood lost during the surgery).  

Antenatally, the patient’s hemoglobin should be optimized with iron supplementation. Delivery is best arranged at a tertiary care center between 34 and 36 weeks’ gestation after corticosteroids administration for fetal lung maturation. A planned cesarean hysterectomy is recommended: the infant is delivered first, the placenta remains in situ, and hysterectomy follows. If the placenta invades the bladder, partial cystectomy may be necessary. Prophylactic placement of ureteral stents has been shown to decrease the risk of ureteral injury during cesarean hysterectomy.

Intraoperatively, patients should have at least 2 large bore IVs placed and cross-matched blood readily available for transfusion. Antifibrinolytic therapy (e.g. tranexamic acid) may be administered in cases of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) or severe hemorrhage.   

Option Analysis

✅ Pre-delivery occlusion of the internal iliac arteries:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Antenatal medical management of the bladder lesion:
Incorrect: This patient has placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) with bladder invasion. Definitive management requires cesarean hysterectomy and partial cystectomy to remove the entire placenta. PAS does not resolve with antenatal medical management.
❌ Antenatal surgical management of the bladder lesion:
Incorrect: This patient has placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) with bladder invasion. Definitive management requires cesarean hysterectomy and partial cystectomy to remove the entire placenta. Attempting antenatal surgical management would be inappropriate because invasive placental tissue cannot be safely resected before delivery.
❌ Dilation and curettage (D&C) immediately following delivery of the neonate:
Incorrect: This patient has placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) with bladder invasion. Definitive management requires cesarean hysterectomy and partial cystectomy to remove the entire placenta. D&C may be utilized in patients with smaller, focal areas of abnormal placental attachment, unlike the patient described here.
❌ Antenatal iron supplementation:
Incorrect: Antenatal iron supplementation is recommended in most patients with placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) to maximize hemoglobin concentration prior to delivery. However, it does not independently reduce the risk of PPH.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with sudden urges to urinate followed by involuntary leakage of urine. There is no leakage when coughing or laughing. These symptoms have been present for the past three months and have significantly affected daily activities. There is no history of urinary tract infections or surgeries. The patient is not currently taking any medications. Family history is unremarkable, and the patient does not smoke or consume alcohol. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. A neurologic exam is normal. Pelvic examination reveals no signs of pelvic organ prolapse or vaginal atrophy. Urinalysis is negative for nitrites, leukocyte esterase, and blood. Which of the following diagnostic tests is most likely to be abnormal?
questions.solution:
This patient's symptoms of sudden urges to urinate followed by involuntary leakage, without leakage during activities that increase abdominal pressure (e.g., coughing or laughing), are indicative of urgency urinary incontinence (UUI). This type of incontinence is primarily caused by detrusor overactivity, in which involuntary contractions of the detrusor muscle lead to a sudden and strong need to void. Urodynamic testing can confirm the diagnosis by demonstrating these involuntary contractions.

The diagnostic workup for urinary incontinence begins with a detailed history and physical examination, including assessment of symptoms, medical history, and current medications. Initial tests often include urinalysis and urine culture to rule out infection. Simple in-office evaluations such as the cough stress test and post-void residual (PVR) measurement help assess for stress incontinence and incomplete bladder emptying, respectively. If the initial evaluation is inconclusive or if UUI is suspected, further testing such as urodynamic studies may be required to confirm the diagnosis and guide appropriate management.

Option Analysis

❌ Post-void residual (PVR) measurement:
Incorrect: A PVR measures the amount of urine left in the bladder after voiding and is typically elevated in overflow incontinence. However, this patient has no reported difficulty emptying the bladder, and the symptoms are more consistent with urgency urinary incontinence. Therefore, the PVR is expected to be normal.
❌ Cough stress test:
Incorrect: The cough stress test assesses for stress urinary incontinence by observing for urine leakage during activities that increase abdominal pressure, such as coughing. Since the patient does not report leakage during coughing or laughing, the test would likely be normal.
❌ Test of urethral mobility:
Incorrect: Urethral hypermobility would be expected with stress urinary incontinence. However, this patient’s symptoms are more consistent with urgency incontinence rather than stress incontinence, so this test would likely be normal.
❌ Pelvic ultrasound:
Incorrect: A pelvic ultrasound is used to visualize the pelvic organs. This patient's symptoms and normal pelvic examination suggest that an ultrasound would not provide relevant information for the diagnosis of urgency incontinence.
✅ Urodynamic test of detrusor activity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 3, presents in the postpartum period with fever, malaise, and right breast pain. Breastfeeding has been difficult due to nipple discomfort and incomplete milk emptying. There is no significant medical history aside from three uncomplicated vaginal deliveries. Current medications include only prenatal vitamins. No tobacco or alcohol use is reported. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), heart rate is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/76 mmHg. On physical examination, there is erythema, induration, and tenderness over the right breast without fluctuance. A complete blood count (CBC) shows a white blood cell (WBC) count of 14,000/µL. When is this patient most likely presenting?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of fever, malaise, breast pain, erythema, and induration, which are characteristic findings of lactational mastitis. This condition typically occurs over one week postpartum and is often associated with nipple trauma, poor latch, or incomplete breast emptying. This patient’s difficulty breastfeeding, along with the physical findings of tenderness and erythema, strongly support the diagnosis.

In cases of postpartum fever, the clinical presentation, including the time since delivery, is often sufficient to guide diagnosis. Evaluation begins with a thorough history and physical examination, followed by targeted testing such as urinalysis and a complete blood count to assess for urinary tract infection and leukocytosis, respectively.  

During the first 24 hours postpartum, transient low-grade fevers (typically less than 39°C or 102.2°F) are common and may result from resolving intraamniotic infection, misoprostol use, dehydration, epidural anesthesia, or atelectasis. Observation is often appropriate in these cases. In contrast, higher fevers or those developing after the first 24 hours require further evaluation. The differential diagnosis can usually be narrowed based on the timing of onset and associated clinical features, as outlined in the table above.

Option Analysis

❌ Within 24 hours of delivery:
Incorrect: Transient, low-grade isolated postpartum fever can occur within the first 24 hours. However, this patient’s presentation of localized breast tenderness, erythema, and systemic symptoms is not typical in the immediate postpartum period.
❌ 1 to 3 days postpartum:
Incorrect: A fever developing 1 to 3 days postpartum is most often due to endometritis, particularly following cesarean delivery. Endometritis typically presents with uterine tenderness and foul-smelling lochia, which are not present in this case.
❌ 3 to 5 days postpartum:
Incorrect: A fever developing 3 to 5 days postpartum is most often due to a surgical site infection (SSI). These infections typically present after cesarean delivery with peri-incisional erythema and discharge, which are not observed in this case.
❌ 6 to 7 days postpartum:
Incorrect: Thromboembolic events, such as deep vein thrombosis, typically present with unilateral leg swelling and pain 6 to 7 days postpartum. This case involves localized breast findings suggestive of lactational mastitis, which more commonly presents later in the postpartum period.
✅ More than 7 days postpartum:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A previously healthy 28-year-old woman presents to the OB-GYN clinic 48 hours postpartum with fever, lower abdominal pain, and foul-smelling vaginal bleeding that has been worsening. Labor lasted 20 hours and was followed by a cesarean birth due to fetal distress. Intrapartum antibiotics were administered for group B Streptococcus (GBS) prophylaxis. The patient is taking only prenatal vitamins and has no known drug allergies. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), heart rate is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The abdominal examination reveals mild suprapubic tenderness, and the uterine fundus is markedly tender on palpation. There is foul-smelling purulent lochia. A complete blood count (CBC) shows a white blood cell (WBC) count of 18,000/µL with a left shift. Urinalysis and urine culture are negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient's presentation of fever, lower abdominal pain, a tender uterine fundus, and foul-smelling lochia two days postpartum, along with a history of prolonged labor and cesarean delivery, is highly suggestive of postpartum endometritis. The diagnosis is typically clinical and can be made based on history and physical examination after ruling out a urinary tract infection. Additional diagnostic testing is not required, and prompt initiation of empiric antibiotic therapy is essential to reduce the risk of progression to sepsis.

The differential diagnosis of postpartum fever includes endometritis, pyelonephritis, surgical site infections, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), septic pelvic thrombophlebitis, and lactational mastitis. The timing of fever onset can help narrow the differential. When the diagnosis is unclear, further testing such as a complete blood count (CBC), urinalysis, urine culture, or imaging studies may be appropriate.

In this case, the timing, clinical presentation, and negative urinalysis point towards endometritis as the most likely diagnosis. Additional evaluation is only necessary if there is no improvement with empiric treatment.


Option Analysis

❌ Endometrial culture:
Incorrect: Although endometrial culture can help identify the causative organism, it is not routinely obtained in the evaluation and management of postpartum endometritis. Empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics should be started promptly, covering skin, vaginal, and gastrointestinal flora.
❌ Pelvic ultrasound:
Incorrect: Pelvic ultrasound is useful for identifying retained products of conception (POC), but it is not required when the clinical presentation is typical for postpartum endometritis. Retained POC is extremely uncommon following cesarean birth due to the nature of the procedure
❌ Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: A CT scan may be indicated in cases where there is suspicion of other intra-abdominal pathology, including septic pelvic thrombophlebitis. However, this patient’s presentation is classic for endometritis. Further imaging is not required.
❌ Blood cultures:
Incorrect: While blood cultures can be useful in patients with systemic signs of sepsis, they are not necessary for the initial diagnosis and management of postpartum endometritis, where prompt empiric antibiotic therapy should be initiated based on clinical presentation.
✅ Empiric broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 12 weeks of gestation presents to the emergency department with left calf pain that began 2 days ago. The patient reports returning from an 8-hour road trip a day before the onset of symptoms. There is no history of trauma or blood clots. Past medical history is significant for obesity, and the patient is not currently on any medication. There is no significant family history. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 120/76 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the left calf is swollen, erythematous, and tender to palpation, with a 3 cm difference in circumference compared to the right calf. A lower extremity compression ultrasound of the left iliac vein shows poor compressibility. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms consistent with a deep vein thrombosis (DVT), confirmed by poor compressibility on a lower extremity compression ultrasound. The most appropriate initial management for DVT during pregnancy is low molecular weight heparin (LMWH), which effectively prevents clot extension and embolization while remaining safe for both the pregnant person and the fetus.   

Medical management of venous thromboembolism (VTE) in pregnancy primarily involves anticoagulation therapy, with LMWH being preferred due to its safety profile and ease of use. LMWH does not require frequent monitoring and carries a lower risk of osteoporosis and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia compared to unfractionated heparin.    

Vitamin K antagonists, such as warfarin, cross the placenta and are generally avoided during pregnancy due to the risk of teratogenicity and fetal hemorrhage. Direct oral anticoagulants, including direct thrombin inhibitors and factor-Xa inhibitors, have insufficient safety data in pregnancy and are thus not recommended.    

Treatment with LMWH typically continues for at least 3 months and should extend through at least 6 weeks postpartum, a period associated with increased thrombotic risk. If long-term anticoagulation is required after delivery, therapy may be transitioned to warfarin, which is considered safe during breastfeeding.   

Option Analysis

✅ Low molecular weight heparin:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Vitamin K antagonist  :
Incorrect: Vitamin K antagonists, such as warfarin, are contraindicated during pregnancy due to their teratogenic effects, especially in the first trimester, and the risk of fetal hemorrhage. These agents can cross the placenta and negatively impact fetal development. 
❌ Oral direct thrombin inhibitor  :
Incorrect: Oral direct thrombin inhibitors, such as dabigatran, are not recommended in pregnancy due to the lack of sufficient safety data and unknown effects on the fetus. 
❌ Factor-Xa inhibitor  :
Incorrect: Factor-Xa inhibitors, including rivaroxaban and apixaban, should be avoided in pregnancy because of insufficient data regarding their safety and potential risks to the developing fetus.  
❌ Daily aspirin :
Incorrect: Aspirin is not sufficient for the treatment of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). While it may have a role in the prevention of certain thrombotic conditions, it does not provide the necessary anticoagulant effect required to treat an active thrombus.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida at 39 weeks gestation comes to the emergency room in active labor. She has had routine prenatal care. Medical history is significant for gestational diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 105/75 mmHg. She delivers a 4kg male baby. A 2nd-degree perineal tear is noted. Which of the following structures is most likely involved in this injury?
questions.solution:
This patient has a second-degree perineal tear following a difficult childbirth. A second-degree perineal tear involves injury to the perineal body.    

Perineal tears are a common obstetric injury following difficult vaginal childbirth. They are distinct from an episiotomy, an intentional enlargement of the vaginal introitus to facilitate delivery.  

An episiotomy is a surgical incision that involves the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labor. Episiotomies are done to minimize perineal injuries caused by overstretching the perineum by the fetal head; however, they are not routinely indicated.  Possible indications for an episiotomy include conditions when the physician anticipates a perineal tear, elderly primigravida, macrosomia, face to pubis delivery, forceps/ventouse delivery, breech delivery, or shoulder dystocia.    

There are two common approaches to an episiotomy; a mediolateral approach and a median approach.  In a mediolateral episiotomy, the incision is made at an angle and proceeds from the vaginal opening diagonally downwards to the left or the right in a straight line that runs an inch away from the anus.  During a mediolateral episiotomy, structures incised include the posterior vaginal wall, superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus, part of the levator ani, subcutaneous tissue, and skin.  

In the median episiotomy, the incision proceeds from the vaginal opening downwards. Median episiotomies bifurcate the perineal body, which supports the female pelvic organs, particularly the posterior vaginal wall. Incision of the perineal body poses a risk of pelvic organ prolapse and urinary incontinence. Midline episiotomies can also extend into the anal sphincter and cause sphincter dysfunction and fecal incontinence.  





Option Analysis

✅ Perineal body :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Anal mucosa:
Incorrect: Fourth-degree perineal tears involve the anal sphincter complex and the anal mucosa. Second-degree perineal tears are limited to the perineal skin and the perineal body.   
❌ Ischiocavernosus muscle :
Incorrect: The ischiocavernosus muscle is a component of the urogenital triangle and the superficial perineal pouch. It arises from the ischial tuberosity and inserts into the crura of the clitoris. It is unlikely to be involved in second-degree perineal tears.   
❌ Internal anal sphincter :
Incorrect: The anal sphincter complex (internal anal sphincter and the external anal sphincter) are damaged in fourth-degree perineal lacerations.   
❌ External anal sphincter :
Incorrect: Severe perineal lacerations of the third and fourth degrees tend to involve the external anal sphincter and result in fecal incontinence.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the clinic with constipation and pelvic pain. Her last menstrual period was two weeks ago. She reports her menstrual cycles are regular, occurring every 28-30 days and lasting for five days. Her periods are painful, with heavy bleeding that requires her to change tampons every 2 hours for the first 4 days. They were not painful until a few years ago and ibuprofen does not provide relief.  Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg.
